PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Melbourne.
—I note that the Treasurer is not in attendance and my--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will resume his seat.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Les Johnson-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. With respect, I think it is appropriate to draw your attention to the fact that since we changed the Standing Orders to deal with petitions subsequent to Question Time, questioners often have been confronted with a situation in which Ministers to whom they have wanted to direct questions have not been here.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Sinclair-Perhaps I should explain that following the departure of the President of Greece from the airport this morning the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and a number of other senior Ministers have not yet returned to the House.
IMPRISONMENT OF AUSTRALIAN CITIZENS OVERSEAS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister for Administrative Services. How does the Government justify action by its law enforcement liaison officials in other countries which, by co-operation with authorities in those countries, results in the imprisonment of Australians in foreign gaols for long periods in harsh conditions?

—I thank the honourable member for that question. This is a subject that has been reported with some feeling in newspapers around the country. I think that all honourable members would be well aware of the very great problems we have in Australia with drug trafficking and the use of drugs. We therefore have an arrangement with liaison officers from the Australian Federal Police stationed in countries overseas, particularly in South East Asia. It is important to understand that Australia also has international obligations under, for example, United Nations agreements. The purpose of the liaison officers in a country is to exchange information that comes into their hands on drug related offences. Of course, they receive information from their counterparts in that country and the various authorities in the countries then act on that information. I make the point very strongly that it is up to the country which receives the information to act. Sometimes that does result in Australian citizens being tried and convicted in courts and placed in prison. I make two points about that. First of all, my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and other Ministers who preceded him, and I, have made it clear in a number of public statements that Australian citizens run severe risks if they indulge in drug trafficking activities. The second point is that we have made it clear also that if they are arrested, tried and convicted in another country, whilst we will offer all consular facilities that we can to ensure that they are properly defended and, if they go to gaol, that they get a fair deal, that is about all we can do. However, they will have to run the gamut of that country's laws and prison conditions.

—I refer the Treasurer to his statement on 15 September 1981 in this House that 'if one holds down interest rates in certain areas too far and too long, available funds for housing will dry up completely'. Is it a fact that in Victoria, where building society rates are not regulated, interest rates on home loans are the highest in Australia and are one per cent to 1.5 per cent higher than in New South Wales? Is it also a fact that the decline in building society loan approvals in Victoria over the past year was 50 per cent greater than in New South Wales? Finally, is it a fact that the main impact of higher interest rates is to exclude increasing numbers of families from home ownership and to make more people reliant on the rental market for housing and accommodation rather than to make any improvement in the availability of housing finance?

—I recall the statement which I made and to which the honourable gentleman referred, and I do not retreat in any way from what was contained in that statement. It is true that, as interest rates rise, some people, because of the limits of their incomes, are thereby denied the opportunity of purchasing homes. That is part of the problem with interest rates. I have said to the House on a number of occasions that the difficult areas in housing, apart from the overall availability of money for housing which is obviously related to the competitive interest rate structure of deposit-taking institutions which lend for housing, relate to people who have borrowed fairly recently and to those who are trying to gather a deposit in order to purchase a home. They are affected by rising land and property prices as much as by rising interest rates, and in some parts of Australia by more than rising interest rates. The third category of disadvantaged is, of course, renters. That has been my and the Government's analysis of the difficulties in this area for some time, and I see no reason to revise any of the earlier statements that I made on this subject.

—Can the Minister for Defence advise the House as to what new equipment has been supplied to the Army Survey Regiment, Fortuna, Bendigo? Will this new equipment enable the Survey Regiment to provide a more comprehensive mapping service? Will this mapping service be available for civil as well as Defence Force requirements? Can the Minister also advise whether he has heard of further suggestions that the Survey Regiment is to be moved from Bendigo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether it is because of a current political combat in Victoria that there has been, once again, an emergence of the rumour that the Army Survey Regiment at Bendigo is to be moved. I must say to the honourable gentleman and to the House that there is no proposal before me or before the Government to move the regiment, but I cannot speak for five, 10 or 15 years time. I hope that I will have taken up a monastic existence before that time passes by.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking around at some of the gargoyles here, I would feel very much at home. I say to the honourable gentleman that having regard to the very substantial capital investment in Fortuna, I appeal to the commonsense of people possessed with it. That fines the field down a little. I think it was in January this year that my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services announced the letting of a contract for some $3.5m for computerised mapping apparatus. That will be installed progressively. The answer to the honourable gentleman's question: 'Will that be made available to the public?' is yes, it will be through various agencies. It is a very valuable asset as far as the nation is concerned.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education, concerns the decision of the Government to invoke the Commonwealth Employees ( Employment Provisions) Act in respect of striking Australian Capital Territory teachers. Can the Minister say when the first suspensions of the striking teachers will occur and can he inform the House whether those teachers who are suspended will be automatically reinstated at the conclusion of the present industrial dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give no assurance that teachers who are suspended from duty as a result of strike action will ultimately be reinstated. The Act provides for dismissal and such action is likely to be considered if the industrial dispute continues. In answer to the first part of the honourable member's question regarding suspension, let me point out that the decision taken yesterday by the Government applies to those teachers who engage in strike action on or after the commencement of duty today. I have not yet been advised as to whether any suspensions have occurred today, but I give the honourable member and the House an assurance that any teacher who engages in strike action on or after the commencement of duty today will be suspended. I also want to make it clear that this is an unnecessary industrial dispute. It is causing great hardship to many students and great inconvenience to many parents in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a fact that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has made a determination that the new rates of pay will apply from today even if that determination is not taken up for some time. As I pointed out in answer to a question in this House yesterday, the Public Service Board of the Commonwealth is awaiting determinations in the eastern States. The tribunals which currently are sitting in the eastern States will make determinations before the Commonwealth Public Service Board makes an offer. So the two points that are very relevant to this dispute are, firstly, that the Public Service Board has indicated that it will make an offer and, secondly, that it has made it clear that the offer will apply as from today. There is a firm undertaking in this regard.

The Government of the Commonwealth is not going to stand by idly while children 's education is being unnecessarily affected and disrupted in this way by a group of irresponsible teachers. I deplore the action of the ACT Teachers Federation in directing its members not to attend certain schools that are on a roster for strike action over the coming days. We hear a lot in this place and in other forums throughout the Commonwealth about the contribution-the very great contribution-that government schools make to education in Australia and in particular to education in the Australian Capital Territory. The action of the Teachers Federation in the Australian Capital Territory is designed to destroy confidence in the government school system. The Commonwealth is not going to stand by idly. We will take whatever action we consider to be reasonable and necessary in the circumstances.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Has his attention been drawn to the results for January 1982 of the regular survey of consumer confidence conducted by the University of Melbourne and Morgan Research Centre Pty Ltd? Does this survey show that 'consumers are comparatively at their most depressed level for over nine years'? Is the Prime Minister also aware that the survey states:

QUESTION.PARA: The unseasonal gloom currently engendered in consumers is understandable in the light of increasing and new taxes together with a cancellation of promised cuts to income taxes--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman will ask his question.

—In view of the Prime Minister's statement on Tuesday, can he say how the world economic situation rather than his Government's policy is to blame for this stark evidence of a total lack of consumer confidence?

—My attention has been drawn to that survey. I am aware of the summary of the sentiment that was expressed in that survey. I remind the honourable member and also I remind the House that that is not the only survey that the Government looks at. I point out to the honourable member that the Government also takes into account indications of investor and consumer confidence as illustrated by the continued high level of capital investment, the continued strength in retail sales figures and other indicators which show that growth in the Australian economy is still well above the average of the industrialised world.

—Will the Minister for Defence advise if a submission has been received from the Queensland Government for the transfer of part of the Shoalwater Bay Army Reserve for the purpose of opening up Cape Clinton as a coal port? If so, what is the Government's answer to that request.

—I know that my friend is aware of the fact that Port Clinton rests within the largest and most accessible training and exercise ground that we have in Australia. I have stated on a number of occasions that, for my part, I would resolutely oppose any disturbing of the Shoalwater Bay exercise area. Nevertheless, inquiries have been made. Some may describe them as tentative. For my part, I would describe them as having firmer characteristics. It has been suggested that the Commonwealth should surrender Port Clinton in lieu of other land in the area. No formal proposal has been put before the Commonwealth. I would not like to be regarded as insensitive upon this point but if one is put forward the Commonwealth would be under an obligation to hear the other side of the argument, and as a consequence, we would attend to that. But I say to the honourable gentleman and to all those who may be concerned and interested in this matter that my sense of resolution to the surrender of Port Clinton remains as firm as ever.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his statement to the House on Tuesday in which he blamed the failures of his Government on world economic conditions. I ask: Can the Prime Minister explain how the rest of the world prevented his Government from honouring his promise to 'reduce the tax burden'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the contrary, the honourable gentleman has interpreted my statement wrongly because any reading of that statement should make it very plain that Australia has done much better than the rest of the world in spite of difficult world conditions. The whole point of the statement was to indicate that the Government of this country must have policies that minimise, to the maximum extent possible, the effects of adverse world circumstances on the Australian economy. That is precisely what we have done. I regret that the honourable gentleman's interpretation has been inadequate.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday I answered a question about taxation. When we came into government there was a massive deficit which was blowing out. We have reduced that deficit, firstly, by a rigid control of expenditure and secondly, by a more straightforward approach to taxation because this country has got to pay its way as it goes. Having said that and having done that, the claims on the tax dollars of Australians by this Government have been reduced by 2 1/2 cents in the dollar or $3,700m in the course of a full year. If we were spending the proportion that the Leader of the Opposition did as Treasurer for a short time, then we would be spending an extra $3,700m this year. To that extent, the tax burden is significantly less than it would have been.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TASMANIA: REDUCTION IN SHARE OF TAX REVENUE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware of a document issued by the Tasmanian Minister for Education, Mr Aulich, to all State school principals in Tasmania claiming that recommendations are now before Federal Cabinet to cut Tasmania's share of total tax revenue by $64m annually and warning of what he claims would be the effect on the education system of these cuts? Can the Treasurer comment on the truthfulness of this unusual claim by State Labor Minister Aulich?

—As it happens, I am aware of that particular document and I want to say, without any emotional bias on the matter, that it is an extraordinary claim . What the State Labor Minister in the dying Holgate Government is doing, of course, is to misrepresent totally the fact that the Commonwealth Grants Commission, in its report on relativities, made certain recommendations that, if implemented, would have a particular effect. Everybody, and not least the Tasmanian Government because it was represented by the former Premier at the Premiers Conference that dealt with the matter, knows that we went out of our way to protect those States that would be adversely affected by the immediate implementation of that Grants Commission report by calling for a further inquiry to be carried out. In the face of that, which is well known to the Tasmanian Government and to every Tasmanian Minister, for Mr Aulich to put out a document of that kind is to mislead totally the Tasmanian public and is an example of a Government that is well and truly on the run.

—Is the Treasurer aware that over the two years from 1978-79 to 1980-81 the total net profit after tax of finance companies jumped by 120 per cent while their total income rose by only 34 per cent? Is it a fact that the greatest contribution to these higher profits came from leasing business which carries substantial tax benefits? Does this immense growth in profitability of a largely unregulated segment of the finance industry indicate the effect that wholesale deregulation will have on the industry? If so, will the Treasurer repudiate deregulation and immediately look at controlling finance companies in common with all other financial institutions to the good of the community as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the question of the honourable member for Grayndler a very interesting one from two points of view. Firstly, he appears to be concerned about the implications of certain leasing practices. I welcome that concern and I invite him to translate that concern into voting in favour of the income tax amendments the Government proposes in respect of certain leverage leasing arrangements which, according to the honourable member for Gellibrand, the Labor Party will oppose and therefore cost the ordinary Australian taxpayer about $130m which will go into the pockets of the very companies which the honourable member for Grayndler now says make too great a profit. If he is really worried about the financial position of those companies, he had better look to the policies of his own party on that piece of legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second part of the question, I say only that I hold to the views that I have expressed on the subject. I do not believe that the prescription that the honourable member suggests would work. If he thinks that any section of the business community is making too much money, the best remedy is to expose it to more and not less competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns the harp seal slaughter occurring in Canada. Is the Minister aware of the widespread expressions of revulsion from the Australian people, and in particular from Australian school children, of this action? Are there any bilateral treaties or agreements relating to natural resources or the environment that Australia can use to bring pressure to bear on the Canadian Government to stop this killing of young harp seals? Has the Commonwealth Government expressed its disapproval to the Canadian Government on this matter? If so, what form has this expression of disapproval taken?

—Like the honourable member, I have received many letters on the subject. To answer the first part of the question, no, there are no specific bilateral treaties or agreements in place relating to this problem. The Australian Government has had discussions with the Canadian Government about the seal hunt. I have to say that the Canadian Government is generally recognised in the world community as having an enlightened approach towards conservation issues and, as a result of our discussions, we are confident at any rate that the Canadian authorities are competent to deal with the problem. I note that the Canadian Government's policy is to welcome having representatives of known and reputable humane societies to observe the seal hunt. According to the information we have, the harp seal is one of the world's most abundant species, having a population of some millions and the number to be harvested is well below the safety limit. The Canadian authorities have laid down strict regulations to ensure that seals are harvested with a minimum of suffering. Other than to express our concern over the hunt, there are no direct means by which Australia can stop it taking place.

—My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, relates to the sharp rise in yields in Treasury notes to around 18 per cent. In view of the fact that this is 3 1/2 per cent to 4 per cent higher than Commonwealth bond rates, does this put enormous pressure on these bond rates and thereby greatly increase pressure for all interest rates to rise? What measures, if any, is the Treasurer taking to prevent a further general rise in interest rates or is the Government deliberately increasing interest rates in Australia so as to attract more foreign capital inflow and thereby alleviate the balance of payments crisis ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not surprisingly, I am aware of the results of the most recent tender for Treasury notes. I think it has to be said at the outset that for some time now there has been an anticipation that as the Australian financial community enters the final quarter of this financial year there will be increases in short term interest rates and that that situation is likely to be the case throughout the period of the seasonal liquidity rundown. The short term interest rates normally increase at this time of the year. The relatively high rates for Treasury notes not only reflect that but also reflect the continuing very high demand for funds not only from private sector sources but also from Government sources. I can assure the honourable gentleman that the Government-myself in particular-is daily in consultation with the monetary authorities about the situation.

ANSWER.PARA: We make no secret of the fact that we believe that in pursuit of our longer term anti-inflationary objectives it is necessary to maintain a continually firm monetary and fiscal policy and that one of the shorter term consequences of that , particularly at this time of the year, is that there will be outcomes of the type that were indicated yesterday in relation to Treasury notes. If one looks at this matter objectively it has to be accepted that at this time of the year a government has a very difficult balancing act to do. It has to maintain the effectiveness of its anti-inflationary monetary and fiscal policy and at the same time it has to ensure that whilst liquidity conditions remain firm they do not become too tight. That balancing act is not an easy one, but it is one to which my efforts and the Government's efforts will be bent very carefully and in a very conscientious way over the coming weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport aware of concern being expressed in Western Australia that the Federal Government may not proceed with its commitment to upgrade Perth Airport? Can the Minister assure the House that work on both the domestic and the international facilities at Perth Airport will proceed as announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Press reports which have reported Mr MacKinnon as having said that it appears that the Commonwealth is backing off in respect of Perth Airport. Let me make it very clear that the Government has approved in principle the expenditure of approximately $43m for upgrading the facilities at the international and domestic terminals and the 02/20 runway which, of course, is being lengthened to accommodate the long range international aircraft. Works to the value of $18m are in progress; some have been completed. There has been some delay because we have decided to meet the request of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and community groups in Perth to produce a master plan, which, I hope, will be ready in the very near future for presentation to that Committee. Residents around the airport have expressed some concern about the location of the air traffic control tower. I have no doubt that the provision of the master plan will necessitate some delay but I am sure that that would be desirable to ensure that we do not close off options in respect of perhaps a wide-spaced parallel runway to meet the future needs of the area. I hope that the plan will be in the hands of the Public Works Committee in sufficient time to permit the Committee to give it due consideration and report to this Parliament so that the Government may consider , in the course of budgetary discussions later this year, future capital needs in meeting the in-principle decision.

ANSWER.PARA: If all of those timetables can be met I assume that we will be able to complete the international terminal facility at a time that will be reasonably close to the forecast date announced some time ago, namely, the end of 1984. If there is a delay in completion I am sure that it will be in the best interests of the people of Perth. However, I assure the honourable member and the people of Perth and Western Australia generally that the Government is not backing off from a decision to provide adequate facilities for people travelling by air to and from Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, refers to the clear evidence of a severe and worsening credit squeeze, with spiralling interest rates and very tight money supply. I ask: Does he recognise that in this extremely restrictive economic setting highly geared corporations and financial institutions are vulnerable and that informed money market opinion is that a couple of financial institutions could easily fail? Therefore, if he is not prepared to ease out the money supply, thereby reducing pressure on interest rates and freeing the economy, would he be prepared to extend lender of last resort backing to reputable financial institutions in order to remove any fears that small savers who invest in such institutions will become the next victims of the excesses of government economic policy?

—I must say that I am disturbed at the question by the Leader of the Opposition, not for the reason that he hopes, but rather for the reason that if he has any information which, according to him, represents informed money market opinion about the stability of particular financial institutions he should do the responsible thing and provide that information either to me or the Governor of the Reserve Bank, a person who, incidentally, was first appointed to that position by the former Labor Government. If the Leader of the Opposition is really concerned about the stability of the financial system and about preventing the sorts of results that his question suggests, he will do the responsible, not the irresponsible, thing. But by asking such questions and by making the sorts of statements that he made yesterday, he is merely imitating the behaviour of the Premier of New South Wales who delights in scaring young home buyers. Apparently, the Leader of the Opposition delights in scaring small investors. I say to him and to the House that I have no information from the authorities that would lend substance to the irresponsible claim that he makes in his question.

—I ask the Minister for Trade and Resources whether he can indicate the present stage of discussions with New Zealand in regard to achieving closer economic relations. In particular, I refer to the effect of these negotiations upon Australia's rural industries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is probably aware that negotiations have been proceeding for a number of years on whether it is possible to achieve a closer economic relationship with New Zealand, replacing the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement which has been in operation for the past 15 years. It has been considered that an upgrading of economic and trade activity is needed between the two countries and it is suggested that if we could move towards a closer economic relationship there would be greater activity between our two countries. Up to date, in the discussions that have taken place, a good deal of common ground has been achieved although some problems still remain. Problems relating to rural industries have been looked at closely. Some of them have been looked at on an industry to industry basis and we have been able to come to satisfactory arrangements. In other cases, such as the dairying industry, discussions are continuing.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the New Zealand Minister for Trade and Industry, Mr Templeton, is in Australia at present. He will be having discussions with Ministers and members of parliament. I believe the purpose of his mission is to express the interest of New Zealand in trying to achieve a closer economic relationship and the importance New Zealand sees for its own future well-being in being able to trade more freely with Australia. Australia sees economic opportunities in New Zealand for itself in regard to a wide range of products, not only in manufacturing but also in agriculture. I am sure that if other countries, particularly European countries, can achieve common trading conditions it ought to be possible for Australia to do likewise. At the moment the objective is to achieve an agreement which will come into operation on 1 January 1983. Whether that can be achieved will depend on the satisfactory result of negotiations between Australia and New Zealand. Until there has been further discussion between officials, and with the industry, I will have nothing more to report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the statement by Mr Alan Coates, a member of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System , that it is important when examining the level of interest rates to understand the role of the Commonwealth Treasury in setting those rates. Mr Coates stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Every interest rate now on offer in the market is being set by Treasury bill rates. They are leading the market to where it is now.

Is it a fact that as a result of increased yields on Treasury notes the June interest rate futures contracts are now trading at over 20 per cent? Accordingly , I ask why the Government is using its power in the capital market to increase interest rates to the levels now prevailing instead of invoking Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act to reduce interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that a very interesting question. As to the first part, I am aware of the statement by Mr Alan Coates. He is a person of very considerable ability and I have great respect for him but I do not regard his statements on this subject as being totally the last word on interest rates. I believe and the Government believes that interest rates ultimately are a reflection of the demand for and the supply of money in the community, and anybody who parades under the delusion that we can ignore that does not understand how our system operates. Quite obviously the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues imagine that governments can expand their borrowing demands and therefore add pressure on interest rates and at the same time, by legislative action, force those interest rates down. A government that tries to do that is not being realistic.
—What is the alternative?

—The alternative is a government, by its own actions, trying to reduce the demand for money in the community, which is the complete opposite of the policy urged upon us by the Opposition. The last thing that the Australian economy wants at present, the last thing that the cause of lower interest rates wants, is the sort of policy that will lead to an expansion of the Budget deficit, which is constantly being advocated by the Opposition parties.

—I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to recent reports of the withdrawal of the extreme right wing of the National Party Government in South Africa. I ask the Minister whether any change of this Government's policy in relation to South Africa is contemplated in the light of this development which will, I hope, open a way for long overdue major changes in that country's system of apartheid?

—The Government has followed with a great deal of interest recent reports on the internal political developments in South Africa and particularly the break-away of the extreme right wing of the National Party to which the honourable member has referred. We will be watching to see whether this leads to any improvement in the South African Government's record in relation to the system of apartheid. We are also aware that the present South African Prime Minister said when he assumed office about four years ago that white South Africans had to adapt or die. Those were his words. That message was welcomed by critics of apartheid as an indication of a commitment to major reform of the system. I have to say that in the four years since then there has been very little movement. There have been a few changes at the margins of apartheid. For example, some restaurants have been opened to non-whites. But the basic legislative structure of apartheid still remains.
—It has got worse.

—In some respects it has got worse. I am aware that some defenders of the present South African Prime Minister have said that he has been inhibited in any moves towards reform by the restraints imposed on him by the extreme right wing of his party. It appears that some of those restraints at any rate now do not apply. Australia and the rest of the international community will be watching closely to see any evidence that Mr Botha and the National Party will undertake major changes to apartheid. If we are convinced that major changes have substance and that the South African Government is sincere in them they would have our support.

—Can the Minister for Transport confirm that a committee is considering an application to allow passenger jets to land at Sydney Airport during curfew hours? What is the composition of the committee and what consideration, if any, will be given to the welfare of the quarter of a million residents of Sydney already directly and adversely affected by aircraft noise? Is this in fact another nail in the coffin of the curfew?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I was surprised when I saw a Press report in a Sydney evening paper. No doubt it inspired the question from the honourable member for St George. I have made it clear on a number of occasions that there has been no decision on Trans Australia Airlines' application to allow its Airbus to operate during curfew hours. I will certainly not consider such a proposition until I have received a full report from the airport noise abatement committee and other committees that are inquiring into the whole question of the noise level of the Airbus.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also made it clear that the question of curfews will be considered only against the background of reduced noise levels surrounding airports. I have not veered from that policy. I expect the Aviation Industry Advisory Council to receive a report from a group of people associated with the airline industry as well as with State and Federal departments relating to the noise environment around airports. The Council will recommend whether there should be any review of existing curfew arrangements. But there is no way that the Government will relax curfews at Sydney Airport if such a move will mean additional noise in the community surrounding Sydney Airport.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit of the collection of excise duties and deferred Customs duties by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair)-by leave- proposed:

(1) That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the report of the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit of the collection of excise duties and deferred Customs duties by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, and
(2) that the report be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for inquiry and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to raise, I trust briefly-it is always risky I know-the procedures associated with the dispatch in this House of reports of the Auditor-General. These are probably the most important reports which come before us. They are effectively a test of the efficiency and effectiveness of departments. As things stand now, these reports, which should be the subject of substantial debate, are referred to committees for attention and there they seem to be buried. The processes are obviously either too turgid in the committees or so complex and demanding as to render them incapable of responding to the needs of this Parliament. The needs of this Parliament are for an early debate on the contents of the reports. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has pointed out to me, with his usual attention to this sort of important detail, that the records of the House show that the last annual report of the Auditor-General was presented to this Parliament in April last year and was referred to a committee. As I understand it-the honourable member for Corio will correct me if I am wrong-that report is still with the committee. There was an efficiency audit report of the Auditor- General in October of last year and it is still with the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The point does not have to be laboured. There are, obviously, from the earmarked bits of paper in these several reports, many instances where the Auditor-General, in his commendable and invaluable work, has uncovered matters of concern to this Parliament and to the community. I will not cite them all-in fact very few of them-because I am sure that the force of the point is quite apparent to honourable members. I would expect that bi-partisanly we would share this concern. But I will deal with a few of them. In relation to the Department of Administrative Services the report of the Auditor-General of March 1981 stated:
It is a matter for concern that, at the time of the audit, claims examinations were significantly in arrears, the backlog being estimated at approximately 10- man years.

The report goes on to talk about staff shortages. I do not think I need to give any more illustrations of that. There are at least half a score to a dozen earmarked pages where similar comment is made in that report. We also have the Auditor-General's report upon financial statements which was prepared in June 1980. At pages 82 and 83 matters were referred to in connection with the Department of Health. The shortage of staff is raised. Page 83 of the report states:
Without the provision for staff training, especially in computer-based audit techniques, it is doubtful whether existing departmental staff have the necessary expertise.

This is a reference to doctor fraud. I think this is an appalling situation and one which requires attention. Page 5 of the Auditor-General's report of March 1981 upon audits, examinations and inspections under the appropriate Act, states :
A contractor submitted a tender for the purchase of torpedo batteries having a high silver content.
The report goes on to discuss the way in which this matter developed. It then points out:
Although the differential cannot be quantified exactly the difference between the value of the metal at dates of tender and delivery has been estimated at $ 203 680.
In a nutshell we were taken for a ride. Page 68 the report states:

. . . an error of some $260 000 in a departmental document comparing estimated costs of a project at the sketch plan stage with those at the detailed cost estimate stage ($1 855 000 in 1976 as compared with $2 764 000 in 1978) . . .

That refers to the Department of Social Security. There are quite a number of errors and frankly I have mentioned the lesser ones. Mr Speaker, you will recall that there have been some major disclosures by the Auditor-General of deficiencies in audit processes, efficiency and practices. They represent losses to the community which have to be borne.

Because of the shortness of time I have not had the opportunity of highlighting the more dramatic examples. I do not believe it is necessary. I would expect that we would all share the concern I have that these matters are of such moment and they are so numerous because they have been reported on so frequently and in so many different areas, that there is obviously a need for a tightening up in the way in which the Public Service is being administered. The most obvious deficiency is staff ceilings. Staff shortages are not creating savings; they are generating costs, through amounts of money which are not being detected through effective audit or administrative processes and through inefficiencies. The most dramatic example is the disclosure that staff ceilings in the Australian Taxation Office have saved petty cash at the cost of millions of dollars of tax revenue that is not being collected.

I am saying that perhaps we could have a system so that in future these reports would have a specified period during which the Committee could attend to them and report back-if not finally, on an interim basis- to the Parliament and the Parliament proceed with a debate. I suggest that these matters are of such great moment and the scandal is so appalling and staggering in many cases that the Parliament should not have to wait any more than three to four weeks before it commences debating these topics. If the Committee is not up to handling that-I acknowledge that there would be difficulties about producing even an interim report-nonetheless the Parliament must proceed and put on record its grave concern. Our great obligation is to make the public sector system work. Institutions serving the community outside this Parliament, in my view and from my experience, do so loyally and well. They have to forebear, not infrequently, with ministerial incompetence and most of all, obloquy which is heaped upon their shoulders quite unfairly by Government Ministers who are seeking to escape imputation of blame for their own shortcomings. I want to put that on record because this is not a broad brush accusation or attack on the Public Service. I repeat, that largely I believe the deficiencies arise because of the restrictive arrangements about staff. We cannot increase the work load and freeze the staff levels and expect efficiency to be maintained. It goes down. We can save petty cash in our bookkeeping presentation but at enormous real expense to the community in inferior services, deficiencies in general administrative arrangements and so on. We lose more than we gain.

Those are the things that we should be talking about. They are not the sensationalist or scandalous things that the media might want to attend to, although from time to time the larger matters have drawn their attention. But they are the things that determine the efficiency, the quality and the satisfaction level of the service that the Public Service can give the community . I am arguing that we should be backing up the Public Service in its claim to be able to provide superior services. That can be substantially done only by proper attention by this Parliament to what is going on and unremitting commitment by the Parliament to guarantee that a sufficient level of qualified staff is made available for the Public Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should take the opportunity to clarify a couple of points raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). Firstly, I am delighted to see that at last he has discovered the existence of the Auditor-General's report. I do not recall that he, after many years as Leader of the Opposition, and prior to that as a Minister in this House, has ever made any reference to them. Furthermore, the point should be made that the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts and the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee, which is chaired by my colleague, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), have been handling the examination of Auditor-General's reports for many years, and this in turn includes the handling of the efficiency audit reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) this morning referred the next report, which is the fourth report, to my Committee. The previous two reports were referred to the Expenditure Committee. If I am correct that Committee has reported on at least one of those reports, if not both. I am sure the honourable member for Hume will correct me if I am wrong. The only report outstanding is that into the question of overseas aid, which is a very complex matter and which involves a whole range of issues. Because of their nature they cannot be categorised in mathematical terms as there is considerable subjectivity in the decision making process in the field of foreign aid.

We look now to the fourth report which has been tabled. If the Leader of the Opposition cares to look at page 6406 of Notice Paper No. 74 he will see that many of the items which he has taken out at random from the Auditor-General's report in fact are subject to investigation by the Public Accounts Committee. There is a standard procedure for Committee members to sit down with the Auditor -General, after the reports have been tabled in the Parliament, to go through them systematically and to make their own determinations as to which items are worthy of further examination. In due course we report to the Parliament.

Where the problem lies-the honourable gentleman is certainly correct on this point; it has been emphasised by me and many chairmen for years prior to my occupancy of that position-is in the need for this Parliament to be prepared to have a serious debate on the recommendations made by parliamentary committees, especially in the audit and financial area. The fact that we are not doing so is remiss of us as members of Parliament. I certainly recommend that we provide time for a significant debate on this matter. I would not like the people of Australia to think that the Auditor-General's reports are simply put away and allowed to gather yet further dust when, in fact, that is not the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate briefly. There is a difference between what has been said and a committee examining a document, such as the Auditor-General's report, in some detail and at some length. It should be pointed out that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts currently has before it some 23 references, including some which derive from the 1979-80 Auditor-General 's report. The point that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) made and which I make is that the Parliament has a responsibility to deal with the reports which it requires to be presented to it. The Auditor-General reports to the Parliament, which is evidenced by the fact that you, sir, present his reports to this Parliament. They are important enough in that they have regularly made significant disclosures of bad or at least doubtful practices or inefficiencies which have had to be debated in the Parliament shortly after their presentation. It is a function of the Parliament to supervise public expenditures. It is a function of this House to supervise the finances and the administration of government in this nation. That is what the Parliament is all about. The House of Representatives, at least technically, has responsibility for money.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not suggesting that the Public Accounts Committee should not continue its detailed examination of these reports, but on each occasion a report is presented to the Parliament time should be set aside for members to examine it. Not more than four weeks after its presentation the Parliament should debate the Auditor-General's report as one of its major functions in exercising its authority over the Executive government in its administration of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few words to the debate as Chairman of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee, which Committee has some responsibility in this area. I think the debate which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) have engaged in has gone a little wider than the motion before the House. I will restrict myself to that matter. The reality is that efficiency audits are referred for examination, on behalf of the House, to either the Joint Committee of Public Accounts or the Expenditure Committee. As the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee has already stated, the first two of these reports went before the Expenditure Committee under reference from this chamber and both of those reports have been tabled in the House following inquiry by the Expenditure Committee. The next two have been referred to the Public Accounts Committee and will be referred back here.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have any problem with the suggestion that has been made by the honourable member for Corio that those reports should then be the subject of further debate in the House. I think that is perfectly proper. But there are procedures which have been adopted and which, as I understand it, there has been no disputation about, that provide for reaction from both the bureaucracy and the Government to the reports the parliamentary committees have made, having inquired into the reports that the Auditor-General has made. In the case of the Public Accounts Committee, there is the Treasury minute procedure whereby the bureaucracy comes back to respond to the points made by the Public Accounts Committee and those comments are then tabled in this Parliament as a further report of the Public Accounts Committee. They are subject to debate if there is a desire to bring the matter on for debate.

At least the Government responds in this Parliament, as a government, to the report of the Expenditure Committee, and the responsible Minister comes forward with a response. The Committee has expressed some concern about the delay with responses to efficiency audits. The procedure that has been adopted in relation to normal reports by committees to the Parliament involves the Government or the appropriate Minister responding within six months of the report being tabled in the Parliament. But in the case of an efficiency audit report from the Auditor- General, because the matter has been before the Government and the appropriate departments at the same time as it has been before the Expenditure Committee, and now the Public Accounts Committee during its consideration of the report, we have taken the view that it is proper that the Government give consideration to the time within which it will respond to the Expenditure Committee's report on the audit after it has been tabled.

I, as Chairman of the Expenditure Committee, have written to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to suggest that he change the response period from six months to three months. Once the response has been made I think it is probably important in many cases, because of the nature of the issues raised, that debate ensue. But I think that the Opposition, in putting forward a suggestion that the House in its plenum debate matters of import from the Auditor-General's report or from his reports on efficiency audits before they have been looked at by the committees of the House and a response from the Government has been forthcoming, is being unrealistic.

The other thing, of course, is that both the committees to which I have been referring have members from both sides of the House. The Public Accounts Committee also has members from both sides of the Parliament, from the Senate also. The opportunities are there for fully raising all the matters of substance . I think the Leader of the Opposition is raising the matter in little more emotive fashion than it needs to be raised in. It is important that the House and the world at large understand that these matters are handled properly and thoroughly and that there is adequate opportunity for debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
