DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment report on marine science. I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RESPONSES TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT RECOMMENDATIONS-AUSTRALIAN MARINE SCIENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Recommendation 1 An Australian Marine Science Council be established. This Council would: operate as the national adviser on marine science matters, especially in the areas of policy development; co-ordinate marine science research efforts; liaise with similar bodies overseas; and finance marine science research projects.
Response The Government considers that a Marine Science Council as proposed by the Senate Committee is not appropriate at this time.

Recent initiatives of the Government have demonstrated its strong commitment to develop a worthwhile, effective and cohesive marine science programme. Support has been given to the relocation of the headquarters of CSIRO's marine research facilities in new laboratories in Hobart and to the acquistion by CSIRO of a specialised oceanographic research ship to be operated as a national facility. The Antarctic Division of the Department of Science and Technology has been transferred to new facilities in Kingston, Tasmania and is being developed as a centre of excellence in Southern Ocean marine biology. The Australian Maritime College in Launceston was established by Commonwealth legislation in 1978 to provide for maritime and maritime related education and training for the shipping, fishing and allied industries. Substantial new resources have been directed to increasing our knowledge of the Australian Fishing Zone and a large part of this assistance is being channelled through CSIRO's Division of Fisheries Research. The Australian Institute of Marine Science has had its staffing levels increased and is endeavouring to establish for itself a major scientific reputation as a centre of tropical marine research. The new structure of the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics will include a Division of Marine Geosciences and Petroleum Geology; funds have been allocated for the Bureau to undertake a major geophysical survey of Bass Basin. Additional resources have been provided for the work of the Navy Hydrographer and the Division of National Mapping to accelerate the charting of Australia's marine areas. These operational developments have been supported by the development of policy advisory mechanisms. Special funding has been provided for marine science and technology projects for allocation on the advice of the Funding Advisory Panel of the Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee. For greater flexibility this panel has now been amalgamated with the Queen's Fellowships in Marine Science Committee. As a result of the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions AMSTAC now reports to the Minister for Science and Technology. This has served to consolidate marine sciences and technologies advisory and funding functions within a single Ministry that has also an operational role.

These arrangements are the result of recent initiatives designed to cope with the present and near-future level of marine science activity. The considerable cost and disruption that would be involved in setting up a Marine Science Council are not justified at the present stage of development of Australian marine science. Acceptance of these recommendations would also be contrary to the Government's policy of financial restraint and its concern to reduce the number of statutory bodies. Existing institutional arrangements, including AMSTAC exercising a coordinating role and providing advice on marine science programmes and priorities, are considered adequate for meeting present needs. The Government believes that AMSTAC already has functioned to good effect and with continuing support will become even more effective. The organisational model and concept proposed in this and related recommendations, though inappropriate at present, may have a place at some future time as Australia's marine science effort evolves.

Recommendation 2 The Australian Marine Science Council co-ordinates research efforts through Regional and Marine Sciences Committees and an Advisory Committee. The Council, through its Executive and Secretariat, would be responsible for operating an Information Services Unit and a Ship Operations Unit. The Council would also manage the two proposed Research Institutes, presently operating as the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the CSIRO Division of Fisheries Research and Oceanography.
Response See Response to Recommendations 1 and 15.

Recommendation 3 The Australian Institute of Marine Science Act 1972 be repealed and replaced with an Australian Marine Science Act. This Act would contain such provisions as are necessary to enable the Australian Marine Science Council to fulfil its proposed functions.
Response See comment on Recommendation 1. The Government does not consider these legislative changes are necessary.

Recommendation 4 A Marine Science Research Endowment Bill be enacted to establish a Marine Science Research and Development Fund. The Australian Marine Science Council would be responsible for advising the Minister for Science and Technology on the administration of the fund.

Response Not accepted. The Government does not believe that the establishment of a Marine Science Research and Development Fund would offer any advantage over existing funding mechanisms. Such a Fund would account for only part of the Commonwealth's total expenditure on Marine Science Research. It could not comprehend Tertiary Education Commission and Australian Research Grants Committee funding of marine science for example, and would have no effect on State or private sector funding activities. The Government considers that a plurality of funding mechanisms helps to maintain a proper balance of funding availability between research, development and routine monitoring. In certain circumstances amalgamation of funding sources may be desire- able to increase the flexibility of funding. For this reason AMSTAC-FAP and Queen's Fellowships in marine science have already been amalgamated. Co-ordination between Commonwealth funding agencies already occurs, and ensures that proposals are transferred to the most appropriate agency.
Recommendation 5 A small Secretariat be made available by the Department of Science and Technology to provide administrative support for the Council.
Response See comment on Recommendation 1. The Department of Science and Technology provides secretariat support for AMSTAC.
Recommendation 6 Four marine science regions be identified.These regions would be based on northern, eastern, southern and western waters.
Response See response to Recommendation 8.
Recommendation 7 Four Regional Committees be established, comprising representatives for all major marine science agencies in each region.

The Committee recognises that two streams of committees will be necessary: one stream to co-ordinate and advise on a regional basis; and other stream to deal with special disciplines in marine science. Recommendations 8-12 refer to these committees.
Response See response to Recommendation 8.

Recommendation 8 The role of the regional Committees be: to co-ordinate research activities within the region, to the extent of advising the Council of any overlap; to provide a means of encouraging co-operation and liaison between researchers and agencies in that region; to ensure that individuals or organisations seeking finance for marine science research have access to the financing process; to advise the Council of areas of research, or research projects, which they consider are worthy of support, and to generally represent the region's interest.

Response The Government recognises the need for the coordination of regional advice but believes that the Committee's proposed regions are not an adequate reflection of the scale, complexity and natural regionalisation of Australia's continental margin, of the very different priorities attached to the scientific study of particular regions (such as the Barrier Reef, Bass Strait and the North -west Shelf) or of the location of existing and proposed facilities around the Australian coast. The proposed Committee structure would be unduly cumbersome and expensive. AMSTAC's terms of reference provide a sufficiently broad charter for it to obtain necessary information from regional, sectoral and disciplinary sources when developing its advice to Government. AMSTAC is expected to give increasing consideration to specific regional research needs and priorities. Already AMSTAC is moving to cultivate closer links with regional organisations such as the Antarctic Research Policy Advisory Committee, the various committees concerned with the Great Barrier Reef, regional committees of the Australian Fisheries Council, the Victorian Institute of Marine Sciences and other state- oriented marine science agencies.

Recommedation 9 Appropriate Marine Sciences Committees be established. These Committees would include the interests of the following areas: marine biology; fisheries research and technology; marine geosciences; oceanography; marine taxonomy; coastal and ocean engineering; and marine environmental studies.
Response See comment on Recommendation 10.

Recommendation 10 The role of the Marine Sciences Committees be: to co-ordinate research activities undertaken in their field and to reduce unnecessary duplication of research; to operate as an information source to researchers by providing resumes of current research being undertaken in the field; to encourage joint research projects across agencies and regions; to ensure that individuals or organisations seeking finance for marine science research have access to the financing process; to advise the Council of areas of research, or research projects, which they consider are worthy of support; and to generally represent the discipline's interests.
Response See comment on recomendations 1, 6, 7 and 8.

The Government believes that co-ordination of research activities is best achieved by ensuring that operating agencies receive effective support for scientific collaboration and for encouraging and facilitating contracts between working scientists through the promotion of conferences and workshops, and the dissemination of information. Inadequate co-ordination and collaboration arise as often at the interdisciplinary level as within specific disciplines. AMSTAC will continue to establish specific-purpose working parties to undertake major investigations in the course of which advice and information is sought from non- government disciplinary organisations such as the National Committee on Coastal and Ocean Engineering (of the Australian Institution of Engineers), the Australian Marine Sciences Association, and the Consortium for Ocean geosciences of Australian Universities. AMSTAC is conscious of the need to identify, and to seek information from those organisations which utilise the results of marine science as well as those carrying out research.

Recommendation 11 One broadly based Advisory Committee be established to advise the Council on programme planning and evaluation, education and training, and the conferring of fellowships, scholarships and project and programme grants.
Response See comment on Recommendations 1 and 2.

Advice on marine sciences and technologies programs is provided to the Minister for Science and technology by AMSTAC. The amalgamated AMSTAC-FAP and Queen's Fellowships in Marine Science Committee advises the Minister on the conferring of fellowships and on project and programme grants in the context of priorities set by the Minister on advice from AMSTAC. Responsibility for advising the Government on the level and pattern of provision of tertiary education lies with the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission.

Recommendation 12 The CSIRO cease to conduct marine science research, and the Divisions of Fisheries Research and Oceanography become a separate Research Institute. This Research Institute, together with the Australian Institute of Marine Science, would become Research Institutes responsible to the Australian Marine Science Council.
Response See comment on Recommendation 13.

Recommendation 13 Each Institute would have its own Board, to which the Director of the Institute, subject to Council policy, would be responsible for the management and operations of the Institute. The research programmes would be approved annually by the Council and would be financed by the Marine Science Research and Development Fund. The Council would direct the Institutes to develop independent programmes to avoid unnecessary duplication.

Response Not accepted. See response to Recommendation 1. CSIRO has a responsibility to continue to play a major role in Australian marine science in accordance with the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 as amended in 1978, following the Government's acceptance of the Report of the Independent Committee of Inquiry into CSIRO. The Executive of CSIRO has given marine research a high priority. The Government believes that removing the marine science divisions from CSIRO would, without providing any compensating benefits, break existing links which facilitate interdisciplinary consultations and a multidisciplinary approach especially to problems which bear on both the terrestrial and marine environments. Within CSIRO the marine science divisions interact on the widest possible range of skills and resources and utilise the capabilities of various scientific disciplines to meet changing objectives. The Government has previously accepted the recommendations of ASTEC that the future long-term role of AIMS (5 years ahead and more) be determined by the situation at that time, including the reputation and capabilities of AIMS and of other institutions, as they evolve and that for the forseeable future AIMS should direct its research towards programmes associated with the tropical waters of Australia, particularly, the Great Barrier Reef Region, and chiefly in appropriate marine biological/ecological fields.
Recommendation 14
In view of the importance of the dissemination of information the Australian Marine Science Council becomes a user of the CSIRONET computing service.
Response CSIRONET is a commercially available computing service and its facilities are available to whoever needs them. Several marine science data banks are already stored on CSIRONET.
Recommendation 15 The Council establish an Information services unit to service the information needs of the organisation and researchers and agencies concerned with marine science.

Response The Government recognises that the effective management of information is a key element in a national marine science program and believes that it is of prime importance that the transfer of information and data are readily available to those who have a need for them. However, it believes that a strongly centralised information services unit is not practicable. Data and information are best managed by those with prime responsibility for collection and with the necessary expertise to analyse them. A basic need in information management is to have a readily available central registry of what data and information are available and where they can be obtained. To this end the Department of Science and Technology is currently compiling an inventory of marine science data banks and a directory of current research projects. In addition, a research officer is being funded through the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account to investigate the fishing industry's need for scientific information and how to develop better mechanisms for distributing this information.
Recommendation 16 The Council establish a Ship Operations unit to co-ordinate the operational management of marine science research vessels.
Response See comment on Recommendation 18.

Recommendation 17 The Ship Operations unit be responsible for co-ordinating information concerning available ship time on Australian and overseas vessels in Australian waters. The unit would administer a fund to enable scientists to take up ship time opportunities at very short notice.
Response See comment on Recommendation 18.

Recommendation 18 The Ship Operations Unit establish a Users Committee, comprising representatives of the various disciplines which require access to research vessels. The Users Committee would be an integral part of the Ship Operations Unit.

Response The Government accepts that research vessels need to be utilised to their maximum extent possible subject to necessary considerations of scientific and cost effectiveness and that a mechanism is needed to co-ordinate the use of available ship time. However, it does not consider that a centralised system of control is required at this time and believes that research vessels, including those acquired as national facilities, should be managed by major operational agencies. The Government has already accepted ASTEC advice that organisations managing a research vessel designated as a national facility should appoint a committee, comprising representatives of major users of the vessel, to provide advice on the allocation of vessel time.

Recommendation 19 Marine science research vessels purchased, or chartered, as national facilities be managed for the most part by experienced marine contractors and that these contractors form part of the Ship Operations Unit. Such contractors would liaise closely with the Users Committee to ensure compatibility in decision making.

Response In response to the Report of the Review of Commonwealth Government Functions, the Government has decided that there should be further contracting of its services to the private sector where practicable. In this regard the need is recognised for maximum scientific and cost effectiveness in the use of research vessels. Accordingly the Government will consider in particular cases whether the best results would be achieved through management by marine contractors or through Government operation. In all cases close liaison between operators and users is essential.
Recommendation 20 Wherever possible all marine science research vessels be chartered, and experienced marine contractors consulted in identifying research vessels suitable for charter or purchase.

Response The practice of chartering research vessels is well established in Australia. If a vessel is required for a definite and short-term project, chartering may provide the necessary flexibility if a suitable vessel exists, is available, and can be used to full capacity during the charter period. However the Government believes that, where there is a continuing need, or where a long- term project is envisaged, purchase may be cheaper than chartering. All relevant sources of advice are used in identifying vessels suitable for charter or purchase.
Recommendation 21 Encouragement be given to developing modular research vessels.

Response Most research vessels constructed recently have some provision for interchanging laboratories but overseas' experience has shown that fully modular research vessels have not proved generally effective. It is the view of the Government that users should be uninhibited in selection of vessels designed to meet particular needs.
Recommendation 22 The Ship Operations Unit fully consider the acquisition of small research vessels for use by bodies such as universities, colleges and museums.
Response The acquisition of small research vessels is a matter for the individual institutions concerned.

Recommendation 23 AMSTAC and ASTEC oversee the establishment of the Australian Marine Science Council. Thereafter, AMSTAC and its Funding Advisory Panel would no longer exist, as the Advisory Committee would assume the responsibilities of AMSTAC.
Response See comment on Recommendation 1.

Recommendation 24 A marine science policy be developed incorporating such aspects as: The types of research to be financed; and mechanisms for the selection, financing and effectiveness of research as well as the exploitation of research results.
Response See comment on Recommendation 1.

Recommendation 25 All possible avenues be explored to acquire a complete bathymetric and hydrographic survey of the Australian coast as rapidly as possible. These measures could include financial assistance to the Royal Australian Navy Hydrographer, the Australian Survey Office, the Division of National Mapping and private contractors.

Response The Government accepts the importance of having a complete bathymetric and hyrdographic survey of the Australian coast. It has recently committed the ' 'Cape Pillar'' for additional bathymetric work, at least until the end of 1982. The Division of National Mapping of the Department of National Development and Energy has been allocated additional funds of $1.5 million in 1981-82 for that purpose.

Recommendation 26 Funding of physical and chemical oceanography be increased, particularly in determining an understanding of the tides, waves and circulation patterns of the continental shelf. Priority should be given to processing this information such that it can be widely made known to other marine scientists.

Response Accepted. The Government decided in 1980 to establish CSIRO Marine Science Laboratories at Hobart to be supported by an oceanographic research vessel. The Government notes that CSIRO attaches high priority and commitment to marine sciences and especially oceanography, and inter alia is reallocating staff and resources to this end. The need for routine collection and distribution of oceanographic data is being considered and proposals aimed at meeting this need are being developed.
Recommendation 27 The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 be amended so as to reduce the period of time for the release of information from five years to twelve months.

Response Not accepted. The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 was extensively amended in 1980 following consultation with all State Governments. Amendment of the relevant provision (Section 118) was considered at that time, but it was decided that no changes would be made to this provision.

Recommendation 28 Priorities for coastal and ocean engineering in the protection of our foreshores and the development of our mineral resources be better recognised. Emphasis should be given to the provision of tanks and basins for the simulation of wave, current and wind impact on structures and the sediment bed.
Response This recommendation is in accord with advice received from ASTEC/AMSTAC and is being considered in detail by a working group of AMSTAC.

Recommendation 29 The adoption of a national code to provide a development-free zone of approximately 1 km from the shoreline for those areas of the Australian coast which have not yet been developed and where there is any risk of shoreline erosion or instability.

Response Although the Commonwealth has constitutional power with respect to maritime areas beyond low water mark adjacent to the States, under the offshore constitutional settlement each State is to have the same power with respect to the adjacent territorial sea (including the sea bed) as it would have if the waters were within the limit of the State. The establishment of such a zone would, therefore, be mainly a matter for the States, subject to any Commonwealth legislation. The matter will be taken up with them in accordance with the Commonwealth Government's decisions on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation Report on Management of the Coastal Zone which is being considered by the State Governments.

Recommendation 30 A blue-water research vessel be acquired, or a modular laboratory be developed for, the marine geosciences, and that Australia seriously consider participating in the forthcoming Ocean Margins Drilling Programme. Priority should be given to upgrading the services provided by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics.

Response The matters raised in this recommendation have also been foreshadowed as important issues for future action by AMSTAC in its report ''Towards a Marine Sciences and Technologies Program for the 1980s''. Participation in the Ocean Margins Drilling Program is not considered warranted. However the Government is expecting to receive shortly a proposal from Australian marine geoscientists concerning participation by Australia in the second phase of the International Program of Ocean Drilling. In the reorganisation of the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics, the Public Service Board has agreed to the formation of a Division of Marine Geosciences and Petroleum Geology. This Division will undertake regional offshore geological and geophysical investigations and analyse and integrate offshore petroleum exploration data.
Recommendation 31 Priority be given to studying the biology of marine micro- organisms, plankton and the fish resources of the 200 n.m. zone.
Response Accepted. The Government has already significantly strengthened CSIRO's capacity to undertake research related to the resources of the Australian Fishing Zone.
Recommendation 32 Increase finance be provided for marine taxonomy and for the upgrading of museum facilities.
Response The Government accepts the importance of marine taxonomy to Australian marine science and notes that AMSTAC-FAP has supported projects in this field.

Recommendation 33 Priority be given to research into the distribution, allowable yields and management of current and potential fisheries. To foster such research, greater liaison between government and industry should be developed.

Response Accepted. The Department of Primary Industry has established a comprehensive system for collecting catch and effort data from foreign vessels operating in Australian waters as a basis for research and the development and management of the Australian Fishing Zone. An extensive feasibility fishing programme has been carried out by means of foreign and Australian commercial partnerships. The results of both these programmes are available to industry. The Australian Fishing Council has established the Australian Fishing Zone Committee, a government/industry committee which reports to it annually on the interrelations of foreign and Australian fishing in the AFZ. The reports of the Committee are published. Additionally, there is extensive consultation with industry when foreign operations are approved and during the development of fishery management and development regimes. Industry is represented on the Fishing Industry Research Committee which advises the Minister for Primary Industry on expenditure of funds from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account.
Recommendation 34 The possible over-exploitation of the North West Shelf by foreign fishing ventures be immediately examined, and if necessary, rectified.
Response See comment on Recommendation 33.

There are serious deficiencies in the knowledge and understanding of the functioning and appropriate management of tropical, multi-species, trawl fisheries. Examination of the basis of this recommendation must await further development of our understanding. The CSIRO Division of Fisheries Research is examining a proposal for research of this type. In the meantime, however, the exploitation of the North-west Shelf is being managed on a very conservative basis.

Recommendation 35 Priority be given to researching the effects of oil spills, waste disposal and effluent on the marine environment, especially on coral reefs . This research should include the development of a marine pollution monitoring system.
Response Accepted. The Government notes that a number of research programmes are underway which are relevant to this recommendation.

Recommendation 36 Attention be paid to the impact of tourism on the Great Barrier Reef. The possibility of developing an extensive underwater viewing gallery should be explored as a means of reducing this impact whilst at the same time promoting tourist interest.

Response Accepted. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has this matter under investigation. The development of proposed tourist facilities on the Great Barrier Reef and adjacent Coast is being considered so as to increase opportunities for the public to experience the Reef environment, while at the same time minimising human impact on it.

Recommendation 37 The declaration of the 200 n.m. Australian Fishing Zone should be accompanied by research into the fauna of this zone, especially mammals, and how they can be adequately protected from the over-exploitation of their foodstocks.
Response See comment on Recommendation 31.

The Fisheries Act obliges the Minister for Primary Industry to take account of the effects of fishing on cetaceans. Recent government actions on whaling have demonstrated the Government's commitment to conservation of marine mammals.
Recommendation 38 The development of appropriate technology for the marine sciences be encouraged, especially in relation to remote sensing and fisheries technology.

Response Accepted. This recommendation is consistent with the Government's policy of a balanced development of Australian marine science. Development and utilisation of advanced technology already is part of marine science activities. For example, the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account has funded a CSIRO/West Australian Institute of Technology study on the applications of remote sensing to fisheries. The Australian Maritime College is also involved in developing appropriate technology. The College's School of Fisheries provides training in the application of modern fishing techniques. There is an on-going Defence program of design studies for industrial production of the Laser Airborne Depth Sounder which can greatly increase the rate of collection of data from coastal waters shallower than 50 metres. Both CSIRO and AIMS regularly use remote sensing techniques in their research.

Recommendation 39 The Australian Marine Science Council provide finance for the operation of facilities at the island research stations. Programs conducted at these stations would be the responsibility of the Consortium of Island Research Stations.

Response The Government is aware of the important contribution made by the island research stations to marine research in the Great Barrier Reef and notes that parent institutions of island research stations are eligible to apply for funding support through marine research and development grants.
Recommendation 40 The marine science laboratories at Cronulla be retained as research and training facilities for marine scientists in the Sydney region, especially for university-based scientists.

Response CSIRO will have no need for a residual presence at Cronulla when the proposed Marine Science Laboratories are constructed in Hobart. The Government has noted this recommendation and will take it into account when consideration is given to the future of the Cronulla facilities.

Recommendation 41 Support be given to increase the number of graduates in the marine sciences whose initial degrees are based on the pure sciences. Emphasis should also be given to the provision of courses in resource management and marine technologies.

Response The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is responsible for advising the Government on the level and pattern of provision in tertiary education. The Commission's planning for the 1982-84 Triennium has been based, among other things, on there being no increase in student numbers in universities during that period. This is consistent with the findings of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training. The Government's policy is that, in expensive and highly specialised fields of study, decisions on the numbers of places to be made available will be influenced primarily by manpower considerations. The Government acknowledges however that an improvement in the quality and comprehensiveness of labour market information is a prerequisite for any significant advances in the use of manpower consideration in educational planning. AMSTAC will review the adequacy of trained manpower in the marine sciences. With regard to the provision of courses, the Australian Maritime College currently offers a number of relevant undergraduate courses and is planning to introduce post-graduate courses in hydrographic surveying and fisheries technology. The college also provides short, specialist, non-award courses to meet the needs of maritime industries.

The Government has currently under consideration a suggestion that the proposal for a National School of Fisheries be examined further with a view to its development in the 1985-87 triennium. It is recognised that such a school would complement the role of the Australian Maritime College with regard to fishing and related activities.

Recommendation 42 The number of Queen's Fellowships be increased both to give young Australians an opportunity to continue their research in this country or overseas, and to attract researchers from overseas on a short-term basis.

Response The recent amalgamation of the Queen's Fellowships in Marine Science committee with the AMSTAC-Funding Advisory Panel enables an appropriate balance between fellowships and project grants to be reached year to year.
Recommendation 43 Post-graduate scholarships be made available in the marine sciences and technologies, to be tenable in Australia and overseas.

Response The number of new Post-graduate Awards provided by the Commonwealth Government has been increased from 700 in 1980 to 800 in 1981. This increase was in response to the Recommendations of the William's Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training. It has not been policy under the Post-graduate Award Scheme to allocate Awards to particular areas of study. Traditionally the Awards have been available in open competition on the basis of academic merit to people in all disciplines.

Recommendation 44 The Australian Marine Science Council finance marine science in this country through the mechanisms of the Marine Science Research and Development Fund. Research directed towards national priorities would be financed through project and programme grants, scholarships and fellowships. This Fund would also finance the Ship Operations Unit, the Information Services Unit and the operations of the Research Institutes and the island research stations. Financial support for research conducted at these, and all other facilities, would be subject to successful application for grants, scholarships and fellowships.
Response See response to Recommendations 4.

Recommendation 45 Adequate levies be placed on industries exploiting resources in the 200 n.m. zone, especially foreign-owned fishing ventures and oil and gas industries. The revenue derived from these levies should assist in the financing of marine science research, and in the provision of inspectors and scientific observers on foreign fishing vessels.
Response The hypothecation of general Government revenue derived from fishing and offshore crude oil production to specific Government expenditure is contrary to general Government budgetary policy.
Mr Barry Jones-Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a very short statement on the Government's response to the Committee's report.
Mr Sinclair-Leave is refused, but I am prepared to move that the House take note of the paper and for debate to be adjourned until another day.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

Mr Barry Jones-Before I move that the debate be now adjourned may I have your indulgence, Mr Speaker, to say that I hope that this matter will actually be brought on for debate. I ask the Leader of the House whether he can give an undertaking of some sort. We have not been exactly burdened with the business in the last few sitting weeks. This is an important matter on which I think several honourable members would like to speak briefly. I hope that rather than just being put on the Notice Paper and going into the limbo of forgotten things, time will be found to have a discussion of over an hour or so some time within the next two sitting weeks.
Mr Sinclair-I shall discuss the matter with the manager of Opposition business along with the other outstanding matters of business for the House that have been deferred in a similar way.
Debate (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) adjourned.
