PROCTEXT.PARA: Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit-Zone Allowances-Marihuana-Housing-Australian Loan Council-Research in Australian Universities-Tertiary Education-Lowe By- election
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise today is one which will not be seen to have world shattering implications for many people but for those people who are affected it certainly has influenced both their faith in the word of government and their ability to maintain a decent standard of living. Back in 1972, in the 1972-73 Budget Speech delivered on 15 August, the then Treasurer, none other than yourself, Mr Speaker, announced the domiciliary nursing care benefit. The intention of the new benefit was to supplement existing nursing home benefits. In the statement accompanying the enabling legislation, namely the National Health Bill of 1972, the Minister of the time expressed the hope that the domiciliary nursing care benefit would provide many people with an alternative to full time care in a nursing home. This was a laudable aim. These were the words used by the Minister in ending his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of elderly people in our population is increasing each year and therefore the requirement to provide community services and benefits based on the particular needs of this segment of the population needs to be given special consideration. It is also a fact of modern day living that the evolution of the so-called nuclear family tends to exclude, often through necessity rather than choice, the care of parents or grandparents in the same home as their children or other relatives. But it is also true that there are many families who feel deeply a sense of family totality and who make considerable sacrifices to keep elderly relatives within the home even when they may require constant nursing. Such people are to be admired. But the Government wants now to see that they receive, on behalf of the community at large, more than just admiration. We trust that the new domiciliary care benefit will not only assist people to meet the financial consequence of their dedication to sick friends or relatives but also help maintain that special sense of service, security and satisfaction which grows out of such dedication.

I am sure that all honourable members will feel a warm glow following the reading of that excerpt from the Minister's statement. Of course, there were and there are conditions for eligibility. Initially, eligibility was limited to those of 65 years or over but that and other conditions were modified; today allowance is made for those in remote areas and, since 1979, the minimum qualifying age has been reduced to 16 years.

Benefit rates were increased from $28 to $42 per fortnight from 4 September 1980. It may come as some surprise to those who have so far basked in the rosy glow of self-satisfaction to learn that there is still a credibility gap which the Government must bridge if the fine words of 1972 are to be accorded any respect in 1982. The rise in the consumer price index since the benefit was first introduced on 1 March 1973 has steadily eroded the value of the benefit despite the increase of 1980. The following figures give the true picture. Had the $28 per fortnight kept its original value, beneficiaries would now be receiving $74 per fortnight. When the rate was increased to $42 per fortnight, an increase to $65 per fortnight was needed to regain the original value of the benefit. Now the picture is even worse. What has happened is that the benefit has been seriously devalued since the fine words of 1972 were spoken. Of course, if that were the only problem facing beneficiaries, that would be bad enough, but the situation is worse than that.

When programs such as this are introduced and are in operation I consider that there are moral obligations on both parties, that is, the Government and the participants, to maintain the principles involved. After all, when the Department of Health approves the payment of the benefit, it cautions the participants with these words: 'Advice of any change in circumstances which might affect payment of the benefit should be forwarded to this office as soon as possible but not later than seven days from the time the change occurred'. But obligations should not be one-sided.

What then is occurring in Victoria at present? A number of constituents of my electorate of Ballarat have contacted my office in recent days and indicated that their domiciliary nursing care benefit payments have been delayed or have arrived rather intermittently since the end of October 1981. Any member of this House should feel very concerned about this delay of payments. Firstly, there is the matter of breach of faith and, secondly, many of those participating in the scheme depend upon the prompt arrival of the benefit cheque to be able to meet the cost of the care, for instance, for the services of a visiting nurse or the cost of medication and aids. I have made inquiries about this matter and have found that the reasons for the delay are recent in origin. Firstly, there has been a reduction in the number of staff involved because of a failure by the Government to replace staff who are promoted or transferred out of the section or who leave the service. Secondly, no overtime money is allowed. Thirdly, sicknesses among the people in the section dealing with this benefit have caused a reduction of staff and no relieving staff have been available.

Not only should members of this House be concerned about this matter, but also members of the Government should feel absolutely ashamed that the victims of the actions of the so-called razor gang of 1981 are, once again, those least able to withstand the impact of this Government's actions. If Government members have any compassion at all, they will revolt against this rigid and dogmatic adherence to this Procrustean doctrine so dogmatically pursued by their Government at the expense of the aged, the infirm and their loved ones who make such a tremendous effort to keep their faith in the Government's proud words of 1972.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two matters on which I wish to speak today are both, I am sure, in the evaluation of any reasonable Australian, of immense value to the nation generally and to every person in it. I wish to refer first to the severe penalties, both financial and physical, that are suffered to a greater or lesser degree by people once they live beyond the boundaries of the metropolitan areas in each State.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like particularly to draw attention to some of the extreme difficulties which exist for residents of areas such as those for which I and other members, including you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are responsible. I have in mind the obvious disadvantages presented by climatic conditions and the penalty of distance. I do not use that phrase as a cliche; it can be applied in 101 different ways. To use my own state of Queensland as an example, once a person travels in his motor car 80 or 90 miles from the city of Brisbane he must face a petrol bowser charge of anything from 42c to 45c a litre. In my home area which is 500 or 600 miles from the coast, a family man who drives his family to the nearest point which enjoys somewhat better climatic conditions must face an expenditure on petrol alone of $100 to $200, or as much as $400 for a return trip. What I have stated is fact.

My electorate embraces many mining interests and today I would like to take a slant different from that which I might be expected to take. Constantly we hear of industrial upheaval, in coal mining areas in particular. I would like to point out that the average labourer in the area in which I represent must combat temperatures of anything from 35 to 45 degrees centigrade. That is not an exaggeration. The effect of the intense heat is greatly accentuated if one is, for instance, a linksman engaged in repairing railway lines. All of us know of these groups of men, whose work is quite unheralded. I use their situation as an example. I do not want to become ultra-parochial but a very fundamental principle is involved. Whenever men who work in coal mines go underground they take their lives in their hands. I had the terrible experience of having 13 of my constituents wiped out at Kianga in a coal mine disaster. It is important to remember that such people sustain the most vital industries of this nation. They sustain the beef cattle industry, the sheep industry, the mining industry, the sugar industry and the fisheries. All of these, in the aggregate, fill the coffers of the Treasury, and if one were suddenly to cut off the income they produce the nation would be in real trouble; it would be bankrupt.

Recently the Government made a well-intentioned attempt to re-examine this situation, and in particular zone allowances. As one who was on the original committee, under Ben Chifley, which considered zone allowances many years ago, I have argued repeatedly that such allowances are an attempt to meet just one aspect of the financial penalties under which people must operate once they get away from the more favoured areas of this nation. The Government's review was well-intentioned but it was utterly futile. The findings that were made, and the recommendations that were accepted by the Government, did not help in any measure that was commensurate with the difficulties confronted in the areas involved. Any honourable member who has any intelligence, who is reasonable and who is not trying to make political points because perhaps a marginal seat is involved will recognise that the Government is making a super effort to balance the Budget in what are very difficult times. It is a pretty weak argument to refer constantly to what is happening overseas but one cannot deny that what is in fact happening overseas involves our interests.

When we talk of additional funding and of trying to assist these areas that produce this great wealth, wherever they might be, let us remember that there is certain expenditure, certain funding, which the Treasury is obliged to make which is non-productive, which does not bring a return. However, I say with all of the conviction of which I am capable that every cent that is given to the people living in these areas is more than productive. This funding stimulates production. We do not talk very much these days about the gross national product . The GNP is regulated by such things as the capacity of people to produce, the desire of people to produce and the intention of the worker to give an honest day's labour for an honest day's pay. If we can build up that we can increase our social services and the good things that we like to give the people of the nation. I well remember that when I was in the United States of America, attending the United Nations, President Nixon came on the television to make one brief announcement. He said to the people of America: 'I am immensely proud of you because today you have reached a gross national product for this nation of one trillion dollars'. Admittedly, things are not that good now.

I am saying that if funding can be given to these areas, these achievements can be made. Take the pensioners. I know this is a very moot subject but it does not bring me or anyone else any great joy to see the situation in which the old people of these areas are placed. If the Australian Labor Party, the Opposition, takes any joy in saying that Katter is having a belt at his own party, I point out one fact that will stand to the disgrace of the ALP for all time: It reduced the pension during the Depression. People in the most disadvantaged group in the nation had their limited income reduced during the Depression years. Also, I doubt whether one yard of bitumen was put down in the inland areas of this great nation during the term of office of that Government. What did the Menzies Government do? It produced an epic and made probably the greatest contribution even to this nation-it built the beef roads. Where would any of us in those desolate areas be if those beef roads had not been built? Let members of the Opposition gain no particular comfort from my, I hope constructive, case to the Government.

What can be done? I refer to the sales tax on freight costs. For years and years-as long as I can remember-we have argued against this. It is a vicious penalty and should be removed. I believe its removal would be one of the great contributions we could make to decentralisation and to the building up of the great inland areas of this nation. It is not so much a matter of building up those areas now but of keeping people there. It is a matter of survival. The great story of history is that when people begin to emigrate, like moths around the glow of the city, the nation concerned begins to deteriorate. I could go on and on in regard to this subject but I do plead with the Government to look at the whole spectrum of penalties under which people in these remote areas live. I ask the Government to have a look at freight costs, at the price of petrol, at health services and at the capacity of people to travel to more favoured areas for perhaps a week's holiday. It should look at these things and try to give back to these people, who are doing the hard yakka, who are working their guts out in terrible climatic conditions, some compensation for sustaining the great industries of this nation.

The other subject I want to speak on is an unbelievable recommendation made by a working party or committee-call it what you like-on which some very eminent people served. I refer to the recommendation that marihuana be made available, that people be permitted to grow it. What is the attitude of a group of people who could make such a recommendation? I happened to chair a marihuana committee- it was not a drugs committee, but a marihuana committee-and the greatest lesson I learned was from a young addict who had succeeded in getting rid of the habit. He said: 'Look, Bob, marihuana is not an addiction like heroin is; your body doesn't scream for it, you don't get that terrible physical reaction, but what does happen is that you get such a lift when you take it or when you are addicted to it'-he used the word 'addicted' with a good deal of thought-'that when you are without it you would sell your socks to get back to it'.

I was on the World Health Organisation mailing list. Information I have received from that body clearly indicates that 90 per cent of those who have graduated to the heavier drugs such as LSD and heroin had been addicted to marihuana. I am not saying that 90 per cent of people smoking marihuana went to the heavier drugs; what I am saying is that 90 per cent of those on heavy drugs had at some time or other been addicted to marihuana. I think that men who put another pressure on young people should be subject to a dreadful indictment. These young people are already absolutely barraged with various pressures that reduce their capacity to be the good young Australians they naturally would wish to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to grieve for those Victorians, pensioners and home buyers, who are exposed to the cruel and deceptive fraud perpetrated by the Thompson Liberal Government and particularly by the Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Jeff Kennett. The conspiracy to shift the whole of the blame on to their Federal colleagues was conceived by the Victorian Liberal Government late last year when it started to realise that it had lost the confidence of the Victorian electorate. The Victorian Minister of Housing, Jeff Kennett, put full page advertisements in Victorian daily papers blaming Malcolm Fraser for the disastrous housing situation in Victoria. Kennett spent tens of thousands of Victorian taxpayers' dollars on that exercise. He set up the effigy of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and, knowing his unpopularity, knocked him down. He hit below the belt in the process and expected the applause of the Victorian people. Well, the applause never came. All Kennett got instead was a sharp attack on him by the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), his senior colleague, who pointed out that Victoria has the worst record of all the States in Australia, and has spent the smallest amount per capita on housing . To add insult to injury, he called Jeff Kennett a political gelding. I am occasionally ashamed of the terms which the honourable members opposite use to describe their own colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: So after spending tens of thousands of Victorian taxpayers' money on gimmicks instead of on better housing, the Liberal Minister of Housing, Jeff Kennett, did not succeed in duping the voters of Victoria. All he managed to do was to invoke the wrath of his Federal Liberal colleagues who are guilty enough in their own right of the slump in housing without being blamed for the Victorian Government' s mismanagement also. It is true that the Fraser Government has a dismial record on housing, especially as far as allocations for welfare housing are concerned. It is true that the Fraser Government presides over the highest housing interest rates in our history.

But let us examine the credentials of the Victorian Liberal Government, and what credentials the Victorian Housing Minister, Mr Kennett, has, to drag its Federal buddies across the carpet. While Kennett was busy trying to blame his ideological buddies in Canberra, he left $16m unspent from his allocation for housing in Victoria for 1980-81. While homeless youths in my electorate, and indeed in many other parts of Victoria, sleep in parks and shelters, this Minister, Mr Kennett, has $16m unspent from his allocation. He would have done better if he had used this money and the taxpayers' money that he is spending on Liberal Party electioneering through media advertisements on housing homeless youth. Let us have another look at the Victorian Liberal Government's performance as far as housing is concerned. According to Federal Department of Housing and Construction figures, Victoria spends less on welfare housing per capita than any other State in the Commonwealth. Let us look at how they compare . On a per capita basis New South Wales spends $13.98, Queensland $13.67, Western Australia $16.10, Tasmania $25.17 and South Australia $66.08. Victoria spends the princely sum of $8.80. How does Mr Kennett have the temerity, the impudence, to criticise anyone?

Let me now turn to the latest gimmick of the Victorian Housing Minister. At a special meeting of State Premiers last month Mr Kennett outlined a new scheme- the so-called 'granny bond'-which has as its target the syphoning off of $500m to $1,000m held by aged people to lend to home buyers. It was a good old confidence trick-use anybody's money but your own. However, there are many other things wrong with this scheme. Mr Kennett knows that. As I have said before, he is perpetrating a deceptive fraud on Victorians. He knows very well that this scheme is useless unless the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) cough up the dough. Both Mr Thompson and Mr Kennett know that those two Liberal colleagues of theirs in Canberra are good at making promises and equally as good at breaking them. However, in this instance no promise was given. On 25 February 1982, I asked the Prime Minister this question without notice:

Is the Prime Minister aware that the granny bond scheme outlined by the Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Kennett, this week depends heavily on the Federal Government agreeing to legislate to provide for tax deductibility of interest rates? Since this involves a major commitment by the Commonwealth Government with far broader implications than housing policy, will the Prime Minister state what consultations, if any, he has had with his State colleagues on this important matter? Has the Commonwealth Government agreed to support the Victorian Government by immediately introducing legislation for such tax deductibility? If not, why not?

From the Prime Minister's reply to my question it was quite clear that no undertaking has been given for the introduction of tax deductibility for granny bonds, not to mention the question of assurances that interest earned on savings of aged people will not affect their pension entitlements. So the fraud perpetrated on pensioners and home buyers by the Victorian Government is exposed . But, Mr Deputy Speaker, if you think that I am somewhat harsh on the Victorian Liberal Government, I wish to draw your attention to the editorial of the Australian Financial Review of 26 February this year. I may be accused of some measure of bias or dislike of the Liberal Party, but the same cannot be said of the Australian Financial Review. Let us examine what was said in the editorial. It stated:

The silly season for housing subsidy schemes is well and truly on. The Premiers of the States, in their collective wisdom, have just produced a set of proposals which would be ludicrous if they were not seriously advanced as some kind of solution to the difficulties of house buyers.

As usual, the bill is to be presented to the Commonwealth Government, and therefore to the taxpayer. The States have always been only too willing to spend the taxpayer's money so long as they do not have to take the blame for collecting it.

A rough estimate of how much the measures proposed by the Premiers would cost the Commonwealth is $750 million. In the present state of Commonwealth finances, to expect expenditures of such a scale is unrealistic, especially as the States are equally enthusiastically opposing the sales tax measures which were designed to increase Commonwealth revenues. Of course, realism is not what the exercise is about.

Rather, it is a cynical exercise in politics intended (in the Victorian case) to shift the blame for impending defeat on to the Federal Liberal Party, in the likely event that the Prime Minister refuses to cough up, and in the New South Wales case, to be used as a campaign issue in the Lowe by-election.

What an indictment. This speaks for itself. I could not have said it better myself. The dirty tricks of Mr Thompson and Mr Kennett are exposed here-not by me, a member of the Opposition, but by a newspaper which is not known to favour the Australian Labor Party. Let us now have a look at Thompson's latest promises made last night. Again I quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review under the title: 'Thompson bids with a fistful of dollars'. The article stated:
The Premier's speech was notable for the absence of any reference to how the Government proposed to fund its big-spending bid for votes in the April 3 poll.

The Liberal Government in Victoria had 27 years to implement what it has suddenly started to preach now. 'Thompson bids with a fistful of dollars', says the headline. The Victorian electors remember only too well that Liberal fist of $5 notes in a federal election a few years ago. That fist is back again. But the Victorian electors will not be duped by Mr Thompson. They will not be misled by his dirty tricks and by Mr Kennett's shadow boxing with his own Liberal Party. They will see through these manoeuvres. On 3 April they will elect a Cain Labor government which will be an honest government for Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the investigation which is currently being set up into the activities and future of the Australian Loan Council. This investigation was first announced after the recent Premiers Conference, and first announced in the newspapers following that Premiers meeting. I was concerned that such an important and fundamental investigation should be launched in such a way as to ignore Parliament in that announcement. I spoke on this matter in a speech which I made in Queensland to a dinner of the Young Liberal Movement on the evening of 22 February. Subsequently I asked a question of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) as to the Government's intentions. My question in part stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Who are the members of the committee which is to conduct that study? When will the committee report and to whom will it report?

That was the first reference made in Parliament to this investigation. The Treasurer was good enough to table the terms of reference which are headed: ' Terms of reference for inquiry into role of Loan Council'. It was only then that we were able to learn of the significance of this inquiry. I wish to quote from parts of that document. Whilst the document has been tabled it has not yet been inserted in Hansard. The terms of reference stated:
Loan Council resolves that a working party of Commonwealth and State officers be established to undertake a fundamental examination of the role of Loan Council . . .
They go on to say:
. . . the Working Party is to identify any desirable changes in a Report to Loan Council.

In part, one of the changes which it was to examine was the extent to which governments and their authorities now have access to capital funds additional to those provided through approved Loan Council borrowing programs and the extent to which Loan Council should control such access. The paper indicates a number of other items of investigation and in a particular paragraph states:
Additional specific issues may be added at the request of the States during the next two weeks.

Those two weeks have elapsed and the Parliament has still not been informed of any additional matters that reflect upon or add to the work of this inquiry. In the speech which I made in Queensland I said:
It is fair then that it should not be surreptitiously altered--
I was referring to the Loan Council-
behind the closed doors of a secret meeting. Proposed changes should not be stage-managed by a departmental investigation.

It is worth noting that the inquiry-this fundamental examination of the role of the Loan Council-will be carried out by a working party of Commonwealth and State officers. It is worth reflecting that whilst some of those officers, as any honourable members who have been involved with those officers would agree, are of the highest order of integrity and commitment to their work that one will find in Australia the fact nevertheless exists that they are departmental officers. They are subject to direction by their Ministers and to a direction in the way in which their study could be and can be carried out. The Loan Council has served Australia for 50 years. It regulates the developmental programs that are spread across this nation. It is an organisation which was set up out of a very great debate conducted over a long number of years. It was set up because States had overborrowed and had established loans which they were unable to meet . The legislation to set up the Loan Council had to be approved by a referendum of the Australian people. I find it rather strange that considering the background of such a successful organisation, which has stood behind an enormous program of decentralisation and development in this country, it should be subjected to a fundamental inquiry of its future role by departmental officers who are subject to departmental and ministerial direction. I find that that pays less than proper service to the importance of that body and to future development in Australia. I believe it has been a tremendous regulatory factor for decentralisation, which I have already mentioned.

In this country we have an enormous aggregation of population on the eastern seaboard. We have a financial system which greatly subsidises population in the smaller States from the wealth of the larger States. This is something which has been carried on in relation to the amount that smaller States have been able to borrow in their loan programs. I believe that it is easy to agree superficially to an examination of the Loan Council. However, on further study one finds that one is examining a very fundamental basis for development and growth in Australia and a fundamental prop of living standards of some equality for all Australians wherever they may be. It would be inconceivable to think of disbanding the Loan Council. In fact, I believe that the Government would never countenance disbanding it. However I refer again to the statement that it is a fundamental inquiry. If it is fundamental one could conceive that it could recommend that the Loan Council be disbanded. If that were the case that recommendation would come from departmental officers. I believe that the investigation is not of sufficient width and independence to provide the basis for any such recommendation.

It is a somewhat shoddy way of the Government to treat the importance of the Loan Council that it should announce such an investigation outside the Parliament. It is somewhat shoddy that information about that investigation is being supplied to this Parliament only by an answer to a question. It should have been the subject of a ministerial statement and, following that, a debate in the House of Representatives. It may be that the Treasurer will provide further information. In response to my question asking who will comprise the members of the investigative study I was told that the names will be furnished. They have not yet been furnished although the question was framed on 23 February . I await the answer. All members of the Parliament should take an interest in the study of the fundamental role and future of the Loan Council. We should know who are the members of the study group and we should be assured that they are free of ministerial direction. I await the Treasurer's further reply to the question that I have posed. As I said, I hope that he will initiate a statement in this place as to the Government's intentions.

I remind the House that some Premiers arrived at the Loan Council without knowing that this matter would be on the agenda. I understand that one or two were informed privately. That in itself is a bad start to such an important step . If the recommendations of this committee were to be put before the Loan Council in the same way as the proposal to have the investigation was put before the Loan Council, we would have a very much closed shop investigation and tend to have a closed shop implementation of the recommendations that would come from it. The Treasurer owes it to the importance and future of the Loan Council to make a statement to the House and to allow it to debate fully the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Innes Mr U.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the Premier of Victoria, in his policy speech, put up a phony housing proposal that must be regarded, by anybody who has studied the situation in that State, as much too little, much too late. The people of Victoria will assess it in that way on 3 April. The needy were, once again, ignored and the Premier simply carried out a cynical vote-catching exercise for the marginal seats in Victoria by offering a mere pittance to a handful of families. While the debate continues to rage on the problems of home ownership, the availability of loan funds and the costs of these funds, those dependent on the rental market are ignored by both State and Federal governments . Yet, ironically, as the myth of home ownership becomes more mythical, as the great Australian dream becomes the great Australian nightmare, more families and individuals are being forced to rely on the rental market for housing and accommodation. The fault lies at both federal and State levels and the Victorian Government's performance in this area has been abysmal.

SPEECH.PARA: The major contributors to the problems in Victoria have been the non-regulation of interest rates in respect of building societies, the concentration of federal and State funds on bolstering the private sector, the massive decrease in real housing funds under the Federal Government, the failure of the Victorian Government to match other States in housing spending and the run-down of the public housing sector, exemplified in the irresponsible sell-off or, more correctly termed the 'give-away' of the Holmesglen construction division by the Victorian Minister of Housing. With an economy in chaos for ordinary working people facing the obstacles of real and threatened unemployment, falling wage values, inflation and soaring interest rates, public housing must become a government priority. Yet this Government and the Victorian Government say nothing about it and do less. Public housing is not the provision of low cost, poorly constructed estates for the disadvantaged. It is the provision of high quality, decent housing stock throughout the community at reasonable rentals. Rentals ought to be adjusted to salary or income but the level of income ought not debar people from the right to adequate and proper housing.

Let us look at this Government's record. When the thieves of public office stole government in 1975 the Federal Budget outlay on housing was 3.9 per cent. Last year it was one per cent of the total Budget outlay. A comparison of that decline against the Government's spending patterns on industry assistance, handouts and giveaways to big business, subsidies and support for the pastoral and rural industries, spending on massive infrastructure for the resource industry and tax concessions and holidays to giant capital makes the major thrust of the Government's policy and philosophy apparent. The results are more apparent in the desperate need for decent public housing at one end of the scale and the record profits and affluence at the other. Spending on public housing, expressed in constant 1981 prices, was $1,227m in 1974-75 and a pitiful $399m in the present Budget. There was a cut of 77.5 per cent in real terms over that period. At the same time, spending on defence homes and home savings grants has increased dramatically, unbalancing the priority further in favour of private housing against public housing. Further, under the current 1981-86 Commonwealth- State Housing Agreement the break-up of funds between home purchase assistance and public rental housing is determined by each State. When that choice is placed in the hands of a free enterprise government, such as the Victorian Government, with no concern for ordinary working people, the result is disaster.

We have recently heard the Victorian Government excuse its appalling record in public housing by blaming the Federal Government. In part that is true but the growing numbers of people requiring a responsible public housing policy are being jammed between two governments which are unwilling to assist them. While Federal funding is being reduced dramatically the Victorian Government has also failed to pull its weight in the area. The Federal Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) was reported in the Age of 18 May last year as pointing out that the national average State contribution to housing was $16 a head, yet the Victorian contribution was $6 a head. My friend, the the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) said earlier, that it was $8 a head. Whilst the Victorian Government claims that the money was directed into another area of housing, it is a matter of robbing Peter to pay Paul and highlights the poverty of the policy. At the level at which the need exists this irresponsibility by Federal and State governments means waiting lists in some areas of up to five years at a time when Victorian Housing Commission waiting lists are growing by an additional 1,200 rental applications a month. Even the Victorian Ministry estimates the number of low income earners living in poverty in the private rental sector at about 200,000 households. At least 15,000 young people are homeless, and women's and youth refuges turn down three in every four requests for accommodation each week.

More and more people are being forced into the rental market through their inability to meet housing repayments. In this Government's economic climate the position will only worsen. The need for massive injections of Federal and State funds on public housing is desperate. It is receiving no more than token acknowledgement from this Government or its Victorian ally. The only new direction of any Victorian policy, as spelt out by the Victorian Premier last night, is down. Public housing must be provided by buying good housing stock in developed areas and building new, high quality stock in other areas or through inner urban infill housing policies.

The Victorian Government has abandoned this principle by giving away its Holmesglen construction division. It argued that the cost of construction at Holmesglen was excessive. However, there are strong arguments to suggest that the costs arose not from the Holmesglen facility per se but from the maladministration and professional incompetence within the Housing Commission itself. Given the Commission's history of corruption and land deals, which have left more than one Liberal Minister in retirement or on the back bench, that explanation seems quite reasonable. In an area where the State Government claims there is a shortage of funds we have the scandalous position of engineers and architects sitting in the Housing Commission with virtually nothing to do. Of course, given the track record for wastage and contempt of public funds in the Victorian Housing Commission that position is par for the course.

But the position is worse. In the mass give away of the viable and the socially vital Holmesglen plant expensive machinery has been handed over to the private sector at a fraction of its value. In a concentrated industrial area the big business mates of the Victorian Government were able to buy cheap and sell at a major profit. Let me give one example. Simsmetal Pty Ltd bought 16 vibrating tables, which are large work benches, for $189 each and sold them for $850 each with no interim costs apart from transportation. Large tyre tractors worth up to $6,000 were sold by the Victorian Government for $1,400 and overhead gantries worth up to $20,000 were sold for $6,000. Expensive mixers worth $45,000 were sold for $4,000; if 'sold' be the word. I would rather use the more correct term that the items were given away by the Government to its mates. If the items were to be sold they should have been sold at least at their real value so that the State did not subsidise big business any more than it already does.

In real terms the major companies which bought these give-away items were taking the roofs from over the heads of the needy who cannot obtain housing, thanks to the policies of the Victorian Government. However, the construction plant should have been retained, not only for building homes and units, but also for other vital government works where lucrative contracts are let to private profiteers. I believe the Holmesglen plant which was allowed to be destroyed by the Victorian Government was the only plant in Australia capable of supplying the amounts of material required for the new and permanent Parliament House.

The homeless, the needy, those who require adequate, proper and non-charitable public housing are the victims of both of these governments. The people of Victoria will reject the Liberal Government on 3 April. I sincerely hope and trust that the Cain Labor Party will be given a mandate to correct this shocking state of affairs perpetrated on the people of Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I imagine that regular listeners to this program will find the sort of harangue which we have just heard rather tiresome. No doubt that sort of thing will continue through to the Victorian election.
—It is all right for you living in the lap of luxury. Why don't you tell the people where you live. Have a look at the Victorian housing situation.

—I will allow anybody who heard that outburst to judge from that the level of the honourable member's contribution. I speak today about research in Australian universities and in particular about a program concerning research centres of excellence in Australian universities, a program in which I had the very fortunate opportunity to participate last year. The Prime Minister (Mr Fraser), in his 1980 policy speech, promised that $16m would be devoted over the 1982-84 triennium to set up research centres of excellence in universities. The idea originated with the old Universities Commission which put forward the idea of special post-graduate centres giving in universities a concentration of research which could not be provided from normal individual grants. In other words, if the critical mass of research were put in one area a more concentrated effort could be made. Results would be speeded up and there would be a contribution to better or more attractive conditions for researchers around Australia. The Commonwealth Research Centres of Excellence Committee had the following terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: Research Centres of Excellence will be special units within Australian universities, or in other places by arrangement with universities, established by concentrating research workers and resources, with the aim of pursuing research of outstanding quality within an international context likely to lead to a significant and major development of knowledge; in addition, their research programs may be directed to a national research objective or to take advantage of unique Australian opportunities. A Research Centre of Excellence will be led by a chief researcher, recognised internationally as eminent in his intellectual discipline, currently active in the Centre's particular area of research and able to maintain his commitment for the duration of the Centre's program.

It is fair to say that this kind of idea is already in practice in the research schools of the Australian National University and also in certain research institutions such as the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research in Melbourne. It is not a totally new idea. The idea was to extend research from outside those sorts of special centres into universities generally and to enable them to set up concentrated centres of research and give the very best people a push along.

The Government decided to set up not an academic committee to determine grants but a committee chaired by a businessman, Mr S. B. Myer, the Chairman of the Myer Emporium Ltd, and having as its members Mr R. D. G. Agnew, a Perth businessman and Chairman of the new Australian Bank Ltd, Professor D. N. F. Dunbar, the Chairman of the Universities Council and me. Obviously we had to get assistance from the academic community in Australia and elsewhere to judge the academic excellence of the applicants. We were able to contribute something towards the selection by looking at the management of the centre and the kind of support it received from the university in which it was placed. We had to get some idea of the individual qualities of the chief researchers. We had to be very heavily guided by the expert advice of the peers of the researchers from overseas and within the Australian community; in other words, those groups which were not applying for grants.

The scheme was publicised. We received some 327 proposals from universities. It was a very difficult task to get these down to a short list of some 30 universities, which we did again based on the academic recommendations which were received. The Committee visited the 30 institutions on the short list. Going to universities pretty well all around Australia and meeting the very best Australian researchers was one of the most interesting and exciting things in which I have ever been involved. I was overwhelmed by the quality of the people, by their dedication to what they were doing and by the sheer brilliance of their work, as far as we, as lay people, could judge it. I had a feeling also that, despite all the problems Australia has in getting enough funds for research, it has an extraordinary capacity in this area when it is looked at at ground level. I recommend to honourable members to visit, insofar as they can, their local universities and to talk with some of the very best research workers. It is a most rewarding and enlightening experience.

We really had a surfeit of excellent applications. From that short list of 30 and from the money we had we were able to give awards to only 10 centres over the three years. We awarded not on any geographical basis-that caused some heartburning in certain areas-but as we awarded on the sheer excellence of the proposals we virtually had to ignore the disciplines in which the proposals were and also the locations of the universities in which these centres were based. Of course that caused some heartburning and some difficulty had to be faced. We also invited applications from non-university institutions, such as colleges of advanced education, although there was a requirement in our terms of reference that those centres be funded through universities. Indeed, in one case we were able to make a grant to a joint microelectronics research centre headed by Dr Graham Rigby, who is about to be made professor in the school of electrical engineering and computer science in the University of New South Wales, in association with Dr Martin Green of the University of New South Wales and Dr James Williams from the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology. This was quite an interesting situation in that we had two proposals from two quite separate institutions, but by finding a head of a research centre who came from the private sector and who was about to be appointed to the University of New South Wales we were able, with the advice of the Australian Science and Technology Council, to have a centre which got the very best from the two cities and from two quite different institutions. It was a rewarding experience to see that being set up in an area of great importance to Australia. But it has to be emphasised that that centre was chosen on the excellence of its research rather than on the particular discipline on which it was based. It was a happy coincidence that it happened to be also very much in the national interest.

In the choice of the final 10 there was a bit of a bias towards medical sciences and related disciplines, but that tends to reflect where the very best Australian research efforts are currently placed. This is not in our report and it is only a personal view, but I suppose if the medical schools around the country over many years have been creaming off the very top number of places from the schools, it is almost inevitable that over time-as people are attracted to that field-there will tend to be heavy concentrations of brilliance in those areas. This was certainly the case. But we did get a reasonable spread in other areas. It is worth looking at that situation for the future and worrying about how we can get greater concentrations of the very best brains across the various faculties, some of which have a more direct relevance to Australian results and Australian research than medical sciences, which have relevance virtually on a world wide basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The medical sciences have more sources for grants too, which is another bias.

—That is right, they have more sources of funds and also there is sometimes more public support because of the personal appeal that can be made to people. But generally speaking this has been a worthwhile exercise. I hope it will be continued in the future. We hope that in a year or two a new committee will be set up. We have recommended that our committee be abolished and the Government has accepted that. We thought that was the right thing to do. But we do hope that in the future the Government will set up another committee to look at the existing centres and continue their grants where appropriate. I hope also that the Government will enable the centres to be expanded.

SPEECH.PARA: In the final moment that I have, I draw attention to the other remarks in the report about the need for additional assistance, particularly in post-graduate studies. We think that the concern about the funds for post-graduate students is real.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many other Australians I am eagerly awaiting the Lowe by-election next Saturday, 13 March. I believe that a crushing win by the Australian Labor Party's candidate, Michael Maher, will mark the beginning of the end of this Government and that the demise of this Government will come as a pleasant relief to the majority of Australians. Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics brought down a report which stated that unemployment was as high as 483,000, or 7 per cent of the work force. That figure is up by nearly 60,000 over last year's. The balance of payments for the first eight months shows a trade deficit of $2.2 billion. The current account deficit is $5.6 billion, which is almost double last year's. The capital inflow figure is $3.9 billion. That is an overall deficit of $1.7 billion-a great record for this Government! Inflation is running at 11.3 per cent and rising, whereas overseas it is less than 10 per cent and falling. Consumer confidence is at its lowest level for nine years. Short term interest rates are now 20 per cent with no signs of any ceiling. This rise must eventually affect home loan interest rates in some measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been given more than six years to implement its policies, this Government has proven beyond any doubt its general incompetence to do the job. It can no longer cast the blame for its troubles on the Whitlam Government. The Australian Labor Party was in power for only three years, and that was six years ago. This Government cannot reasonably blame overseas economic conditions, the unions or the so-called 'millionaire pensioners' for the nation's troubles. These scapegoats wore thin long ago with the electors. The responsibility for this mess has been laid squarely at the feet of the Government and no amount of squirming and lying is going to change that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not like the use of those terms in the House. We have had them before. Let us cut it out.
—The honourable member for Sydney may proceed but should exercise restraint.

—I believe those voters in the 1980 elections who foolishly gave this Government another chance are now rueing their mistake. Some of these voters are in the electorate of Lowe, and 13 March is their chance to make amends and to let the Government really know how they feel about its performance . Other voters will, I hope, not have to wait too much longer for their chance. As they cast their votes they should consider the Government's policies over the last six years and especially how they affect them. The aged should consider how their pensions have been whittled away by inflation and how they have been further denigrated as second-class citizens. In March 1976 the pension stood at $38.75 a week, which was 22.8 per cent of average weekly earnings. By June 1982- in three months-the pension will be $72.10, which is only 21.6 per cent of average weekly earnings. If this is not bad enough, the income test figure has remained constant at $20 when it should have been increased to at least $36 to allow for inflation. This has meant that gradually more and more pensioners have been denied the full pension although six years earlier they would have been entitled to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Likewise, because of the negligible increase in the income test for health cards and fringe benefits, which by the way was raised only last year, a growing number of pensioners are being denied health cards and fringe benefits although six years earlier they too would have been entitled to them. Late last year the Government threatened to stop pensioners from holding no-interest bank accounts, even though this situation was mostly caused by the Government's failure to raise the pensioner income test. Now the Government is threatening to apply a stricter means test on pensioners in order to reduce its expenditure on social welfare. It is a pity that the Government did not think of the need for cost cutting when it decided recently to spend nearly $480m on an aircraft carrier. As a further infliction on pensioners, from May this year single pensioners will be paying tax on any bank or building society interest of more than $6.51 a week . This does not affect just the interest; it affects also the pension payment. Pensioners will face the imposition of tax at 32c in the dollar on their income above the $4,195 threshold. This will mean that many more pensioners will be joining the 250,000 pensioners who are already paying tax.

I think the Government is making its message to pensioners loud and clear. It is blatantly treating them with contempt and playing them for fools. Does the Government seriously expect their vote? How can anyone blame pensioners for being apprehensive about their future when different members of the Cabinet contradict each other about Government policy? How can anyone have faith in the assurances of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when the Deputy Leader of his party (Sir Phillip Lynch) is espousing the opposite view. Based on the Prime Minister's past record of broken promises, his word is worthless. How appropriate it is that the description of him remains in Hansard.

The Government has displayed indifference to the plight of the aged in need of nursing home and hostel care. As the Australian population is aging and becoming increasingly in need of domiciliary services and nursing home and hostel care, the Government is short-sightedly making cutbacks in this area. By not adequately supporting domiciliary services it is also promoting inappropriate use of residential care. In my electorate of Sydney the demand for nursing home and hostel accommodation far exceeds the supply, causing many of my constituents to look for accommodation in the neighbouring Kingsford-Smith, Lowe and Grayndler electorates. The accommodation in these areas has reached saturation point.

The inadequate quantity of accommodation is one serious problem; the quality and price of the accommodation is another. A number of nursing homes are still providing poor quality care for their patients, particularly in the areas of meeting social and activity needs. The price of staying in many nursing homes now far exceeds the pension, causing many pensioners to become a financial burden on their children or to quickly use up their financial reserves. At present the nursing home benefit in addition to the pension fails to cover the full cost of nursing home care for over 15,000 pensioners. By next May this figure will double, leaving as few as 30 per cent of pensioners in nursing homes fully covered. With quality tending to follow price, and with available accommodation difficult to find anyway, more and more pensioners and their families are realising the sorry state of affairs only too late. For those families in the electorate of Lowe their chance to break through this frustration and to record their hostility comes next Saturday through the ballot box.

Those 36,000 residents of the Lowe electorate who were born overseas and who have now made Australia their home should consider the Government's performance in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs as they cast their vote. At a time when immigration to Australia is at an all time high, nearly $10m has been cut from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as a result of the razor gang's recommendations. Long delays are occurring in the Department's offices overseas in the processing of applications for permanent residence. It is not uncommon for families to wait for a year or more to be reunited with their loved ones, including spouses. The Government apparently thinks the money saved by staff cuts justifies this heartache.

Also worthy of consideration by the many families in the Lowe electorate is the Australian Labor Party's new universal health insurance plan under which all Australians will be automatically covered for 85 per cent of the standard medical bills and public hospital treatment and accommodation will be available free. Compare this to the present medi-muddle which has undergone several changes and which costs taxpayers a considerable amount each week in health insurance premiums. The present system has proved difficult for consumers to understand and has provided a windfall for health insurance companies and unscrupulous doctors.

As I mentioned earlier, I welcome the Lowe by-election and look forward to being joined in this Parliament by my friend and colleague, Michael Maher. I believe he is an outstanding candidate. He has successfully proven his ability in his 10 years as the State member for Drummoyne. He is a very popular man with people throughout the Lowe electorate because he is a man of the people, ever willing to help them with their problems. Even when Michael was a State member, he was handling Federal matters for those constituents who could not find their Federal member or who preferred to deal with a person they knew and trusted. Therefore, in many ways I believe Michael will find the transition to Federal Parliament an easy one. I wish him, his wife Margaret and their many children every success.
