PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Australia- Japan Agreement for Co-operation in the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, signed in Canberra on Friday 5 March 1982. The text was made available publicly on the same day. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In presenting this Agreement, I am maintaining the commitment by the Government to present the texts of all of Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements in the Parliament as soon as practicable after signature with a full explanation of their provisions. The Agreement, which replaces the 1972 Australia-Japan Agreement for Co-operation in the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy , provides that nuclear transfers between Australia and Japan will be exclusively for peaceful, non-explosive purposes. It prescribes the conditions and controls which will apply to achieve the purpose of the Agreement and to ensure the observance of its provisions is fully verified. The provisions of the Agreement fully meet Australia's policy requirements as laid down by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 24 May 1977 and put into effect in Australia's other bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements. The Agreement also establishes a framework for mutual co-operation in the peaceful non-explosive uses of nuclear energy.

SPEECH.PARA: The conclusion of the Agreement represents the achievement of a major objective of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy. It marks a significant extension of Australia's network of bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements which are designed to facilitate international nuclear trade under strict non- proliferation conditions. Further, it clears the way for export of Australian uranium to Japan, a country which is a major market for Australia's uranium and which has a heavy commitment to nuclear electricity generation and a significant investment in the Australian uranium mining industry. The Agreement adds significantly to the bilateral relationship and confirms the broad measure of agreement between Australia and Japan on the need to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and how this can be done. The conclusion of the Agreement with Japan is further evidence of the international acceptability of the requirements of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy.

The Agreement brings the number of nuclear safeguards agreements concluded since 1977 to 10, covering 17 countries, including those Western countries with the most significant civil nuclear power programs, as well as two developing countries. All these agreements have been tabled in the Parliament. They are published in the Australian treaties series, and available to the public and to the media upon signature.

The announcement in 1977 of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy made it necessary to replace the 1972 Agreement between Australia and Japan by a new agreement incorporating the requirements of the Government's policy. Negotiations to this end began in Tokyo in June 1978 and were concluded in Canberra in January 1982. Several factors influenced progress in the negotiations. The Japanese, along with several of our other negotiating partners , wished to await and study the findings of the International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation-INFCE-which took place from October 1977 until February 1981. The Japanese also took a close interest in the outcome of our negotiations with other significant partners, particularly those in Western Europe. I wish to stress that, as required by the Government's policy, there can be no deliveries to Japan, or any other country, of Australian uranium under contracts concluded since 1977 until the relevant nuclear safeguards agreement has entered into force.

The Agreement complies with all of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy requirements for the export of uranium. These include the prohibition of explosive and military uses of Australian-supplied uranium; the application of International Atomic Energy Agency-IAEA-safeguards to verify compliance with these basic undertakings; 'fallback' safeguards in the event of failure of the Non-Proliferation Treaty safeguards regime; adequate physical protection; consultations, and detailed procedures to ensure implementation of the obligations of the Agreement; provision for sanctions in the event of the non- observance of stipulated obligations of the Agreement; and arbitration procedures. The Agreement also provides for controls on the transfer of material , equipment or sensitive technology between the two countries, and for co- operation in the peaceful non-explosive uses of nuclear energy.

There have been suggestions in the media that the Agreement waters down Australia's policy requirements for prior consent over reprocessing, retransfers and high enrichment. These suggestions have no foundation whatsoever. The Agreement fully upholds all of Australia's policy requirements, including these requirements. The detailed conditions under which our consent rights are exercised over reprocessing and retransfers are set out in the documents which are attached to the Agreement and form part of it. I announced the Government's approach to the exercise of consent rights over reprocessing in my statement of 27 November 1980. As I made clear in that statement all of Australia's existing policy requirements continue to apply. What we have done on reprocessing is to define what had not previously been defined-the conditions under which the consent to reprocessing would be exercised and the controls that would apply to that operation. These have been incorporated in this Agreement with Japan as in the agreements with the European Atomic Energy Community, France and Sweden which have already been presented to the Parliament. The text of the Agreement shows that Press speculation which appeared at the time officials concluded their negotiations was misleading and incorrect. Japan has received no more than any other negotiating partner.

The Agreement incorporates what is known as the Australian 'program approach' to reprocessing. It requires that Australian-origin nuclear material subject to the Agreement shall be reprocessed, and the resulting separated plutonium stored and used, only under IAEA safeguards in the delineated Japanese Nuclear Fuel Cycle Program. Reprocessing for research and other applications is not approved under the program approach but is to be the subject of individual consideration in the future. This is fully in accordance with Australia's policy requirements and the conditions are the same as those in previous agreements concluded by Australia with EURATOM, France and Sweden. The Japanese Nuclear Fuel Cycle program is heavily dependent on nuclear fuel cycle services, namely, conversion, low enrichment, fuel fabrication and reprocessing, being undertaken at facilities in third countries. As I have already observed, the Agreement provides for the exercise by Australia of prior consent rights over transfers to such third countries. All the third countries with facilities included in the delineated Japanese Nuclear Fuel Cycle program have a safeguards agreement with Australia incorporating the requirements of the 1977 policy. These agreements confirm that satisfactory controls would be applied to the trans- ferred material in those countries in accordance with Australia's policy requirements. Consequently, it has been possible, in an exchange of notes to the Agreement, for the Australian Government to exercise its prior consent right by means of a system of notification for the transfers to the facilities in third countries within the delineated Japanese Nuclear Fuel Cycle program. A similar arrangement is contained in our agreements with Sweden and EURATOM.

The conclusion of the Agreement with Japan means that the Government has now come close to accomplishing the objective of concluding bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements with those member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development with significant nuclear industries. The network of bilateral agreements we have established represents a body of international law and practice that is facilitating international nuclear trade under strict non-proliferation controls. This is what is meant when we say that Australia's bilateral agreements are contributing to international efforts to limit the spread of nuclear weapons. The Agreement with Japan is particularly relevant in this respect. Like our agreements with EURATOM, Canada, Finland, Sweden and the United States, it has a duration of 30 years. Moreover, Japan has a heavy commitment to the use of nuclear reactors for the generation of electricity possessing some 24 such reactors, and, for the foreseeable future, the Japanese nuclear fuel cycle will continue to depend significantly on international co-operation for its effective functioning.

Bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements are a major element in the Government's policy, aimed at preventing the further spread of nuclear weapons. This approach includes active participation by Australia in international disarmament discussions, continued support for relevant international treaties and for efforts aimed at maintaining and enhancing the contribution to this objective of international institutional arrangements. To this end, Australia has played an active role in the Non-Proliferation Treaty review conferences, in INFCE in the negotiation of a Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material in International Transport, in the study of the feasibility of an international plutonium storage scheme and in an IAEA committee which is studying the question of assurances of supply in the nuclear field. The Government is also active in working for improvements in international safeguards through the IAEA itself, and is making a voluntary contribution to a program of support for IAEA safeguards.

I wish to stress the importance of this Agreement for the bilateral relationship between Australia and Japan. It is a binding legal document which expresses the obligations of the two countries to carry out future co-operation in the peaceful, non-explosive uses of nuclear energy. It represents a significant contribution in the continuing effort to prevent the further spread of nuclear weapons not least in our own region of the world. It provides confirmation that the Government has been able, throughout its negotiations on nuclear safeguards agreements, to apply the terms of Australian policy without favour or discrimination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has made a statement today relating to the Australia-Japan Nuclear Safeguards Agreement and, as he has said, this is the tenth agreement. We could say it is the tenth statement in similar terms. It has a feeling of deja vu about it. On that basis, I find myself having to repeat the strong objections I made to the other nine agreements because this one is no different. The objections I put forward, whether they related to the agreements with France, Sweden, the European Atomic Energy Community or Finland, still apply. The Government will not shift its position as to the weaknesses of that position. The key to these agreements, it seems to think, are the much lauded administrative arrangements to implement the provisions of the Agreement, to guarantee that we can always follow our fuel through the whole cycle and to guarantee that there is no diversion of the fuel into explosive material.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the Agreement purports to say that Australia maintains its right to prior consent over reprocessing. If looked at from that point of view, it appears that the Government does have some continuing control over it. But I want to make the point that the Agreement has watered down safeguards to which any responsible government should adhere. We do not really have control of the fuel throughout the cycle. At the moment, it is taken out as natural uranium and is then controlled by everybody else except Australia. It is important for the Australian people, and for the policies of peace in the world, to guarantee that environmental factors at least are preserved during high level waste disposal, that we maintain complete control. It is important that we talk about storage of waste, and the Government has a responsibility in that respect also.

A fair bit of work has been done in technology but it is still not sufficient. The technology of the world is not sufficiently advanced to guarantee that there will not be any diversification into weapons grade material. There is certainly no technology to guarantee the safe disposal of the high level waste. It is important not to assume that the technology is right; it is wrong. The French vitrification process of high level waste disposal is not adequate. The United States of America will not use it and nor should it. It is important that we consider developing some research, such as that done in Australia by Professor Ringwood and others, in an effort to help the world by safe disposal of high level waste. Unfortunately, at the moment, simply because it is France disposing of the waste, it has to be done the way the French do it; if it is the United States disposing of the waste, it has to be done the way the United States does it. But when an Australian has a few good ideas nothing is done. Australia remains well down the totem pole compared with the people who are using its uranium in the matter of taking advantage of the intelligence of Australians who might be able to help in the safe disposal of high level wastes. The fact that governments make statements such as the one before us, while not really grappling with the problems facing the world, is to be deplored. It is important that we back high level research in this area. If Professor Ringwood has ability in that regard he should be backed fully by the Government. The moneys that apparently are being expended upon the sale of natural uranium should certainly be used to guarantee that the world remains a safer and better place.

What is Australia's significance in terms of natural uranium resources? We have 294,000 tonnes of reasonably assured resources, and an estimated further 264,000 tonnes available to us. Thus, we are second only to the United States in the world, in terms of natural uranium resources. Of course, we do not know the extent of the resources of the Soviet Union or Eastern Europe. Admittedly, the demand for uranium has declined rapidly. In 1975 it was estimated that by 1985 the demand from Western world buyers would amount to 108,000 tonnes per annum. A revised estimate now puts the figure at a mere 39,000 tonnes by 1985. Simply because world demand has become slack is no reason why the Government should become slack and embark upon a desperate effort to maintain a high selling rate for our natural uranium.

Again I make the point that at present uranium is making a contribution to the production of the world's energy. Unfortunately, it is also making a contribution to the production of weapons. The issue is one of getting the two uses separated, with an understanding that there must be proper peaceful use of the fuel rather than its being used for weapons. At present there are in operation in the world 243 nuclear power stations of more than 30 megawatt capacity. An additional 229 are under construction and another 55 are on order. There is no doubt that within a very short time at least 500 nuclear power stations will be operating throughout the world. Japan has 23 in operation and a further 10 under construction. Indeed, it is one of the world's top five users of uranium. Because it has no natural fuels of its own but obviously must sustain its capacity for electricity generation, it must employ uranium for that purpose. Again, because Japan is in that bind, and has to enter into negotiations with us concerning safeguards anyway, it is important to guarantee that there shall be no diversification or misuse of the resultant waste. It is not just a question of being anti-Japanese; we are not that. But the Japanese have no alternative, and surely it is possible to reach a proper agreement. The same can be said of the other nine agreements.

The Minister states that there has been no watering down of the Agreement but I ask honourable members to examine it. Certainly, the Agreement is expressed in very fine words. Article V provides that there shall be no processing without our prior consent, but if one turns to the annexure one finds a letter written on 5 March by the Minister to His Excellency the Ambassador of Japan which states:
I have the honour to refer to the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of Japan . . .
I have further the honour to propose, on behalf of the Government of Australia, the following arrangements:

As regards the question of giving prior consent, the statement is made that consent is hereby given. Therefore, it is not of much use Article V providing that Australia must give prior consent when a letter such as that of 5 March is attached saying that consent has been given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only to delineated programs.
—The Minister's letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . hereby gives the consent referred to in sub-paragraph 1 (a) of Article V . . .
That provision states:
Nuclear material . . . shall only be transferred beyond the jurisdiction of a Contracting Party with the prior written consent of the other Contracting Party.
The Minister has given that consent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is a delineated program.
—But you have given consent.
—But we both have to agree to the program.
—Let us examine what else the Government has done. In his letter the Minister states also:

SPEECH.PARA: (ii) the consultations referred to in the Implementing Arrangement are not requested by the Government of Australia . . .

2. (a) As regards the transfer of nuclear material from Australia to Japan through any third country, or re-transfer of ANM from any third country to Japan . . . the Government of Australia shall approve such transfer . . .
(ii) in the case of the transfer from Australia to Japan through a third country, the consultations referred to in the Implementing Arrangement are not requested . . .
They are not required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we have agreements with them.
—Yes, but it is of no use to say in the Agreement that we have all these chances for control when we have written them away. The Minister's letter states further:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. (a) As regards the transfer of nuclear material directly from Australia to Japan, the Government of Australia shall approve such transfer in accordance with the relevant laws . . .

Finally, the Minister writes that he wishes to ensure that the letter shall be deemed to be an agreement between the two Governments. I am not making a personal attack on the Minister-the same may be said of all of the other agreements-but this seems to be a desperate attempt to sell uranium fuel even though we do not have the necessary technology to guarantee safeguards.

Article VIII speaks of arbitration. If there is any dispute between the parties again we will lose control of the fuel because it will fall within an arbitral process. Certainly, Australia has one arbiter, the Japanese have another, and the two countries select a third, but naturally the point is made that 'the decisions of the tribunal shall be binding on the Contracting Parties'. Therefore, even if an arbiter disagreed with what was being done he could be outvoted two to one and Australia's ownership control of the fuel would again have disappeared, as a result of this arbitral clause.

The point I have made whenever I have spoken on the issue is that Australia's only guarantee is to own and control the fuel throughout the cycle. I acknowledge that Australia does not possess all of the processes necessary to enable this to be done but we certainly should be endeavouring to develop the technology. We should not be allowing our fuel to fall into private hands. That is far too dangerous a course to follow. Throughout the world reprocessing plants are government owned. One cannot afford to place the re-processing of fuel in the hands of the private sector. That is where the great difficulty lies . The United States has adopted the stupid approach that it should be left in the hands of the private sector. Look at the disasters that Westinghouse has perpetrated in regard to uranium fuel as a result of its poor technology or inability to understand the problems involved. I invite honourable members to consider that there are in existence 40,000 nuclear weapons, the possession of which is not limited in all cases to the super-powers. A number of diversions have occurred into countries that should not have such technology. That is the difficulty that confronts the world. The question as to what is happening to Australia's uranium is a cause for concern. I repeat, the only way to provide an adequate safeguard is to own the fuel throughout the cycle or, if the technology is not safe, to refuse to sell it. There will always be a market for it later on ; there is no need to sell it now. It is the wrong way to go.

The International Atomic Energy Agency has not yet arrived at a proper safeguard policy in respect to the use of plutonium, which is being produced in large quantities as a result of re-processing. If the world has not been able to work out a satisfactory safeguard procedure for plutonium, why does the Minister believe that the fuel which we sell will be treated differently from any other fuel? Our fuel goes into the fuel rod with fuel from other countries. We cannot trace the progress of every unit of our fuel. When it goes through the fuel rod in the first cycle and is re-processed knowledge concerning it is lost to us. We cannot identify Australian fuel as distinct from other fuels. One may well ask: What has happened to the plutonium and what is to be done about it. At the moment Japan sends our uranium elsewhere for reprocessing. Japan has a limited capacity in that regard. But Japan is adopting fast breeder technology, which involves the re-use of plutonium.

Also great pressure is being exerted on Japan by the United States to upgrade its defence commitments. Does this mean that Japan might at some stage feel that the best way for it to go, in order to achieve parity with the Soviet Union or China, is to manufacture nuclear weapons? It will have the technology and the fuel and could well be pressured into doing that on the ground that it had better do something about achieving such a capacity. Again I make the point that , although that surely is not the intention of this Government, the Japanese might say: 'We have to do something like this; we have this concept of defence for the area.' It could well say to Australia: 'We will give you an umbrella of protection'. How laughable that would be. But it might happen because President Reagan of the United States is saying to Japan: 'I want to withdraw our umbrella of nuclear protection; you had better think about providing one yourself'. In the light of this, one becomes very sceptical about the making of arrangements.

France engages in the reprocessing of fuel. As everyone knows, it provides a dreadful example of what can be done in the name of providing nuclear energy. France has set itself out to be the leading exponent of the use of such fuel in the production of nuclear energy, but its technology is not right. Its vitrification processes can easily be shown to be wrong. France is also, though, persisting with nuclear testing at Mururoa and irrespective of the change of government in France, unfortunately, that testing will continue. Why is the testing carried out at Mururoa, in the Pacific? If it is so safe, why not do it at Marseilles in France? When we ask the French about that they say they do not have the basalt rock structures that Mururoa has. That is nonsense. They would not be prepared to do it, nor would the people of France allow them to do it. France insists on having a first strike capability for nuclear weapons. It sold enriched uranium to Iraq-enriched to 30 per cent, well over the average-which in effect led to the pre-emptive strike by the Begin Government to destroy the reactor. We know that Finland and Sweden reprocess and enrich their uranium in the Soviet Union.

Do we have any idea what happens to the uranium? We do not. There are no adequate safeguards. We cannot control the fuel unless we prevent all diversion and can ensure satisfactory disposal of the wastes. The only way to do that is to own and control the fuel through the whole cycle. This applies to all our agreements, not just this one. Australia has this dangerous fuel but obviously it is a fuel that the world will use more of. It is ridiculous to think that we can run the world without energy but if there are alternatives we should try to find them quickly. If there are no alternatives and governments have to use this fuel for peaceful purposes, of course there will be demand for our uranium. There is no danger about the market; there is no danger about the capacity of Australians to fulfil their role.

However, it is important with agreements like this to analyse what is wrong. The technology of waste disposal does not exist. The French technology is basically wrong. This can be shown clearly in regard to the vitrification process. The waste, because of the heat in it, has to be stored for 40 years and if it is stored it is likely to break down because of the conditions. It is important that we do something about these matters. The Labor Party policy has always said we want more technology and more guarantees that this fuel, if used for peaceful purposes, will not be of any danger to the world. What will happen in regard to the Japanese disposing of our waste in the Pacific? Will anybody in the Pacific agree to that? What will the Japanese do about waste disposal? Where is there in this agreement any arrangement as to the disposal of the high level waste? We cannot find such an arrangement because the Japanese do not yet have the technology. They should not be using French technology. I can guarantee that the French will not be prepared to store the Japanese high level waste in France , so what will happen to it? The United States will not store any of its high level waste because it has not developed the technology.

It is about time we had a pause in uranium development, not to prevent people from maintaining their standards of living but certainly to prevent any misuse of safeguards which are as weak as those contained in this statement. It guarantees nothing unless we own and control the fuel through the whole cycle. That means it all has to be done on a government to government basis. The private sector has no chance to participate in uranium development because it cannot give guarantees on the issues that worry the world. It is for that reason I repeat what I have said in my previous addresses to the House on uranium. It is about time we put more money into technology. That is the way we ought to go. Until such time as we help Ringwood and others develop that technology we should not do anything about selling our uranium.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received letters from the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro ( Mr Sainsbury) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by Standing Order 107, Mr Speaker has selected the matter which in his opinion is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Reid, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to develop and implement programs to relieve critical housing problems.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest rates on housing finance will rise by at least one per cent in April after the Lowe by-election and the Victorian State election are out of the way. This will mean a further increase in repayments of $22 a month on a $30,000 loan repaid over 25 years. It will be a further burden placed on people now paying off their homes and it will drive home ownership out of the reach of 9,000 prospective home buyers. This will mean an accumulated increase of $88 a month on an average loan since September 1980. Things could be even worse because if the Howard-Lynch group in Cabinet gets its way the Government will implement the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommendation to deregulate interest rates. This would mean that savings bank loans would rise at least to 15.5 per cent, which would mean an increase in repayments on existing average housing loans of $132 a month since September 1980. It would disqualify nine out of 10 prospective home buyers . Of course building society loan repayments would be even higher than those of the savings banks.

SPEECH.PARA: Next to unemployment, housing is the most serious social problem in this country. Over the past six years housing problems have grown more serious because of this Government's neglect. We have not seen any attempt by this Government to address the growing problems of housing. Instead we have seen the Government withdraw further from its responsibility to ensure the adequate provision of shelter for Australian people. We have seen it withdraw from its responsibility to ensure a stable flow of funds for housing at a price ordinary people can afford. We have seen this Government deliberately withdraw support for State public housing. We have seen it withdraw from its responsibility to promote stability in the housing industry. Just as this Government has been prepared to trade off unemployment against inflation, so it has deliberately sacrificed the housing sector in order to make room for expanded foreign investment in resource development projects in this country. Through its rigid monetary policy this Government has stifled those domestic economic activities which provide a secure social and industrial structure in our nation.

The housing sector is a major victim of this Government's economic policy. Several areas of the housing sector have suffered badly. The Government's housing policy requires urgent comprehensive attention, and it needs to be attention on a broad base. Its policy cannot really be saved by any band-aid approval or narrow concepts. Home ownership has to be looked at, particularly in regard to first home buyers. As a result of rising interest rates more people are being excluded from access to affordable housing finance. They are faced with a widening deposit gap which years of savings cannot overcome. For example, the median house price in Melbourne in December 1981 was $49,000. At the current interest rate in Victoria of 15.5 per cent a family with a single breadwinner's income equivalent to average weekly earnings of $301 can obtain a maximum loan of only $25,000 from a building society over a 30-year term. The family then has to find a further $24,000. If it had saved, say, $10,000 over six years it could approach a finance company for a second mortgage of $10,000 but it would have to pay an interest rate of between 18.5 per cent and 22 per cent. To do that the family would have to commit around 35 per cent of its household income to mortgage repayments. It would then leave itself highly vulnerable in the event of further interest rate increases. As I have stressed, interest rates will be increased in April after the Victorian State election.

The reality of the situation is that single income families on incomes of up to 135 per cent of average weekly earnings are effectively excluded from access to home ownership at present house prices and interest rates. To put it another way , three out of four salary earners can no longer afford to buy their first home. The Government has done nothing about this problem. It is prepared to stand by while the level of home ownership in Australia continues to decline. The only scheme that the Government has put forward in the past six years has been the Homes Savings Grants Scheme which last year helped fewer than two out of five first home buyers. It provides too little too late to be useful to most people. It is known in the industry as the home decorators' account. It is a scandal that this discredited scheme absorbed over $70m out of a housing budget of some $400m.

At the last election Labor put forward a more effective home ownership assistance scheme which provided for a $3,000 grant over the first four years of a mortgage so as to increase average borrowings by around $10,000 at no extra cost to the first home buyer. We will be putting forward such a scheme again at a revised level to take account of house price increases and interest rate rises .

The second area of concern to the Labor Party is the failure of the Government to protect those families that bought their first home over the last five years and are now having trouble holding onto it because of rising home loan repayments and, particularly rising interest rates. We estimate that there are at least 250,000 households in such difficulty. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the net effect on household incomes of interest rate rises on average loans.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table shows, for example, that a single income family with a dependent spouse and two children, where the breadwinner's income was the equivalent of average weekly earnings, obtained an average loan in 1977- 78 of $26,000 from a building society at an interest rate of 11 per cent. At the time of purchase the family paid $249.20 in monthly loan instalments. Because the interest rate has risen to 14.5 per cent, repayments on that loan are $319. 70, an increase of $70.50 per month. However, the family's post-tax monthly income has risen from 1977-78 to September 1981 by only $16. As a result of the increased repayment burden, in the context of other Government policies which reduce family living standards, the family's real disposable income has been reduced by $54.50 a month. In September 1981 the problem was less severe than it was in September 1980 for those families whose income has grown. Again I stress that interest rates will again rise in April and that pressure will be increased on those people. But what of those who have not been able to increase their incomes during that period?

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to another matter that really needs consideration. Other housing programs are necessary to ensure that no householders who brought their first home over the last five years pay any more of their income in mortgage repayments than the proportion they committed at the time of purchase. The Government needs to implement such a scheme; otherwise it will have the real problems of at least a quarter of a million families on its hands. In addition, there should be provision for household budgeting advice to families in difficulty and to renegotiate the mortgage debt structure of first home buyers.

Another matter of concern is the need to stabilise the availability and price of housing finance. The number of loan approvals for the purchase or construction of dwellings fell by 17.3 per cent from November 1980 to November 1981. In the case of savings banks the fall was 7.2 per cent and in the case of permanent building societies the fall was 35.4 per cent. These declines reflect the increased value of loan advances, the falling demand for loans as a consequence of high lending rates and the declining availability of loanable funds, especially for savings banks. Funds are being attracted away from housing in a number of ways as a result of this Government's policy. In the first place, foreign corporations are raising a large proportion of their borrowings on the Australian capital market. Last year $1 out of every $5 saved by Australians was being used by foreign owned corporations. At the same time, some government authorities are offering an interest rate of 15.6 per cent on four to nine year bonds while the market rate for bonds over eight years is 16.25 per cent to 17.6 per cent. Merchant banks are offering 18 per cent on secured at call notes. Solicitors' funds are offering 17 per cent on 12-monthly investments. Over the year to November 1981 savings banks deposits grew by only 7 per cent, which is less than the rate of inflation and lower than the rate over the last few years of 9 per cent to 10 per cent.

When we look more closely we find, however, that deregulation of bank deposit rates has allowed the banks to increase deposits in investment accounts by 17 per cent while deposits in ordinary accounts grew by only 0.5 per cent. Savings banks currently offer interest rates of 11.5 per cent to 12 per cent on investment accounts as distinct from 3.75 per cent on ordinary accounts. This rate has levelled out at 7 per cent. Under this Government the banks are finding that they are being squeezed by competition from the resource development area. If the deposit structure of the banks continues to shift towards higher interest rates the banks will be unwilling and possibly unable to provide housing funds at affordable interest rates. Action needs to be taken to stabilise the flow of funds to housing lenders. This should be done in a way that keeps the price of housing loans within the means of average households. This Government has no policies in this area. It is prepared to sit back while the market, which is distorted by the power of the large financial corporations, sets for itself new structures to determine the availability and price of housing finance.

Labor is prepared to assert the social importance of housing. I want to stress that for Labor housing is a major priority. We will intervene in the financial system to ensure that there is a stable flow of funds for housing at an affordable price. We will proclaim Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act 1974 which gives the Government power over assets, lending and interest rates and financial corporations at present outside the arm of regulation. We will use the Act in accordance with one of its objectives which is: 'The ensuring of an adequate level of finance for housing'. If, for example, we required that 2 per cent of the assets of financial corporations under the schedule of the Act be earmarked for housing, we would provide an additional $600m for housing. The finance companies could continue to offer housing loans at their usurious interest rates but we would have captured a large part of their lending, together with funds from other sources, to ensure a pool of lower cost housing funds.

Another area at which we could look where funds for housing are available is life insurance funds. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the assets and types of lending by life insurance funds.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1981 only 3.4 per cent of the assets of life insurance funds was provided for housing as against 15.2 per cent in 1961. If the insurance funds were required to deposit 6 per cent of their assets for on-lending for housing, an extra $600m could be obtained. Labor is prepared to explore such possibilities and we will be negotiating about these matters with financial institutions. We are further investigating the introduction of tax-free housing bonds. Another area being examined is indexed housing bonds for pensioners, or those people over 55 years of age.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1 to 2 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech of the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) was a cynical exercise. Its timing was not dictated by any real attempt to improve the situation of Australian home buyers. It was purely and simply an attempt to get round the electronic media blackout in the hope of picking up a vote or two in a certain by-election that is coming up.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has nothing whatsoever to be ashamed of in the way in which it is handling the complexities of providing solutions to the housing problem. It has been difficult to pick up a newspaper, switch on the radio or television or indeed, appear in this House, without being bombarded by suggestions of all sorts from the Opposition about how the Government should solve the housing problem.

As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, we on this side of the House are rather humble people. We have never claimed to be the only people with all the answers and all the wisdom. We have actively sought the views of State governments, housing and industry groups and, of course, many individuals. We have also analysed the Opposition's high-cost panaceas. Let me say that we appreciate the advice that is being offered to us from everyone. But the advice and the suggestions we have heard from the honourable member for Reid would ring truer if they came from someone who had a better track record in relation to housing and home ownership. It would ring truer if it came from someone from a party which had shown itself capable of understanding the interrelationships between housing finance and the economy as a whole. It would ring truer if it had come from an Opposition which had shown itself capable of taking the time and applying the intelligence to track through the complexities and come up with a sensible solution-not one dictated to by political expedience in an attempt to influence each and every election.

I am amongst the first to admit that housing has become an urgent problem for some people, but this is not the case for the vast majority of Australian householders. At the present time, more than 38 per cent of Australians own their homes outright. That compares very favourably with the miserable 28 per cent which Labor managed to achieve in its big spending term of government. The honourable member for Reid has no right whatsoever to be critical. Of those who direct criticism against current policies it is he who should be the least vocal . Despite his cries of doom, Australia still has one of the highest rates of home ownership in the developed world and that has been achieved through a succession of Liberal-National Country Party coalition governments. This Government has carried on that commitment to home ownership and can be expected to do so in the future. At almost 72 per cent, our level of home ownership compares favourably with other countries. It compares with 50 per cent in England; 62 per cent in Canada; 47 per cent in France; 65 per cent in the United States of America and 33 per cent in West Germany.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many in West Germany?

—Thirty-three per cent in West Germany. Victoria's home ownership rate of 75 per cent is the highest of all Australian States and outshines the New South Wales rate of 71 per cent which is below the national average and indicates the Wran Government's demonstrable lack of concern for home buyers and home owners.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been accused by the Opposition and by some sections of the media of being unaware of, and uninterested in, the plight of home owners and intending buyers. Such claims are hysterical nonsense. As I have said on many occasions, the Government has conducted a review of its housing policies and a review of those housing problems and difficulties facing specific groups in the community. We have identified and costed the various ways of assisting both existing and aspiring home owners and are looking at these options in association with measures to increase the availability of housing finance. As we see it, the main groups facing difficulties at the moment are: People who have borrowed in the last couple of years, particularly those who have since become one income families; aspiring first home buyers who are finding it hard to bridge the deposit gap, and some families renting in the private market.

In the face of mounting and emotional criticism I believe it is to the Government's credit that we have not been stampeded into announcing schemes and policies merely to satisfy the likes of the honourable member for Reid and those media commentators who are more interested in headlines than in facts. When we move it will be the right move. It will be the right decision and it will be a decision which fits comfortably into our overall budgetary and economic strategies. There will be no band-aid treatments. There will not be any patch-up jobs. The people of Australia deserve responsible and steady government. That is why they voted for us in 1975, again in 1977 and again in 1980. There will be no ad hoc or erratic decisions on housing or any other matter.

Speaking broadly, the Government's assistance in the field of housing can be broken down into two groups-assistance to first home buyers through the Homes Savings Grant Scheme and assistance to the needy and those in special circumstances. The Government is often subjected to unreasonable criticism by an Opposition which chooses to ignore the facts and the realities of housing and which fights its crusade purely on shallow and emotional grounds. In addition to expanding the flexibility with which the States can manage and direct the welfare housing contributions made by the Commonwealth, this Government, in the August Budget, lifted very substantially indeed its overall spending on housing and accommodation. Appropriation in these areas rose from $555m to $660m, an increase of 18.9 per cent.

Since that lifting of expenditure we have also announced a contribution of $2m to the States to provide crisis accommodation for families in distress. This honoured an election commitment we made in late 1980. Significantly, there was not a murmur from the Opposition benches. The media, with few exceptions, ignored the announcement. If this overall increase is an indication that the Government is unaware of and disinterested in housing and accommodating Australians, then I suggest the only alternative the Opposition can offer is a return to the irrational and irresponsible big-spending programs which it introduced in 1972. The economy of this country and the people of this country are still paying the bill for that senseless period of government.

This Government is aware of the problems facing home owners, intending home buyers and the poor in our society and is taking positive steps, and spending substantial amounts of money, to solve these problems and lessen the burdens. It is about time then that credit was given where it is due and that housing stopped being a political issue and started becoming a human issue. It is often forgotten in the so-called housing debate that housing is an area in which State governments also have a responsibility. State and local governments also bear a heavy responsibility for housing costs.

Let us look at the people who build houses. The building trades award of 27 January this year has given tradesmen an average pay rise of almost $30 a week. The reduction of the building industry's working week to 38 hours-from 24 May this year-will increase wage costs by a further 5 per cent. We can expect the new building trades award to increase wages by a further $14 a week from July. The total wage-hours package will add around 21 per cent to the on-site labour costs of building a house. By the time these costs flow on an average $50,000 new house in Sydney will suffer a cost increase of $3,000. An average new house in Melbourne, costing $36,000, will suffer an impost of about $2,200. Statistics of the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that because of differing building regulations and other factors influenced by State and local governments, the cost of building an average 150 square metre house in Sydney, at around $44,000, compares with $36,000 in Melbourne. A more modest 120 square metre home will cost about $35,000 to build in Sydney and less than $30,000 in Melbourne.

Conveyancing and stamp duty imposed by, or under the control of, State governments also pose a burden to home buyers. In Sydney, a house and land package costing $65,000 confronts a first home buyer with a stamp duty bill of $ 1,300, the only concession being that this can be paid in five interest free instalments. In Melbourne the same house and land package would cost about $40, 000 and would attract stamp duty of $800. By comparison with the mean, miserable New South Wales Government the Victorian Government offers first home buyers a concession which reduces this bill to $400. So there are States which are more willing than others to reduce the cost burdens and cost pressures facing first home buyers. As I have noted in the Press recently that the States are never afraid to offer advice to the Commonwealth Government as to how it should spend money which it has the responsibility of raising, I will now offer the States a little advice. I appeal to all the States of the Commonwealth to abolish stamp duty for first home buyers. I suggest that they stop prancing and parading about and uttering platitudes. They should put their cheque books where their mouths have been and abolish stamp duty for all first home buyers.

It was reported recently that the New South Wales Government, for example-I am not picking out the New South Wales Government for any particular reason- collected $243m from stamp duty in 1980-81. This amount was a staggering 100 per cent increase on the collections made in the previous year and yet the Government is charging first home buyers $1,300 each for stamp duty. The receipts levied from home buyers were more than three times the amount which the Wran Government spent on welfare housing in that year. It raised three times more money in stamp duty from home buyers than it spent on welfare housing. As far as first home buyers are concerned quite obviously there are blood stains on the New South Wales balance sheet on account of this. Last night the Victorian Premier placed himself among the few State leaders who are beginning to take their housing responsibilities seriously. His announcement of two new schemes- both containing an interest subsidy element-indicates Victoria's realisation that housing is a joint and a shared responsibility. Mr Thompson's announcement that more than $60m worth of State funds will be injected into the housing area is welcome news not only for those people who are intending to buy their first homes but also for those who have bought recently and are facing difficulties.

I have already established that the Federal Government shares with State and local governments a responsibility in the housing field. But let us not forget that people too need to act responsibly rather than make decisions in the hope that, if they are the wrong ones, the Commonwealth will mount a rescue operation . Not very often in this House do I quote a member of the Opposition but I believe it is appropriate to quote the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson), a former Minister for Housing. He said recently-it was reported in the Press-that many home buyers are not leaving themselves a reasonable margin. I would like recorded in Hansard what the honourable member for Hughes, a former Minister for Housing, said. He stated:
People are maximising their loans and incurring trouble with the various building societies. They don't take into regard things such as pregnancy. Some of them are getting into trouble.

The whole question of housing assistance is one which must be considered in a responsible light. The Commonwealth cannot afford to provide assistance across the board, nor can the States. Financial assistance must be well directed to people in need and it must be directed for the period of the need. I would like to look at some overlooked facts on housing finance and the building industry. The situation is not as bad as honourable members opposite would have us believe . In fact, lending by permanent building societies has increased in each of the last three months on a seasonally adjusted basis. It is up by nearly 8 per cent in the three months to January on the previous three months. Forecasts by the Indicative Planning Council of the housing industry suggest an even higher rate of lending over the remainder of the financial year. The latest figures for banks for the month of December also showed a seasonally adjusted increase of about 6.5 per cent.

The Australian Labor Party has continuously claimed that the housing industry is on the edge of collapse. The industry keeps disappointing the ALP. In fact the number of approvals for dwellings in 1981-these are the latest figures available-was up 1.2 per cent on those for 1980. Of course, I will not claim that the industry is likely to repeat its near record 1980-81 performance of about 150,000 commencements, but it should commence around 138,000 dwellings. That is not a figure that can be portrayed as a total collapse as the Opposition tries to do. In fact it would be higher than any year since 1976-77 apart from last year's near record level. The contribution by the honourable member for Reid, who tried to stir up the worries of people by indicating that interest rates would increase, reminds me of a funeral director preparing the obituaries of initiative, determination and reliance on one's own efforts. He has seen fit to criticise the performance of this Government, a government which, through its sensible financial control, has been able to stabilise costs to the industry and keep the Australian home ownership rates amongst the highest in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.
