SPEECH.PARA: That this House -

(1) views with the greatest alarm public allegations today that a senior Minister of the Government has been responsible for preventing any action being proceeded with against Nugan Hand in spite of clear evidence that Nugan Hand was involved in heroin deals, laundering money and had connections with organised crime and the CIA;

(2) requires the Prime Minister forthwith to respond to these allegations and to assure this House that neither he nor any other Minister who has served or serves with him has taken or caused to be taken any steps which would prevent or hinder inquiries into any of the above matters or matters related to them.
The Minister concerned has been privately identified as the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), but in these circumstances--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The request is for leave. Is leave granted?
—Leave is refused.
—Leave is refused.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent me from moving forthwith:
That this House-

(1) views with the greatest alarm public allegations today that a senior minister of the Government has been responsible for preventing any action being proceeded with against Nugan Hand in spite of clear evidence that Nugan Hand was involved in heroin deals, laundering money and had connections with organised crime and the CIA, and

(2) requires the Prime Minister forthwith to respond to these allegations and to assure this House that neither he nor any other Minister who has served or serves with him has taken or caused to be taken any steps which would prevent or hinder inquiries into any of the above matters or matters related to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable gentleman have the motion in writing?
—Yes, Mr Speaker. The allegations have been made publicly today. We neither endorse them nor--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is extraordinary. We advised the Prime Ministers's office that this matter was going to come up.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Mr Speaker-

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) agreed to:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Original question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Sales Tax Legislation
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes.

The tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them from general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers.

This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture. Your petitioners therefore pray: that your honourable House will exempt books, periodicals including newspapers from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers, particularly educational publications and books of a religious nature, is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, a clear infringement of our democratic freedom, and that no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr O'Keefe and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth Airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for cost of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non residential area at Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Health Care Card System introduced on 1 September for low income, unemployed, pensioners and other beneficiaries discriminates against the unemployed by its exclusion of pharmaceutical, optical and other entitlements to unemployed people. This discrimination results in greater hardship and distress to the unemployed and their dependants, and reduces their access to essential health facilities by increasing the onerous burden of health charges on this group which can least afford it.
This discrimination is a further example of the Government's harsh and insensitive treatment toward the unemployed and their families, and creates unnecessary divisions within Australian society.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should review the Health Care Card System and extend the benefits for pharmaceutical, optical and other entitlements to the unemployed ( in line with the recent recommendation of the Australian Medical Association).
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantages in employment, education , accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the 26th January, 1788, is the date of first white settlement in Australia , and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia, and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Westernport Youth Refuge, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned about the possible closure of the Westernport Youth Refuge because of inadequate funds made available under the Youth Accommodation Services Program (A joint Department of Community Welfare Services and Department of Social Security Program).

Over a 12 month period more than 500 young people have been assisted by the refuge. If it is forced to close then many homeless young people in the Westernport Region will be left without any assistance at all.
Your petitioners, in duty bound, humbly pray that additional funds be provided under the Youth Accommodation Services Program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes. I am led to believe that my name--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—I am hearing a personal explanation. I will not take a point of order.
—Hearing just one side means that you are restricted to one story.
—There is no point of order. I am hearing a personal explanation.

—Mr Speaker, I am led to believe that my name was mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) a few minutes ago as supposedly being associated with interfering with the investigation of the Nugan Hand organisation. I have no knowledge of what is going on, I have not been involved in any way whatsoever with that organisation and I have not tried to interfere with it in any way and this instance is nothing more than the raising of speculative matters by the Opposition.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hayden

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. What the Deputy Prime Minister has just done is designed to circumvent a proper debate on a matter of great concern. Allegations of a serious nature have been made elsewhere. We trust that they are incorrect. We believe that a statement in Parliament is the proper way in which to expunge the record.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker--
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—May I conclude on this one point?

—No. The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I indicate to the honourable gentleman that he is not raising a point of order; he is putting a point of view. The Deputy Prime Minister was called, appropriately, to make a personal explanation. It is an opportunity available to every member of the House. He did so and I do not propose to allow a personal explanation to become the vehicle of a debate.
—Mr Speaker, the point I am making is nonetheless that the Government wants to gag a debate and create a situation which is loaded heavily in its favour.
—Order!
—These matters have to be heard and--
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—These matters have to be aired, and, I would hope, the atmosphere cleared by a blunt denial on the part of the Government.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I would like to make a personal explanation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know the way in which the honourable gentleman--

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh and the honourable member for Hotham will remain silent. They continually interject and they must cease doing so.

—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to make a personal explanation. The reason I do this is that the terms of the motion which the Leader of the Opposition attempted to move a moment ago clearly implicate me as well as the Deputy Prime Minister.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Having prevented an open debate taking place, the Government is now seeking to introduce a very prejudiced point of view.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The honourable gentleman--
—Mr Speaker, in no way was there any reference to this Minister. He is seeking to introduce a debate but prevent us from debating.

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The opportunity for a personal explanation can be taken by any honourable member if, as a result of the debate that has preceded, he has in any way found it necessary to personally explain his actions or behaviour. In the debate, such as it was, I did not hear the honourable gentleman's name mentioned. I think the way in which the honourable gentleman is putting it is by way of some implication. If the Minister can indicate to me why he needs to make a personal explanation, I will permit it.

—Mr Speaker, I believe that it is necessary for me to make a personal explanation because in the terms of the motion the Leader of the Opposition was talking about allegations have been made on television and in newspaper articles . The television interview particularly clearly implicated a Minister of the Crown who was related to the activities of the Nugan Hand investigation. That can only be me. Therefore it does need an explanation.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I must indicate to the Minister that because he was not in any way implicated by what has been said in the debate, I cannot call upon him to make a personal explanation. If he wishes to make a statement he will need to ask for leave to do so.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order to confirm your ruling. I have the transcript here--
—The honourable member does not need to confirm my ruling. The ruling has been given.
—I would have thought that on past record you would have been delighted at the prospect.
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Further petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Funding of Children's Services
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services program is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important program.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that monies be made available to subsidise child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programs and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners therefore humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, footwear, newspapers, buildings and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers, and reduce employment opportunities.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop 'normalised' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide 'noninstitutionalised' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from , or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a 'disability' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal IYDP Funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned members of the community of South Australia respectfully showeth:

That interest rates on housing loans are at an intolerable level which prevents home buyers, prospective and existing, purchasing their homes without aggravating their already intolerably low standard of living.
That free market forces have dictated this high level of interest rates where some lending institutions charge up to 55 per cent interest and banks up to 11 1 /2 per cent interest.

That home buyers are unable to absorb such increases in interest rates as these and the result is that many Australian families face financial ruin taking with them an intricate chain of small businesses, the backbone of Australia, with further unemployment resulting and in particular a further decline in the building industry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
As a matter of urgency lower interest rates on housing loans to give home buyers a fairer deal; and
Show compassion for the unemployed by pursuing alternative expansionary economic policies.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Minister for Communications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned members of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union respectfully showeth:

That the Prime Minister of Australia should seek the resignation of the Minister for Communications. Failing this the Prime Minister should dismiss the aforementioned Minister. We seek this action following the Minister's apparent lack of concern for the welfare of his employees in the Australian Postal Commission and the Australian Telecommunications Commission.

Staff ceilings imposed as directed by the Minister show that the future employment security of Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union members is jeopardised. It is our educated estimation that these staff ceilings will also effect the standard of service provided to the public by the two commissions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Prime Minister will take immediate action to abide by our desire.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Thomson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for amendment of the Repatriation Act in four respects. The first is in relation to the control of the disability pensions for veterans suffering serious service related mental illness. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced last year, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that deductions for maintenance from the pensions of a small number of mentally ill veterans to whom section 49 of the Repatriation Act applies, were to be discontinued and that the disability pensions of certain veterans should be handled in the same manner as all other disability pensions.

Section 49 of the Repatriation Act is a special provision that can be applied by the Repatriation Commission to withhold the pension of an unmarried veteran suffering severe mental illness. The severity of the mental illness must usually be such as to warrant long term hospitalisation in a mental institution. If a veteran recovers to the extent that he is able to control his own affairs, all retained money is paid to him. If he dies without recovering, the accumulated funds do not form part of his estate but are disposed of at the Commission's discretion to members of his family or to persons dependent on him, with any remaining funds being paid to Consolidated Revenue.

The provisions of section 49, which had their origins in legislation enacted in 1920, are out-dated and create some significant differences between the way these mentally disabled veterans are treated and the way other disabled veterans are treated. For example, it has been the practice under section 49 for half the disability pension to be deducted as a contribution to the cost of their maintenance while in a mental institution, and to pay this deduction to Consolidated Revenue. It is the Government's view that, since no other veteran is required to make such a contribution when receiving treatment for a service related disability, the practice is discriminatory and should cease.

This Bill, in repealing section 49, will provide for a veteran's pension and any accumulated money to become his property, in the same way that it is for every other veteran. As a result, if a veteran dies while still suffering from his disability, all of his accumulated pension will form part of his estate and be distributed in accordance with his wishes if a valid will has been made, or otherwise, in accordance with the laws of intestacy. If a veteran is in a mental institution his affairs are normally controlled by the State Public Trustee. Some of the veterans to whom section 49 applies are not the responsibility of State governments, and these are generally those veterans who are no longer in mental institutions.

The Bill provides that upon the repeal of section 49, the accumulated moneys of these veterans will be transferred to the trusteeship of the Repatriation Commission under regulation 9 of the repatriation regulations or, if it is thought that the veteran is able to manage for himself, his pension will be returned to him with the interest earned. The Bill provides for these arrangements to come into effect on the date of the royal assent. Discussions have been held with the various State governments with a view to transferring the appropriate funds to the respective State public trustee who would be responsible for the veterans' welfare. Agreement has been reached with five States on the proposed arrangements, and a reply is awaited from the other State . These arrangements will mean that a Public Trustee would assume the responsibility which he would normally have in respect of these veterans but for the existence of section 49. In many cases the Public Trustee already has responsibility for the other assets or income of the veteran and therefore the current dual trustee arrangement would be removed.

The Bill also provides for transitional provisions to finalise the accounts of veterans who have died, or who die before royal assent. These provisions extend the benefits of the new proposals to those veterans. The Bill also provides for the extension of repatriation benefits to Australian members of the Multinational Force and Observers committed to the Sinai region. This is in accordance with the undertaking the Government gave last year when repatriation benefits were extended to Australian representatives of peace- keeping, observation or monitoring forces. Repatriation benefits are to be extended on the same basis as applies to Australian members of other peacekeeping forces under Division 10 of the Repatriation Act.

The Bill also provides for two other matters. The first is to facilitate the recovery of Commonwealth expenditure for medical treatment provided to patients eligible to receive either workers' compensation benefits or third party damages and to align such provisions with those in other Commonwealth Acts. The present provisions of the repatriation legislation are restrictive in that they allow the recovery of the medical treatment costs from the injured party only and not from a third party, such as an insurer. The cost recovery process would be far more efficient and less demanding on patients if the Repatriation Commission could act directly with third parties as is the case under the Social Services Act and the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. The Bill will achieve this .

The second matter enables regulations to be prepared which will protect from legal actions those employees in repatriation hospitals who may be required to carry out duties arising from State legislation. These employees, in order to comply with State law as part of their community service, require the full cover of the law in order to be properly protected in the execution of their duties. However, because of their status as Commonwealth employees and the separation of Commonwealth and State jurisdictions they do not have that protection in some instances. At this stage, the main concern is the taking of blood samples in accident cases for the purpose of blood-alcohol testing. As the protection of medical and ancillary staff is not extended by State legislation, repatriation hospital staff have not been permitted to undertake these procedures. These amendments are to come into operation from the date of royal assent. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1982 now before the House proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. The Bill, which contains 13 Schedules, is necessary to enact tariff changes which have been introduced into the Parliament at various times since 14 May 1981 by customs tariff proposals Nos. 6-15 (1981) and proposals Nos. 1-5 (1982). In the main, the amendments give effect to decisions by the Government in respect of the following reports by the Industries Assistance Commission:

Certain bags, cases and similar containers; certain monomers, prepolymers and goods of the silicone type; chain of precious metal; cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools (in respect of razor blades only); fabricated steel structures; lamps and lighting fittings (developing countries preference); loudspeakers; miscellaneous manufacturing-certain refractory products; miscellaneous transport equipment; polyunsaturated margarine; primary batteries; railway and tramway locomotives, rolling stock, etc.; surge diverters; textiles, clothing and footwear; vibratory road rollers (developing countries preference); and wheelchairs

Honourable members will recall that on each occasion when tariffs were introduced into the House, a comprehensive account of the IAC's recommendations and Government decisions was outlined and the IAC reports were tabled. Other amendments contained in the Bill provide for:

Amended tariff preference rates for certain goods from developing countries following a review of developing country quota levels for the year 1981-82; additions to the list of goods accorded special preference under the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement; the addition of electric soil heating apparatus to Schedule A of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement; and a small number of changes of an administrative nature.
A summary of amendments for each Schedule setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and copies are available from the Table Office. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee on the Australian National Railways Commission, together with copies of the minutes of proceedings, the transcript of evidence and copies of published exhibits.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report on the Australian National Railways Commission marks the completion of the last of the inquiries of the Expenditure Committee which were initiated in the previous Parliament. The carry-over of inquiries always involves difficulties for a new committee and, in this case, the Committee's problems were compounded by some very complex issues which inevitably involved assessments as to how a commercial public authority such as Australian National ought to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank the members of the Committee, whose task it was to grapple with these problems and to resolve them. I am particularly grateful to the contributions made by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Morris) and the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) in this regard. The Expenditure Committee's inquiry into the Australian National Railways Commission was initiated because of concern at the large appropriations made by Parliament to offset the Commission's annual losses. The Commission has been directed by Government to eliminate those losses by 1987-88 but, even if this goal is achieved, it will have accumulated losses of over $500m by that time.

Australian National is a wholly owned public undertaking which is subject to pressures and directives from both the market and the Government. It must also operate in accordance with the terms and conditions of the agreements associated with the Commonwealth takeover of the South Australian and Tasmanian railways. The result is a complex web of interactions which give rise to conflicting objectives for Australian National's management. As the inquiry progressed, the Committee developed the following theme which it believes unlocks this interrelationship. Australian National's commercial objective must predominate and therefore the scale and range of operations of Australian National should be determined by customer preferences for its services, subject only to explicit Government directives in the form of Public Service obligations, including the obligations embodied in the transfer agreements.

The recommendations of our report are designed to overcome constraints which inhibit the decision-making ability of Australian National's management. Some of these constraints, such as the corporate planning deficiencies identified in our report, are internal to Australian National and should be remedied by its management. Others, such as operational, legislative and financial constraints require changes which Australian National alone cannot induce. These include difficulties with inter-system arrangements and numerous legislative restraints which inhibit Australian National's performance. The Committee believes it should be the catalyst in overcoming these restraints and has recommended appropriate changes to the Act. The Committee has cautioned against an assessment of management performance on the basis of existing operating losses as presently defined in Australian National's accounts. We have recommended a number of changes to Australian National's reporting processes which will improve both the usefulness of the financial accounts as a measure of management 's performance and the organisation's accountability to the Parliament.

Ultimately Government must make decisions about public business undertakings such as Australian National. One particular view is that they can be direct and closely supervised instruments of government which provide in many cases uneconomic services which are financed by cross-subsidisation and/or claims on the Budget. Alternatively, they can operate at arm's length in the market-place and be reimbursed by Government for those uneconomic services which the Government specifically requires. Having fully examined the issue, the Committee is of the view that the latter option represents the better course. I wish to thank our specialist adviser, Professor H. M. Kolsen, or Ted Kolsen as he is better known, for the contribution that he made both in the inquiry and in the report stage. Special appreciation is extended to Malcolm Aldons, the secretary of the Expenditure Committee and also to Adrian Scott, our assistant secretary, who had to pick up the inquiry at a late stage and see it through to the end. This he did admirably. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian National Railways Commission has the major part of its operations in South Australia. This report, which aims to assist in improving the performance and accountability of Australian National, is therefore, of enormous importance to South Australia. As the only member from that State on the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I have had to ensure that South Australia's views were taken into account. I thank the Committee members and the secretariat for their forbearance and their final acceptance of those interests. Australian National operates the South Australian non-metropolitan rail service. It therefore operates the State's major rail links to Melbourne, Sydney, Perth and Alice Springs. It also services country areas and the provision of those services is a significant and continuing concern of mine and, indeed, of the other South Australian Liberal member who represents a country electorate, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles).

SPEECH.PARA: Ever since the South Australian country railway was sold by the previous State Labor Government during the time of the previous Federal Labor Government, Australian National Railways has endeavoured to reduce its deficit by a more efficient use of its resources. The report of the Expenditure Committee reviews the progress made by AN towards this end and, more importantly, this report looks at how AN can better meet its major objective of efficiency and profitability whilst also meeting some clear obligations to the public. The Committee believes, and I quote from the report:

AN's commercial objective must predominate and therefore the scale and range of operations of AN should be determined by customer preferences for its services subject only to explicit government directives in the form of public service obligations (PSOs), including the obligations embodied in the Transfer Agreements.

I want to deal with those two restrictions on the pursuit of AN's commercial objectives because they are extremely important to South Australia and indeed to my electorate. A Public Service obligation as defined by the report is an obligation:

Which AN, if considering its own commercial interests, would not assume either at all or to the same extent or under the same conditions. Two necessary conditions must both be met, before any obligation can be treated as a PSO. The obligation must be accepted by government as fulfilling an undertaking incurred by government either:
(a) because, in the current government's opinion, it is in the public interest to do so; or

(b) because it is a consequence of previous government obligations (eg. the Transfer Agreements) and the costs of its provision will exceed its revenues when the service is provided as efficiently as possible.

Let me explain a Public Service obligation in practical terms. Australian National, in an effort to reduce its deficit, has curtailed or closed many unprofitable lines, services and sidings, whilst increasing the services, et cetera, on the more profitable lines. This course of action has led to a number of problems. A major problem arises where there is a conflict between efficiency and profitability on the one hand and the need for some form of transport to service country areas on the other hand. Where curtailment of services has been threatened, my role has been to protect the interests of my constituents and to ensure that adequate transport services continue to be provided, especially to remote country centres. In my view it is not responsible of the Government to cease the operation of a service in country areas without satisfying itself that some suitable alternative is available. To date the railways have been meeting an obligation in the provision of passenger and/or freight transport services. Therefore, if those services are to be withdrawn I believe we have a duty to ensure that alternative arrangements are made, and those alternative services do not necessarily have to be provided by public transport.

Let me emphasise the point: In the last financial year 34 sidings were completely closed because the volume of traffic did not, in AN's view, warrant their retention. In these cases we either have been able to ensure that reasonable and suitable alternatives were available, or have been satisfied that there has been no demand for the service. However, the Expenditure Committee was of the view that there may be occasions when, for one reason or another, the Government may wish Australian National to operate a service which it would otherwise discontinue. In these circumstances, such a service would be a public service obligation and separately funded.

The other restriction on AN's pursuit of its commercial objective are the Transfer Agreements. Again as I shall explain, this is enormously important to South Australia. South Australia's ability to attract industry to the State relies on a number of factors. Among these are our geographic position and the availability and lower comparative cost of many basic inputs such as land, power and labour. However, we are also reliant on transport to our markets, both in the eastern States and to our north and west. Given that Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia have their own railway systems, if Australian National, under Commonwealth control, were the only railway to follow a purely commercial objective while the other State government railways did not do so, South Australia could be seriously disadvantaged, particularly in relation to its manufacturing industry, compared with the eastern States. Therefore, it is of particular significance that the Expenditure Committee has recognised the obligations embodied in the Railways Transfer Agreement with South Australia. I want to refer to just one part of that agreement. Clause 8 of the Schedule to the Railways Agreement Act states:

The Commission will ensure that, in general, fares, freight rates and other charges in respect of the non-metropolitan railways and services shall be maintained, on and after the commencement date, at levels not less favourable to users than those levels generally applying on the railways of States other than South Australia and where, in general, fares, freight rates and other charges at the commencement date have established a relative advantage to the users, that advantage shall not be diminished.

Clearly, that clause aims to protect South Australia's relative position in relation to railway rates and charges. It was therefore important, in my view, for the Committee to recognise the agreement, as it ensures that the State of South Australia will not be disadvantaged by this report. In fact the report, subject to those critical provisos, will assist AN to provide a more efficient and effective transport system, one which will be of great benefit to both the users of that system in my State and the whole of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure in expressing the appreciation of Opposition members of the Committee to the Secretary, Mr Malcolm Aldons, the Assistant Secretary, Mr Adrian Scott-he joined us fairly late in the inquiry-and the adviser to the Committee, Professor Kolsen of Queensland University, for the valuable and long service which they provided. The recommendation of the Committee that the Australian National Railways Commission-or Australian National, as it prefers to be known-should be more commercially oriented and that public service or community service obligations should be identified and kept separate from commercial goals is in our view a wise one. The public service or community service obligations should be quickly identified by AN management and separately funded by government.

SPEECH.PARA: Another recommendation is that Australian National should seek to recover the total resource costs of providing its commercial services over a reasonable period in which planned approaches can be implemented without dislocation of services or hardship to communities or employees.

I expressed to the Committee the personal view that I did not accept that deficit elimination could be achieved by 1987-88. I do not believe that that target, or deadline, is based upon evidence; in fact, the deadline was selected prior to the 1977 election, on grounds of political expediency rather than on the results of a sound analysis of how and when Australian National could achieve deficit elimination-that is, apart from the provision of public service obligations-without unduly disrupting the transport network, work force and communities. It is interesting that recently the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation or ARRDO as it is known, in its 1981 report on railways said that in its assessment Australian National would still have a $25m deficit in 1989-90, even assuming significant but attainable rises in real freight rates , passenger fares and labour productivity.

The Opposition believes that, in considering total resource costs, environmental and social costs must also be considered. As a corollary of this, when service reductions are planned, total resource, environmental and social benefits forgone should be compared with total costs saved. One cannot consider the commercial aspects of the provision of rail services in isolation. One must take into account the total resource cost, the environmental and social costs and the impact of service reductions. This general or umbrella-type of approach to the impact of changes on transport services is what economists have chosen to call a 'social cost-benefit analysis'. Since most of the environmental and social costs and benefits are outside normal market considerations, public service or community service obligations will need to be used to incorporate those factors.

Again the ARRDO report states that deficit elimination in Australian National, in isolation from any attempt to implement cost recovery on long distance road transport may, from a resource allocation perspective, result in a worse allocation of resources than presently applies. The reason is that AN's costs, and thus freight and passenger rates, will rise, but long distance road rates will continue to be held artificially low. Thus, ARRDO believes that Australian National should not be considered in isolation from the rest of the transport system but rather as part of a nationally integrated transport network. Only in that manner will we as a nation, be able to achieve maximum efficiency in the use of our national resources.
The General Manager of the Australian National Railways Commission, Mr Don Williams, in a recent speech summarised the position succinctly when he said:
Economic efficiency is achieved when there is both technical efficiency-each mode performing its task at the lowest cost; and allocative efficiency-each mode performing the right task.
The achievement of economic efficiency by means of pricing which properly reflects total costs. . . .
He went on to state:
If road-
That is, road services-
paid full tote odds for its track-
In this case, the road-
the escalation in road prices would force sufficient business onto rail to allow us to contain cost escalations to a very significant degree.

The point he makes is that if the road industry made the proper contribution to national and State revenues to meet the costs generated by its utilisation of road pavements and services, road prices would have to rise to such an extent that it would be better for many industries to use rail rather than road. Similarly, the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation argues that cost recovery for long distance heavy road vehicles covers nowhere near its attributable road costs. On its calculations cost recovery on pavement costs would increase road costs by about 15 per cent. In regard to the railways across Australia-not just ANR but because ANR is locked into the Australian system we have to consider what is involved in each of the State systems that are supplemented-ARRDO has found that railways fail to meet the avoidable costs on less than container loads, the broken container lots, where consolidation is necessary, and importantly, on livestock traffics. ARRDO states:

In competitive markets such as this, it is unreasonable for any mode of transport to take unilateral action to increase prices to improve its cost recovery performance, since if all other factors remain the same then that mode of transport will lose business . . .

We cannot pluck out one mode of transport, force it to bear full cost recovery or to operate on a commercial basis to the exclusion of what is happening in the other modes of transport without decimating in some cases the mode of transport- in this case, railways-that we are seeking to place on a commercial basis. The ARRDO report continues:

Only a policy which requires or encourages joint action by competing modes will make possible improved cost recovery in transport. This implies a strong commitment by governments to improved cost recovery both as a financial goal and as a means of improving economic resource allocation in transport.

It would be grossly unfair to Australian National, as well as inappropriate national policy, to focus on Australian National in isolation from equal cost recovery policies on road, and indeed all, transport.

I turn now for a moment to the investment side of Australian National and our railway systems generally. Part of the commercial approach to Australian National's future must be the upgrading and rehabilitation of the rail network. The Government cannot simply give a directive to Australian National to become commercial, or more commercial, without regard for infrastructure endowment compared with road transport. If one compares government or public investment in road construction and maintenance with that for rail, one can see the enormous disparity in favour of road services. So if we require rail to improve its efficiency, it has to have similar investment in infrastructure. Again I refer to the Australian Railway Research Development Organisation, which can supply the best figures on this matter. Its calculations on warranted rail main line investments-similar to the Bureau of Transport Economics' calculations for warranted road investments-show that an additional investment of $43m annually is commercially justified at current real borrowing rates and if future investment levels are not increased by this $43m annually opportunities for a reduction in deficit by Australian National and other State railway systems will be forgone.

An important repercussion of the situation is that the road network, partially funded by Commonwealth non-repayable grants, far outstrips the rail network. Commonwealth rail main line assistance is repayable with interest. On the one hand road services receive non-repayable grant assistance and on the other hand, in respect of railways, loans are made to the Australian National Railways Commission or to the States on a repayable and interest-bearing basis. One result of such a distortion is that it limits the capacity of rail compared to road to develop infrastructure in the competitive main line freight area.

The Committee in its report points out that the Australian National management should behave commercially; it should search out new profitable areas of work to raise revenue as a means of increasing profitability. It has been found in other rail systems that cost cutting places severe limitations on the possibility for deficit reduction-this has been the experience over recent years-and that the dislocation it causes and the understandable reaction of work forces in protecting their jobs provide many counteracting forces to the often simplistic and academic notions of service cutbacks; the simplistic notion that if we cut back on rail services we cut back on deficit. The experience has been that these types of cutbacks, which ignore the human element and the inherent inflexibility of railway systems, have not been the success originally anticipated. It has to be accepted that there must be rationalisation but this ought to be done within a planned and participative environment which includes service expansions where appropriate. This entails on the part of the railway management, on the part of Australian National, aggressive marketing.

The point I made earlier regarding investment is crucial when we require a railway system to be more commercial. A commercial approach requires investment in potential growth areas. I do not assume that passenger tasks are almost totally non-commercial. It is up to rail management to be innovative, to accept risks in passenger and all rail services and to provide modern services that are convenient, reliable and speedy, that will attract passengers and freight back to rail services and that will yield a surplus to the operator. The Commonwealth should do a lot more than set Australian National an arbitrary deadline for deficit elimination and some deregulation. It must aid the rehabilitation of the system by providing capital where it is shown to be needed for profitability.

It is clear that the Government's arbitrary requirement that AN become profitable in 1978-88 may lead to most passenger oriented and small and medium- scale freight services being cut as they cannot be justified on a commercial basis; that is, unless those services are determined by the Government and by the Commission to be public service or community service obligations. If cost recovery mechanisms for the alternative road improvement and road services required to replace rail services are also taken into account, and if the rail services are placed on an equal footing with road services, Government funds currently expended on financing rail deficits could then be diverted-once we have improved the profitability of rail services-to the profitable areas of bulk mineral carriage and main line general freight.

The Committee's report points out the necessity for appropriate organisation- management information systems, personnel and skills-to fulfil AN's commercial tasks. It is important that Australian National and other publicly owned transport undertakings be modernised and rationalised to enable them to increase efficiency. Bureaucratic structures should be minimised and a more flexible organisation established. Personnel with appropriate skills should be employed. If possible, existing employees should be retained and backed up by the necessary administrative systems. Especially important to this progress are clear Government guidelines within which Australian National will have expanded commercial freedom, explicit and realistic objectives for it to attain, appropriate structure, personnel, skills and administrative systems, retraining and educational facilities, an improved industrial relations environment and expanded, meaningful employee participation in decisions affecting their working lives.

The last matter I want to refer to is the exercise of tendering by AN for works to be carried out within the Australian National Railways Commission system. The Committee had before it representatives of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, who asserted that Australian National had unfair advantage over private contractors when tendering for Australian National construction works. They put to the Committee a similar case to that which they put in respect of national road construction; that is, because they are private enterprise operators, because they employ contract labour, they can do the job cheaper-in a number of cases it was asserted at least 30 per cent cheaper-than a public authority, in this case Australian National. As in the case of roads, I want to reiterate and emphasise that there is absolutely no proof of this-for road or rail. In effect, what is happening is that the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, which is dependent on government or the public sector for about 70 per cent of its total work, in the face of a situation where public sector capital expenditure is contracting, is seeking to have diverted by a sycophantic government works normally carried out by public authorities. It is doing so without regard to the impact upon the level of efficiency of those authorities that would follow a diversion of publicly funded and public authority works to the private sector.

In effect what we see is a featherbedding of the private sector in the name of efficiency. This is a fallacy; there is no proof and there is no evidence. On the other hand, AN, which is a public authority, while able to participate in consultancy work abroad to a limited extent, is unable to use its resources to participate in tenders or to seek work in the private sector. We maintain strongly, and I think the Committee's decision can reasonably be interpreted in this way, that AN is able to continue to tender for its own construction works and development projects. I believe that function is in the interests of the Commission. The alternative is that the resources and employees of the Commission would be kept idle so that construction or maintenance works could be carried out by large and wealthy private contractors. That is the featherbedding to which I referred earlier. Such an arrangement is not in the interests of the taxpayers. It is a squandering of taxpayers' resources to prop up wealthy companies that are going through a period of financial stringency and market contraction.

The recommendations of the Committee were reached after a great deal of discussion and a great deal of input from members of the Committee, and particularly its staff. The subject examined is a very important one. It is a central part of our railway system in this country. I hope that the Government, in the time before it, will pick up the recommendations in a constructive fashion and that at a later stage the Minister for Transport will come back to us with a report on the Government's response to each of the recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-First of all I would like to comment on the remarks of the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). Rather ungenerously, when speaking about the country electorates of South Australia, he referred only to Barker and Wakefield, which is held by Mr Giles. Those electorates represent 9 per cent of the State. I thought he should have been a bit more generous and also thrown in the electorate of Grey which represents 90 per cent of the State. My electorate of Grey also has railway problems which in many cases are similar to those to which the honourable member referred. Whilst I have not had a chance to read fully the report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I would like to comment on some of the anomalies that I have faced in the hope that they have been covered in the report and are the subject of recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: When one of the Expenditure committees examined last year's Budget allocation for the Department of Transport I made inquiries regarding the method of booking on Australian National because it was quite obvious that the system was grossly inefficient. The figures given to me later by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) on the percentage of berth occupancy on both the Transcontinental and the Indian Pacific were shocking. I know that around the middle of the year is not the most popular time to travel. However, the figure for June got down as low as 24 per cent west bound and 34 per cent east bound on the Transcontinental. Even for February we find a berth occupancy of 42 per cent one way and 38 per cent the other way on the Transcontinental. Staff members have informed me that on many occasions people who tried to get on the trains were told that there were no vacancies, that no berths were available. Yet those trains were travelling half empty. It is quite obvious that the booking system was in a shocking state. We have been told that the railways are trying to establish a computerised booking system to overcome this problem. I would hope-as I said, I have not had a chance to read the report-that the Standing Committee on Expenditure has considered this matter and made recommendations to try to overcome this position .

Something was said earlier about public service obligations. I would also like to say something about the social responsibility of a railway system. It is quite obvious that pressure is being put on AN at present to break financially even by 1987. This means that the railway will try to cut out everything on which it is not making a profit and that some of the social responsibilities which have been carried out by the railway in the past will be put to one side.

I would like to refer to one function of the railway which, while not affecting a great number of people, affects people in the more outlying areas of South Australia, and particularly those between the South Australian border and Kalgoorlie. I refer to the historic tea and sugar train which was organised just after the commencement of the construction of the east-west railway line. The main function of this train was to supply provisions for railway staff such as people working on railway gangs along the east-west railway line. Following improvements to the railway system-the re-laying of the track with all welded rails and concrete sleepers-the railway has been able to cut out quite a number of maintenance gangs. I am informed that up to date 14 maintenance gangs have been removed from the east-west railway line between Port Augusta and Kalgoorlie . It is anticipated that in a few years, after the conversion is completed, the number of stops between Port Augusta and Kalgoorlie will be reduced to seven.

The tea and sugar train not only serviced railway people but also enabled people on the cattle and sheep stations-people in any sphere of life-to obtain provisions. Now, because of a reduction in the number of maintenance gangs the number of stops has been reduced. This means that a lot of people will have to get provisions in other ways. Approaches have been made to the Minister and to the railway. The railway has said that it will stop the train to allow people to get their provisions but at a cost. I think the cost in one place that was mentioned was $20 per customer. This is one area where the concept of social responsibility needs to be considered.
Section 44 of the Australian National Railways Commission Act states:

The Minister may direct the Commission to make any alteration in any existing practice or carry out any system or matter of policy, but where any such direction adversely affects the accounts of the railways, the Commission shall notify the Minister thereof from time to time, and the amount of any loss occasioned by the direction shall, if certified by the Auditor-General, be provided by Parliament in the annual Appropriation Act and paid to the Commission.

In terms of social responsibility, some consideration should be given to people who live in isolated areas. These people as a general rule would support the Government. I suggest that any loss incurred by Australian National as a result of allowing the train to stop could be reimbursed to it.

The honourable member for Barker mentioned the closing of country railway lines . In my electorate two such lines are affected. These lines were considered unprofitable. They had reached the stage where maintenance costs were very high. However, if they had been in first class condition they could have carried on. The lines had been allowed to deteriorate over a number of years. As a result the cost of upgrading the lines was not a viable proposition when Australian National took them over. When we talk about closing country railway lines I wonder whether we ever take into account the other costs which result. I am not talking about costs for Australian National but costs which State governments have to bear as a result of having to upgrade roads. When we look at these things all the factors have to be taken into account. If we close a railway line because we consider it is unprofitable it could mean that grain, for example, has to be carried by heavy trucks. As a result the roads on which the trucks travel will not last a great time and will have to be upgraded. Therefore, overall, is anything going to be saved by society? Here again I think we could refer to section 44 of the Act.

I wish to refer to one other matter. Again, I hope that the Committee has given consideration to it. One of the greatest decentralised industries in any country is its railway system. The same applies in Australia. I appreciate that the word 'decentralisation' is a much abused word. Whilst a lot of people talk about it very few people do anything to put it into effect. Since the amalgamation of the South Australian Railways and the old Commonwealth Railways, we have seen greater centralisation of railway activities in Adelaide, with the result that traditional country centres, such as Port Pirie, Port Augusta and Peterborough, have been downgraded. It has been said that some of those centres could become whistle stops in the future. It is quite obvious to me as a resident of Port Augusta, a very important railway town, that the number of railway activities that have been moved out of that city to Adelaide is considerable. This does not bode well for the future.

There has been a continual reduction in staff employed by the railways. Despite the promises which have been given by railway officials to councils and groups of employees in the area that reduction in staff continues. This will certainly downgrade the activities in those towns and cities. According to the report, there has been a further reduction in the number of staff of Australian National of between 400 and 500 in the last 12 months. When one sees the advertisements for staff it does appear that the number of wages staff is going down but that the number of managerial and administrative staff is on the up. So the situation could be getting a bit out of balance. There has been a cutback in the number of apprentices being taken on by Australian National. The railways did promise the Port Augusta council in the northern area where the main workshops are situated, it would put on 40 apprentices this year but it finished up that only 27 lads were taken on. The excuse was given that lads had taken other positions elsewhere. In the past the practice has been that when a lad applied for an apprenticeship he would also apply to Telecom Australia, the Electricity Trust of South Australia, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in Whyalla, the Army, you name it. Often a lad would win one of the railway positions but, if he took one of the others which was offered, another lad would step up and take his place. Apparently that has not taken place this year. I have taken up the matter with the Minister. He has agreed to refer it to Mr Marks, the Chairman of the Commission to see whether this problem can be overcome.

I conclude by saying that I do feel that the pressure which has been put on Australian National at present certainly places it in a position where it has had to ignore completely any social responsibility. I feel that if railways are to play their proper part in Australian society they must be allowed to accept that social responsibility with the full backing of the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 March, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the interruption of this debate last evening I was commenting on the revenue shortfalls in the health administration in the Northern Territory. In the first submission to the Commonwealth by the Northern Territory Government in December last year the clear decline in hospital utilisation and its consequent effect on revenue was clearly demonstrated. In the five months since 1 December 1981 occupied bed days decreased by 20 per cent. Out-patient services showed a downturn of 46 per cent after three months compared with the 33.3 per cent downturn estimated by the Commonwealth. After five months' operation out-patient utilisation decreased by a further 8 per cent to some 54 per cent. Full bed day costs were increased as well on 1 September 1981 from an average of $98 per day to $189 per day. This represents an increase of 133 per cent. As a result, the nominal charges raised show a potential revenue in the vicinity of 46 per cent higher than the actual $ 500,000 which was estimated by the Commonwealth. However, the actual payment of accounts for revenue cases eligible for compensation is usually received between one year and four years after charging. In fact, it is more likely to be four years in the case of larger claims. On current trends the $500,000 estimated by the Commonwealth cannot be achieved and a shortfall of $0.33m is indicated.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned before, out-patient services have felt a severe downturn. After five months' operation it is apparent that revenue at 30 June 1982 will be in the vicinity of $918,000, a $282,000 shortfall from the Commonwealth target of $ 1.2m and 5.4 per cent lower than the $970,000 forecast after three months. In- patient bed days have declined by 20 per cent over the previous year, but out of this Aboriginal bed days have increased from 43 per cent of total bed days at the end of November to 45 per cent after five months' operation. It is still less, though, than the 50 per cent recorded in 1980-81.

Bed days attributable to patients holding health care cards have increased from 44 per cent after three months to 51 per cent after five months. By November 1981 total additional charges raised as a result of the new arrangements represent only 50 per cent of the Commonwealth assessed revenue of $4.8m. Furthermore, with the increased use of health care cards additional charges represent only 41 per cent of the Commonwealth target of $5.25m. So with the reduction of use of in-patient treatment and the increase in the number of disadvantaged patients, the collection of every debt within the financial year would leave a deficit of $3.09m from a target of $5.25m for in-patient services. As honourable members will understand by these trends, the Northern Territory Government has been badly placed under the health funding arrangements by a mis- calculation by the Commonwealth in the amount of revenue the Territory could raise from its hospitals.
