SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill under consideration today to amend the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act permits the Commonwealth to extend to the three most populous States an allocation of $69m in return for their willingness last year not to press the Commonwealth for immediate implementation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission report on tax sharing. This Bill should bring back fond memories for the Treasurer (Mr Howard) for it is the $69m that the Commonwealth was prepared to allocate to the States in May last year, but which was concealed from the Premiers and then boasted about when the Premiers failed to demand it. We then witnessed a truly Dickensian performance from the Treasurer and his fellow culprits as they gave excellent impersonations of Uriah Heep in performing their mea culpas.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially this legislation marks time. It awaits the result of the Grants Commission review of its own report which is to be announced in May. This Bill provides us with what is probably a final opportunity for critical comment on the Grants Commission formula for tax sharing arrangements. From a Western Australian point of view, we are marking time under a Sword of Damocles. The arrangements have trimmed considerable amounts off our financial assistance from the Commonwealth and the review could trim up to $160m more.

Today I want to look at the historical background to this Bill, and the Act which it seeks to amend, in order to demonstrate the extent to which a deceit has been practiced on the citizens of this country by this Government and various conservative State governments, particularly that in Queensland, which is a substantial gainer from this Bill, and that in Western Australia, which is a substantial loser from the whole process. The tax sharing formula is unrelated to the size of the aggregate allocations to the States but some mention of the aggregate allocation is necessary here. When the Whitlam Government was in office it was the object of the most vicious attacks by the Premiers of Western Australia and Queensland as well as the federal coalition then in Opposition for its alleged centralist tendencies. The concept of new federalism was brought forward by the Federal and State Tories and became a centrepiece of Liberal ideology. It was argued that, in particular, specific purpose grants should be phased out and that functions which are essentially dual Commonwealth and State responsibilities under our Constitution should largely be returned to the States . Their responsibilities for those functions were to be exercised by their own power to dispense general revenue grants received from the Commonwealth as they saw fit.

There was the implication in this new focal point of Liberal Party ideology that the States would have available to them much the same revenue that had been available via specific and general purpose grants in the past. This would be possible because firstly, either the Commonwealth would increase general purpose grants by the amount of the reduction in specific purpose grants and/or secondly , the Commonwealth would vacate a proportion of the taxation field to permit the States to re-enter the field with new taxes, raising the revenue directly themselves. Of course neither of these conditions has been fulfilled. It was never intended that they should be. It was a major confidence trick played, to some degree, on some of the State governments and upon the Australian population as a whole.

The decline of the States' share of total Commonwealth tax receipts has been quite dramatic since the implementation of the new federalism policy. In the last Whitlam Budget the amount of money granted by the Commonwealth to the States in either specific or general purpose grants was 50.8 per cent of the Commonwealth tax receipts. In the last Budget of this Government it was 39.8 per cent. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth has not vacated the tax field. It has become even more obtrusive, abandoning indexation of income tax rates and entering new fields of sales tax or increasing its take from old fields. Only in the field of tax on business has there been a decline in the Commonwealth's take since this Government assumed office. The area of tax on business is not really one that is open to the States to enter readily, at least not on an equitable basis as in some States there will be a far greater capacity to raise funds from businesses than there will be in other areas. It is not an area of the tax field which the States can enter and hope thereby to achieve an equitable-in interstate terms-distribution of taxes from that source.

What States' rights have come to mean to the Tories is loading responsibilities for cuts in services on to the States, the losers being Australian citizens who really could not care less about Liberal ideological arguments but would rather like to have their money efficiently expended and be given honest explanations about the purpose of shifting funding arrangements. However the Australian people must pay more attention to the ideological tribal dances of the Liberal and National Country Parties because the outcomes of those dances have an impact upon them. What the collective efforts of the Western Australian and Federal Liberal-National Country Party governments have produced between them for the people of my home State, with the impact of new federalism ideology, has been the breach of an historic compromise on which our association with the Commonwealth was founded. Western Australia traded its right to erect protective fences around its economy in relation to the eastern States and its choice to impose or remove barriers on its international trade in return for the status of a claimant State. What we lost in our hampered development thereby was to be regained in direct Commonwealth assistance. That assistance was important in the 1920s, 1930s, 1940s and 1950s in establishing a number of manufacturing or secondary processing industries in our State. At a time when we found it extremely difficult to encourage private investments in key employment industries in our State the funds that accrued to Western Australia as a result of its claimant status were expended on the establishment of things such as the State timber mills and a number of other State industries. Those funds enabled us to develop those industries when we could quite easily have found ourselves with no industrial development at all because we permitted, effectively, a state of free trade to exist between Western Australia and the eastern States as a result of the terms of federation.

When the Government argues that Western Australia's revenue raising potential is great it ought to reflect on two things. Firstly, under the new Grants Commission formulas, revenues from mineral levies are to be wholly or partially discounted against Commonwealth financial assistance. So our capacity to raise revenue via levies on mineral companies will be offset by consequent reductions in Commonwealth funds. Therefore in reality it is no advantage unless we take extraordinary measures in the judgment of the Grants Commission over and above normal levels in taxing those mineral companies ourselves. Clearly, our capacity to do that will be limited by a whole variety of factors that will be largely beyond the economic control of the State Government. Secondly, we still are massively disadvantaged by eastern States' tariff subsidies. The most recent figures I have been able to find are from an Industries Assistance Commission paper, published in 1980, entitled 'Approaches to a General Reduction in Tariffs Information Paper No. 1'. The figures are for 1977-78 but they remain representative today. If the tariff had been eliminated and replaced by a government subsidy the required distribution to industries in the various States would have been New South Wales, $1,465m; Victoria, $1,635m; Queensland, $265m; South Australia, $375m; Western Australia, $176m and Tasmania $87m. That would have amounted to an explicit massive transfer of resources from Western Australian taxpayers to the east if, as I said, the tariff had been eliminated notionally and, instead, subsidies provided to particular industries out of Commonwealth revenues. The tariff, as it is, indicates the existence of a massive transfer of resources from Western Australian consumers to the east.

We may also consider the hidden subsidy in Australian internal trade. When we entered the Federation, as I have said, we waived the right to erect tariff barriers against the eastern States. There is a trade imbalance now between ourselves and the eastern States of the order of 10 to one. Western Australia's poverty may have been alleviated since the time it first became a claimant State but that was not historically the only question of equity involved in the entry of Western Australia into the Federation. Another question of equity involved was our capacity to develop ourselves internally and that, as I have suggested, continues to be seriously damaged by the nature of commercial relationships in this country.

The Grants Commission report on tax sharing arrangements has been exceptionally hard on Western Australia. If it were to proceed unaltered in the review of May this year it would produce a revenue loss of $160m next year to the Western Australian budget. The Fraser-O'Connor Liberal new federalism therefore would require a 12 per cent increase in the amount of income tax paid by the State's population to make up this shortfall were the O'Connor Liberal Government to fulfil indications by its Court predecessor that a State tax would be introduced . The report tabled last year has many inadequacies. In numerous places it admits inadequacies in data collected. Only 15 centres were visited in Western Australia by the members of the Grants Commission. The commissioners stated:
Several areas of interest were overflown at low altitude.

I am afraid that that is not a substitute for landing and talking. It might be useful in mapping techniques if the commissioners wished to engage in a little mapping in the Western Australian outback. It may be useful in spotting herds of cattle but it will tell us very little about the nature of the needs of Western Australia. I hope that in future when the commissioners fly over the backblocks of Western Australia they will lower their altitude even further, apply the brakes and hop out and have a chat. Nevertheless, this ought to have alerted the commissioners to particular Western Australian distance problems. Whilst the Commission took into account the differences in degree and pattern of dispersal of the State's population it made inadequate allowances for costs arising from distance factors, both interstate and intrastate. There was no attempt to take account of costs of equalising the range and standard of services throughout Western Australia.

Another area of deficiency was the failure of the Commission to include in its assessment all the considerations of expenditure needs it was entitled to include. It was given a legal opinion from the Attorney-General which said that assessment of services should include 'any body which is controlled by the State Government or by any other State statutory authority'. The Commission, however, decided to exclude from its consideration these services: Ports and harbours, electricity and gas, metropolitan water supply, sewerage and drainage, and housing. Its rationale, that these undertakings do not regularly result in a net cost to Consolidated Revenue in all or most of the States, flies in the face of the Attorney-General's legal opinion. Western Australia is particularly disadvantaged by this decision. These services are all extraordinarily costly to Western Australians. They are getting more expensive as charges on them paid by the Western Australian consumers subsidise the interest on infrastructure borrowings for new mineral developments.

Geography adds to our costs. For example, power costs are higher because we lack cheap, dispersed coal deposits, and great distances are involved in power transmission. Supplies of natural gas from the North West Shelf are plentiful but will have to pass along an extraordinarily lengthy pipeline to go from the North West Shelf to the industrial south-west. Another problem with the way in which the Commission has assessed needs is that it has failed to take account of the future development of the States and, in terms of tax sharing entitlement, has locked each State into its past expenditure patterns.

Inadequate planning for regional development by successive Tory governments in Western Australia has resulted in expenditure needs being based on Western Australia remaining the most centralised State. Queensland, on the other hand, which is a major beneficiary of this amending legislation, has encouraged decentralisation thereby creating established needs. In terms of the Commission' s analysis, a need does not exist unless it is an established need and one which has involved past expenditure commitments. I hope that when the commissioners undertake their review to restructure their formula they will do at least several things for Western Australia. I hope, firstly, that their assessment of needs will not be based solely on past needs but that on the question of decentralisation, for example, they will make an assessment of the potential and requirement of the State to decentralise and include that in their judgment. Secondly, I hope that the commissioners will include in their review all the States' services that the Attorney-General said they could include and make a judgment in relation to needs on the basis of an assessment of equity in each State's performance in those various statutory authorities I mentioned. Thirdly, on the question of decentralisation, I hope that the commissioners will pay particular attention to the very extreme difficulties experienced by outback Western Australia and to the fact that even greater distances are covered in Western Australia than in any other State including Queensland.

The Grants Commission report has merely capped an appalling record of lack of direction in federal and Western Australian Liberal thinking on the State's economy. It was a point of Liberal pride which withdrew Western Australia prematurely from the Grants Commission's claimant status in 1967-68. It was an immature, ideological whim that so readily accepted the altered basis of financial assistance assessments in 1976. Even though the State and Federal Liberals knew that the formula then devised would in the long run kick the bottom out of Western Australia's finances, as the new formula was sustained only by a 4-year promise by the Commonwealth Government to permit assistance to a State not to fall below the value of a previous year's assistance, ideological blinkers caused them to persist.

Western Australia has been living on borrowed time since 1976, and this year the debt on that time has been called in. We lost $53m last year and experienced effectively only a 7 per cent increase in funds available during a period of 10 per cent inflation and when tax revenue to the Commonwealth-the Commonwealth is far from vacating the field, as I said before-from all sources increased by 16 per cent. It is quite evident from the tone of the Commonwealth's attitude on this Bill that the type of special grant it entails will not be readily forthcoming in the future. Western Australia cannot expect any reliable form of special assistance once the formula has been settled, as it had been promised it will be settled in May this year. That will be very much a red-letter month-I suspect even a dead-letter month-for Western Australians.

The ideological blinkers of the Federal and State Liberals also deprive the Western Australian population of the possibility of an intelligent trade-off between our tariff disadvantage and a formula which recognises Western Australia 's real difficulties. The free trade credentials of the State Liberals are suspect. Most recently the Premier of Western Australia was critical of the level of tariffs and the extent to which they disadvantage Western Australia. Yet he was a Minister in a government which in August 1980 criticised the Federal Government for its lack of decisiveness in rejecting the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission on lower tariffs for the clothing and footwear industries.

People such as the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) have been more consistent. However, his stand on tariffs, which will never gain the support of a Federal government, Labor or Liberal, has not included any consideration of a trade-off elsewhere in the economy or in financial policy. His philosophy does not contemplate the alternatives. The philosophical commitments of his colleagues in the State combine with sheer intellectual laziness to ensure that no serious initiative is taken. In other words, they set up the straw man of the tariff barrier in the full knowledge that if Western Australia is to remain in the Federation absolutely nothing can be done as the lobby of the eastern States on the question of tarrifs will always be far more significant and powerful than the Western Australian one. But they do not take the logical next step of using a legitimate source of complaint. They do no seek to offset that situation with a request for special assistance for Western Australia or, at the very least, a formula in the Grants Commission which takes into account Western Australia's developmental needs. We will never have that because the Liberals in Western Australia, Federal and State, are utterly incapable of the intellectual effort to make that leap. Those of them who are capable are more interested in their ideological stance than in the real needs of the people of the State.

Despite the fact that the tax sharing Act could eventually spell extraordinary damage to the Western Australian education system and State services, the State Liberal Party puffs up pipe dreams and volleys of inconsistent statements. We can only hope that they organise their minds in their last few months of grace and take some cognisance of the lesson they will learn from the State by- elections which will be held on Saturday when massive swings will be registered against them as punishment for their financial mismanagement.

I understand the concern expressed by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Tambling) on the funding of public hospitals in the Territory. He made a plea to the Government last night and again today on this problem. I feel I should make the position clear to the Northern Territory Administration and the House. PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, line 4, omit 'and'.
(2) Clause 3, page 2, lines 5 and 6, omit paragraph (b), substitute the following paragraphs:
'(b) by omitting sub-section (2) and substituting the following sub-section:

'(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1), the basic tax sharing grant, in relation to a State in respect of the year commencing on 1 July 1981, shall be an amount that is the product of $6,524,600,000 and the factor obtained by dividing the adjusted population figure in relation to that State in respect of that year by the total of the adjusted population figures in relation to all the States other than the Northern Territory in respect of that year.'; and
'(c) by omitting sub-paragraphs (3) (b) (v) and (vi) and substituting the following word and sub-paragraph:
'and (v) in the case of Tasmania-2.00188''.'.
(3) Clause 6, page 2, line 22, omit 'State', substitute 'States'.'.

The purpose of the amendments which have been circulated is to correct a technical fault in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill 1982. As the Amendment Bill now stands, the States' aggregate tax sharing grants vary from the figures settled at the June 1981 Premiers Conference to the extent that the Australian Statistician's determination of State and Northern Territory populations as at 31 December 1981 is different from the estimates that were used for the purposes in June 1981.

The proposed amendments overcome this problem by fixing the States' aggregate basic tax share at $6524.6m and providing for the addition of $165.1m on a basis also determined at the Premiers Conference. The amendments also simplify the description in the legislation for the calculation of the States' tax sharing grant. At the Premiers Conference on 20 June 1981 it was decided to pay the States an aggregate tax sharing grant of $6,689.7m in 1981-82. This amount was comprised of a basic tax sharing grant of $6,524.6m and certain other additions which total $165.1m and which, with the exception of the $9m once and for all granted to Queensland, are set out in Schedule 2 of the amendment Bill. It was further decided at the Conference that in distributing the basic tax sharing grant amongst the States, the existing States' per capita relativities would be used; that is, the distribution of the basic grant would be calculated on the basis of the population of each State as at 31 December 1981, weighted by the per capita relativities contained in section 8 of the principal Act, which in turn derive from the per capita relativities established by the financial assistance grants in 1975-76. The amendments retain the description of the basis of distributing the basic tax share amongst the States but remove the method of calculating the basic tax share. In doing so the amendments involve nothing other than simplifying a description and providing for the payment to the States an aggregate of the amount which was decided at the June 1981 Premiers Conference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about these amendments. Firstly the explanatory memorandum which was circulated with these amendments and which the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) has read to the chamber is a fairly unsatisfactory document for explaining exactly what these amendments do. It is particularly unsatisfactory for explaining why they are necessary. The second paragraph simply states:

SPEECH.PARA: As the Amendment Bill now stands, the States' aggregate tax sharing grants vary from the figures settled at the June 1981 Premiers Conference . . .

But it does not explain why that is so. It is not immediately obvious why that would be so. In talking about the difference in population figures as between the States and the Northern Territory for December 1981, in actuality as distinct from what the original assessment by the Australian Statistician would have been, it is not immediately clear, I suggest, why that would alter the States' aggregate tax sharing grant. After a lot of delving around one can find out why that is so, but it would surely not be beyond the realms of possibility for the Government to spell that out clearly so that people and the Parliament can understand what is being done and why before such debates come on, rather than leaving it to the Opposition to make those explanations.

It seems to me that it is worth while putting into English why these amendments are appropriate. Therefore, I put to the chamber what I understand to be happening at present. The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act-which I remind the Committee was opposed by the Opposition when it came before the Parliament in June of last year and to which I will refer later-determined a formula for calculating the aggregate tax sharing grants to the States and the Northern Territory and provided a formula also for dividing that aggregate grant between the States and the Northern Territory on an adjusted population basis. The Amendment Bill, which is the Bill now before the chamber, provided for a fixed grant to the Northern Territory of $315.1m, which was expected to be $6.5m more than the formula would have provided; that is, the formula for dividing up the aggregate grant between the States and the Northern Territory. However, this was only an estimate as to what the additional grant to the Northern Territory would have been over and above the formula, because it involved the Statistician making an assessment in June of last year-the time of the Premiers Conference-of the population of each State and the Northern Territory as at 31 December last year.

The Bill also made consequential adjustments to the original Act by seeking to remove reference to the Northern Territory in section 8 of the Act, which deals with tax sharing grants for the States in 1981-82. However, it is clear that the legislation did not make those changes satisfactorily because the determination of the payment for each State, not the Northern Territory still involved reference to the total amount to be paid to the States and the Northern Territory. If, under that formula, the Northern Territory entitlement was different from that originally estimated, the States' aggregate funds would be accordingly changed from what was originally agreed upon; which was the figure of $6,524.6m.

The amendments to the Bill, which are now before the Committee, are presumably to ensure that the States receive that agreed amount of $6,524.6m. The amendments to the Bill abandon reference to the formula for calculating the total grant to the States and the Northern Territory and just set the sum to be divided amongst the States and vary the formula for the division of that sum to exclude any mention of the Northern Territory.

I believe that explains the situation rather more adequately than the Minister did in his speech to this chamber on the amendments now before us. In not opposing these amendments the Opposition draws attention again to the change in the formula which was brought about by the original Act last year, following the Premiers Conference; surely one of the most notable and despicable Premiers Conferences of all time because of the actions of this Government in deceiving the States in a way which got every State Premier enormously upset. After that Premiers Conference the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) skited to the nation about the way in which they had deluded the States and kept from them 1 per cent which they would have been prepared to give them if they had been pushed hard enough. But, more importantly, at that Conference the Commonwealth imposed upon the States a change in the formula for the calculation of the total grant to the States from the previous tax-sharing arrangements to a basis on which last year's sum was increased eventually by only 9 per cent. In other words, there was a real reduction in the amount of funds that were made available to the States.

There are other reasons which one could go into but as we are in the Committee stage I will not pursue that matter any more. I do reiterate how important it is for the Government, when bringing forward complicated amendments, to spell out exactly what is being done and why it has to be done. Broad references to technical changes leave the Parliament in a position in which it is difficult to know what the Government is doing and it is left to the Opposition to explain exactly why the changes need to be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate I said that there were some aspects of the amendments proposed by the Government about which I was not very sure and about which I had some concern. I endorse the remarks that have just been made by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), in connection with the necessity for the Government to provide in explanatory memoranda sufficient detail to make it possible for honourable members to understand clearly what is intended by the amendments and the impact that they will have so that we do not have to spend, unnecessarily, hours of our time wading through the Act, the amending Bill, the formulas that are being applied and the proposals that are made in connection with any adjustments. To some extent my fears have been allayed but not entirely.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially I was concerned about the impact of proposed amendments to this amending Bill which, as the Minister has indicated, seeks to correct a technical fault in the Bill. It appears that the June 1981 Premiers Conference agreed to the aggregate tax-sharing grant of $6,689.7m for 1981-82. That aggregate grant was comprised of a basic grant of $6,524.6m and other additions totalling $165. 1m which included the $9m once and for all grant to Queensland, because of an adjustment in the population base part of the formula. It was suggested that the States agreed to the total amount of the grant rather than the basis upon which it was to be calculated. I am prepared to accept that suggestion. The specification of the actual amount rather than including the method by which that amount was calculated, and the explanations that have been given for that, satisfy me but I am still not completely satisfied about the reason why the $165 .1m less, if we wish, the $9m to Queensland has been deducted to reach the total as specified in the amendment, $6.524m instead of $6,689m.

I raise this question because it was agreed at the Premiers Conference that the aggregate tax-sharing entitlement of the States in any year after this current financial year will bear the same proportion to the previous years total tax receipts as the general revenue grant to the States during this current year bears to the total tax receipts for 1980-81, that is, 20.72 per cent. For the purpose of this calculation the additional $60m which this legislation provides to be granted to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland is to be included in the 1981-82 grant. I am concerned that this $60m now forms part of the $165.1m which has not been included in the amount stated in the amendments. I would like clarified the extent and the way in which, if at all, the deletion of that $165. 1m, which includes the $60m which the Commonwealth and the States had agreed would be included in this current year's allocation, will affect the grants to the States for 1982-83 and subsequent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position in respect of the $ 165.1m is that the amount of $156.1 is included in the tax base, the difference being the $9m which was the once and for all grant to Queensland.

Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 7 and 8 (1982).

The customs tariff proposals I have just tabled and which are being circulated relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals No. 7 ( 1982), which operate from tomorrow, introduce tariff changes arising from the Government's decisions on recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission in its reports on ginger and ginger products, cork and articles of cork and floor and wall coverings. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations on these goods except in regard to a section of the report on floor and wall coverings. The Government decided not to accept the Commission's recommendation that goods falling within tariff item 59.10, other than floor and wall coverings, be dutiable at minimum rates. Implementation of the Commission's recommendation would have created difficulties of identification. However, the spirit of the recommendation by the IAC will be achieved by allowing normal by- law criteria to apply.

In respect of ginger and ginger products, the effect of the decision is that: dry ginger will be assisted by a sliding scale duty of $0.60 per kilogram less 50 per cent of the value. Duty will be payable on imported dry ginger only where the price is less than $1.20 per kilogram.

This arrangement is designed to maintain stability by providing a buffer against an unexpected or drastic fall in world ginger prices. Gingerin will be dutiable at 10 per cent in line with the tariff assistance recently accorded other fragrances and essences. Other ginger and ginger products will be dutiable at 2 per cent. The IAC had concluded that the ginger industry is efficient and is well suited to the Australian economic environment. The above duty rates largely maintain the assistance the tariff currently provides.

In respect of cork and articles of cork the effect of the decision is that natural cork, mainly wine corks and agglomerated wine corks, will be dutiable at 2 per cent, which represents a decrease in the duty rate. The duty rate on floor or wall coverings made of agglomerated cork will be reduced from 26 per cent to 20 per cent after two years and the duty rate on gaskets and similar joints of cork will be reduced from 30 per cent on implementation to 20 per cent over two years except in regard to certain goods currently dutiable at 17 per cent which will become dutiable at 20 per cent immediately. The IAC's recommendations generally represent a lowering of the duty rates currently applying to the goods covered by this report. The phasing arrangements will allow local producers of these goods time to adjust to the new levels of assistance. The new rates will reduce duty disparities between different cork products and between cork and substitute products.

In respect of floor and wall coverings the effect of the decision is that laminated rigid sheets of artificial plastic materials and floor and wall coverings of materials other than artificial plastic will be dutiable at 20 per cent, foamed polyethylene wall coverings will be dutiable at 6 per cent and other floor and wall coverings of artificial plastic materials will be reduced to a rate of 20 per cent over two years. These rates are not expected to have any significant adverse economic, social or employment consequences.

Proposals No. 8, which operate from 1 April 1982, introduce a legal note to define 'printed' fabrics for the purposes of the customs tariff. This change was foreshadowed in my media release of 12 February 1982 concerning textiles, clothing and footwear. The legal note will ensure that only genuine printed cotton sheeting may be entered at the lower rates of duty prescribed for such goods and is consistent with the definition used in the by-laws which allow concessional admission of certain fabrics 'in the grey' that are subsequently printed in Australia. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and has been circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Tobacco Charge (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Tobacco Charge (No. 3) Amendment Bill as they are related measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate concerning these three measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —These three Bills are minor Bills but the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), in his second reading speech, was at pains to stress that there are quite a few matters in them which need to be discussed. The Opposition does not oppose the measures. The industry, at both the growing and the processing level, agrees with them. The purpose of this Bill to amend the Tobacco Charge Act (No. 1) 1955 is to increase the rate of charge payable on sales of Australian tobacco leaf on and after 1 March 1982 from 1.1c to 2.5c per kilogram. It also enables the rate of charge to be increased or decreased by regulation. Of course, these charges are paid by growers.

SPEECH.PARA: Linked with this Bill are the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 3) which apply the rate of charge set under this Bill for Australian tobacco leaf purchased by manufacturers or grown and used by manufacturers. At present the rate of charge paid by manufacturers is 2. 2c per kilogram. The principal Acts were introduced in 1955 and simply established rates of charge to be paid by industry funds for research financed from the Tobacco Industry Trust Account. In 1965 the Act was amended so that part of the charges paid by growers and manufacturers could be appropriated to meet the cost of operation of the Australian Tobacco Board. In 1965 the rates of charge increased from one halfpenny to three-fifths of a penny per pound of tobacco. They were reduced in 1973 to 1.1c per kilogram. One can see from that that there has been a decline in the amount of money thus provided for research. Also, as the cost of operating the Australian Tobacco Board has escalated, there is a need for the industry to pay more levy at all levels. Of course, the size of the marketing quotas has declined under the terms of the Tobacco Stabilisation Plan.

I think the highest production figure in recent years was in 1971 when it was 15.876 million kgs whereas last year, for example, it was down to 14.739 million kgs. The research and extension programs in the three producing States have been pruned and rationalised over a period of several years. These new arrangements will result in the industry contributing a quarter of a million dollars more than it had been doing. The Commonwealth contributes on a dollar for dollar basis. As I said, the issue of government support for an industry which produces a commodity of dubious benefit to society was mentioned very strongly by the Minister in his speech. The Government is saying that it is now promoting the redirection of research moneys into alternative varieties of tobacco leaf which have a less detrimental effect on health. The Minister made the claim that in the research programs there has been increasing emphasis on plant breeding and on cultural practices which affect alkaloid levels in the leaf. Research is also aimed at lessening dependence on the use of chemicals in the growing of the tobacco.

To ensure that there will be further emphasis on these essential aspects of research, the Government has sought the agreement of the Australian Agricultural Council to add a representative of the Department of Health to membership of the Central Tobacco Advisory Committee, that is, the committee which has the responsibility for examining research programs and recommending to the Minister the expenditure of moneys from the Tobacco Industry Trust Account. Expenditure approved for this year, that is, 1981-82, is $1,233,155 of which the Commonwealth is committed to contribute $348,000. The additional State expenditure on tobacco research in 1981-82 is estimated at $580,000. As I have said, the increases have been sought by both the growing and the manufacturing sectors. The Tobacco Growers Council has said that the growers are not opposed to the Bill and consider it in their interests that it be passed.

The industry has had a substantial input into the decision to increase charges. Prior to proposing the increase in charges, the growers were careful to review the existing research and administration in order to make all possible cost savings. The funds will not be used for promotion or research into promotion, and the arrangement whereby the Commonwealth is required to match expenditure of industry funds will not mean that the Government will have to make a considerable increase. The Government's contribution has not increased in absolute terms since 1965 but this increase does not make up for growers' losses due to inflation and the declining quotas I have already mentioned.

Rather than acting as a means of maintaining a health problem, research into the growing and curing aspects of the tobacco industry can act as a valuable and effective means of dealing with problems. Through research programs, efforts can be channelled into developing less toxic varieties of tobacco or devising methods of curing and processing that minimise the levels of contaminants in the tobacco leaf. The industry is aware that such research is in its long term interests. The dependence on heavy applications of insecticides and herbicides is another problem. Pollution of streams is widespread in tobacco growing areas. Therefore, substantial social and economic benefits are to be gained from research within the industry itself into ways of curbing the dependence on chemicals. I suppose that most honourable members, as realists-this would certainly be the industry view-are convinced that in the short term it will never be possible to ban cigarette smoking any more than governments will be able to ban junk food, both of which may be desirable objectives. However, via research, we may be able to make smoking less harmful. It is this positive direction that research should be encouraged by the Government to follow.

Further research, inasmuch as it facilitates cost savings in production, allows Australian leaf to become more competitive with leaf produced overseas. If we do not support and encourage the domestic tobacco industry, increasing amounts of leaf will simply be imported from overseas. It is much harder to control the toxicity levels of a product produced in foreign countries than it is to control them in our own. It appears to the Opposition that research is capable of making a positive contribution to the problem of the effect of smoking on health. It is doubtful that such one-off measures as a 10 per cent levy on cigarettes, which I understand is being proposed in another place, will be equally positive. Numerous studies have indicated that there is no provable relationship between the level of advertising and the level of smoking in the community, but there is a very commonly held view that advertising certainly does promote brands and in so doing stimulates consumption. The recent Committee of Inquiry into Advertising of Tobacco Products which was conducted by the Western Australian Department of Health reported:

There are many factors having the potential to contribute to the establishment and maintenance of the smoking habit. Advertising (including promotion) is only one of these. The majority of the more potent factors are of phychological or social nature.

This Bill gives honourable members a chance to say a few words about the tobacco industry, even though it simply increases the amount of levy being paid by growers and processors. As honourable members are aware, the Tobacco Stabilisation Plan operates until 1983. It is administered by the Australian Tobacco Board, whose main job is to oversee the marketing quota for Australian flue cured tobacco for each of the five years dealt with in the plan. Quotas are increased or decreased by the use of a rather complicated formula. As I have said, production levels are coming down slightly. Queensland produces over half of Australia's leaf, Victoria produces over a third and New South Wales produces the least-some one-tenth to one-twelfth of total production, which comprises about 15 million kiograms a year. The Tobacco Board also maintains a grade and minimum price schedule which is operated under the terms of the stabilisation plan. It is an industry which is in discrete locations. For example, in Queensland the industry is located mainly in the electorate of the honourable member for Leichhardt, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson). There are elements in the northern tablelands of New South Wales and also in the electorate of the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron).

It may be appropriate, as some of my comments have been devoted to health aspects, to refer to the recent report by the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence. One of the things which some people in our community smoke is marihuana. The recommendations of that report should be seriously taken on board by the Government because if we admit freely that tobacco can be a harmful product, we need also to deal with the recommendations of that Committee, which reviewed all the reports that had been submitted on drugs to see how society should handle this problem, including the legal situation, possible control measures and so on. We should not continually seek to avoid that issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my privilege to support the Government on these tobacco Bills. In doing so, I support also some of the comments made by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), especially those to the effect that much of the increased revenue will be channelled into research into the effect of various varieties of leaf on the health of we humans when we smoke tobacco. One of the three Bills relates to leaf that is sold; another relates to leaf that comes into Australia; and the third relates to leaf that manufacturers produce and consume themselves through their factories. All in all, an average charge of 2.5c per kilogram is to be applied as from 1 March 1982. The levy has been in operation since 1955.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to point out that in future the levy will not need an Act of Parliament in order to be either increased or decreased. The Bills allow the levy to be regulated by the Department concerned. This is a big step forward. It is much easier to make amendments to research funding in that way than by going to the trouble of putting an Act through Parliament. Unfortunately, these days most charges seem to go upwards; nothing seems to come down in price. I suppose that the next change will also be for an increase in the levy. On 2 July 1981 the industry decided that the research allocation for 1981-82 would be no more than $1.23m. As the honourable member for Werriwa has indicated, the Commonwealth and States contribute to that fund. I add that New South Wales receives approximately $59,250, Victoria $430,200 and Queensland $676,000. A contingency fund of $66,000 is also set aside. That is a very good idea. Doubtless that fund is used for carry-on purposes if the research funds are run down or additional finance is needed in a particular research sector.

Money is also allocated for the publication of an industry journal. That is an excellent idea. Of course, these allocations apply to only the three States in Australia in which tobacco is grown. As has been mentioned recently, most is grown in Queensland-on the Atherton Tableland, in the Glasshouse Mountains area and in my electorate of Maranoa, around the Texas-Yelarbon district. Most of the expenditure is involved in research. I believe that the honourable member for Werriwa has covered the health aspects very well and, of course, I support what is being done in that regard.

I will refer briefly to what is happening in each State. In New South Wales most tobacco is grown in the Ashford area which is quite close to the Queensland border, so the two States have something in common in that regard. Junior and senior screening trials are conducted in an effort to keep the quality of leaf as high as possible. In Victoria the research station is established in the district of Myrtleford. Its programs cover pests and disease, weed control, plant breeding and so on.

The honourable member for Werriwa mentioned the alkaline content of the leaf. It is most important that this be researched and minimised for reasons of our own good health. Of course, weeds in crops are always a problem and must continually be kept under control. Much work is being done in agriculture these days in the use of insects rather than chemicals to keep pests under control. We all know the detrimental effect which some chemicals have on our lives. It is important that this work continue. We have seen all sorts of beetles and toads introduced into Australia to try to keep some of these pests at bay. Some of them, of course, have not turned out to be very exciting. For example, the cane toad got completely out of hand and has spread right across eastern Australia. Research is continuing into methods of harvesting. Also the curing of tobacco is very important. Once the crop has been harvested in its green leaf stage, it has to be cured. That is probably one of the most important stages of the crop. Most of the curing is now being done with gas. A lot of work is going on to try to reduce the cost of the heat necessary to cure tobacco. All tobacco leaf must go through the curing stage.

Plant pathology and crop management are other considerations. In Queensland, which grows the most tobacco, most of the research takes place in the Mareeba district. There is also a station at Beerwah and one at Indooroopilly, in Brisbane. These establishments are looking at plant breeding, crop protection and the economics of the crop. Of course plant varieties are very important. The one currently being looked at is ZZ100. It is hoped that that variety will replace the Hick variety, which has been the most popular in the last few years. Bulk farm tests have been carried out on ZZ100 and it is hoped that it will be used to counteract blue mould, which is very prevalent in tobacco growing and will easily wipe out a crop. This variety is resistant to blue mould. A chemical called Antimould has been produced which is very useful in keeping this disease under control.

Like the honourable member for Werriwa, I would like to use this opportunity to refer to the industry. It is presently in very good shape. It has had a number of dry years-the last three-but this year has been excellent. Tobacco likes overcast, rainy conditions and certainly Queensland has been getting plenty of those conditions in the last two or three weeks. The wet has set in with a vengance and the tobacco growing areas in my electorate have received up to five inches of rain. Most of the tobacco is grown under irrigation. I have taken the liberty of contacting some of the growers, including Mr Augi Agostenalli and Mr Harley Girle in the Yelarbon district. I have spoken to them about these Bills. They are very happy as growers to see that the Government is increasing the levy . As good farmers, they know that without research these days any industry will quickly slip backwards. They have indicated to me that they would like to see funds spent on the things I mentioned previously-variety trials, fertilisers and particularly irrigation. There are all sorts of new methods to irrigate crops. Perhaps at this stage we should ask the Federal Government to give us more funds for irrigation, not just in Queensland but throughout Australia. It is one area at which we have to look closely. Water, along with roads, is very important and certainly we need much more funding for irrigation. I guess the money we need to spend does not drop out of the sky.

TALK.START.PARA: —Water does.

—Water does but unfortunately the money does not. The current price for tobacco is 464c a kilogram, which is 20c above the minimum price set by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the Tobacco Growers Stabilisation Fund. At present the price is above that minimum, so it can be understood that the growers are quite happy with the prices they are receiving. Like all good farmers they want more money all the time. They argue that the manufacturers are probably making a greater profit than they are, that the manufacturers' profit margins continue to rise whereas the profit margin for farmers is fairly static. They would like to see the minimum price increased.

SPEECH.PARA: The gross value of tobacco in Australia today is approximately $60m, so it is no small industry. Of course it is very important to the people involved. New South Wales has 69 growers, Victoria 316 and Queensland 575, giving a total of 965 growers in Australia. We have 234 single operators and 663 family partnerships. A large portion of the Australian tobacco growing industry is made up of Italian immigrants. They are not frightened of a bit of hard work and wielding the hoe, and having got into this industry they now lead it. Anybody one talks to at the top of the industry has an Italian name. I think that is excellent. This situation is excellent for Australia and it has been of tremendous value to the families concerned. It is of tremendous value to the Government's philosophy of helping the family farm and making it the base of our rural operations. Nearly three-quarters of the operators are family partnerships , which is a very good indication of the co-operation within the industry. It has not been taken over by the large corporations; it is still basically made up of family units that work very hard to make a living from the industry.

Queensland now has a quota system. The industry has just voted on it and has decided to allow a quota to be established throughout the State. Previously quotas were allowed to be sold only locally. For those who do not understand the quota system, each grower has a quota. If his quota is over and above what he is able to grow then he is allowed to sell that quota. Since this vote was taken he has been able to sell it throughout Queensland. The industry presently is asking the Industries Assistance Commission to look at extending those quota sales throughout Australia. This would be very welcome if it were to come about because it would allow growers to move their quotas throughout the eastern States, so allowing tobacco growing to be moved from one area to another much more quickly. At present the heavy leaf grown west of the range is not in demand . The market is looking for the light leaf that is grown more in Victoria and on the Atherton Tablelands, in the more humid areas and the cooler areas. It is most important that quotas can be transferred throughout Australia.

The stabilisation scheme was mentioned by the honourable member for Werriwa. This has been of wonderful value to the industry. I am sure that with those involved in the industry working so hard, with the stabilisation scheme they have and with the extra funds that these Bills will enable the industry to use in research, the industry can look forward to a very prosperous future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take just a couple of minutes to express my reservations about the Tobacco Charge Bills. Some people have implied that money for research on tobacco will somehow be used to improve the health of the Australian population. I challenge that. Most of the money going into research is used to make it possible to grow the tobacco more cheaply, to make it available more cheaply and to encourage more people to get--
—Lung cancer.

—To get lung cancer, as the honourable member for Reid points out. Lung cancer is only one of the conditions which are a result of tobacco smoking. I am not one of those who believe in banning things but I do think that this problem is of huge cost to the community. The previous legislation passed by this House dealt with grants to the States of some thousands of millions of dollars for hospitals and health care. A very high proportion of that care is connnected with the use of tobacco and the excessive use of alcohol. It is a huge cost to the community. It is a clear question of addiction so far as tobacco is concerned. I do think that some of the money which is being raised as a result of this legislation ought to be used to educate the community and to counteract the temptation, especially for young people, to smoke more and more.

SPEECH.PARA: I think most honourable members would agree, with the possible exception of those who are smokers, that there has been a significant drop in the use of cigarettes amongst what I would call the thinking portion of the population. Fewer and fewer people with certain educational standards who have thought about it are in fact smoking. But it is worrying that the total consumption of cigarettes is not going down, partly because their use has spread to younger people and to females. More and more females are smoking; more and more females are suffering the diseases which formerly were mainly confined to males. A greater proportion of females has such conditions as carcinoma of the lung and other things.

I think money should be used to advertise the adverse effects of the use of tobacco and alcohol. Although in this instance we are dealing specifically with tobacco, I think that such action should be taken in respect of both substances. Governments, of course, have been in some ways hypocritical. I am not referring to this Government but to governments as a whole. Large amounts of revenue from excise, sales tax and so on, are collected from the sale of tobacco and alcohol. I am sure that people who have looked at the question would agree with me that the cost to government and to the community is much greater than the amount of money collected. My party has a policy to forbid the advertising of tobacco products on television and radio. I have some reservations about that policy. I can see reasons for such a policy but I would very much prefer to see every advertisement by Peter Stuyvesant, Marlboro, or whatever glamorising the use of tobacco and every advertisement glamorising the use of beer, wine or whatever, counteracted by an advertisement showing the results of the use of those substances. If this were done I think that within a relatively short period we would see a significant decrease in the consumption of those substances. I think that such a requirement would be to the advantage of the population as a whole. People at least would be aware of the problems that are being caused. As I said, I think there is a lot of hypocrisy about this matter.

The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) mentioned a report on marihuana. Obviously there is a large amount of hypocrisy involved on the part of governments of all kinds when we condemn out of hand the use of marihuana and yet allow the use of tobacco and alcohol. Tobacco and alcohol undoubtedly do much greater harm to society. Yet people hold their hands up in horror and complain about any suggestion that the use of marihuana be legalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely you are not advocating the use of marihuana?

—I am not advocating the use of any drug which affects people's minds , any drug which becomes addictive in any sense, or any drug which has a mind altering quality. I suppose that alcohol is by far the leading drug used in this community. All of those drugs are bad. But I think it is quite hypocritical to go ahead and make statements about the danger involved in using one drug and not to do anything about other drugs, not even to run any strong campaigns against the use of tobacco and alcohol. I may be a wowser on those issues but I think that governments ought to look at the health bill. Indeed, they often talk about it. I am sure that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), who is at the table, was very concerned when he was Minister for Health about the continuing increase in the proportion of gross national product that goes to health. Yet one of the easiest and most clear-cut methods of reducing expenditure on health is to spend more money on education to discourage people from leading unhealthy life styles. I am sure the unhealthiest lifestyles of all from the point of view of cost to the community are the two I have mentioned-the excessive use of alcohol and the smoking of tobacco products. I urge the Government again to think about this point when it imposes charges on the tobacco industry. The best way to help Australia, the revenue and individuals in the community would be to spend much more money on educational programs to expose the dangers that follow the use of tobacco and alcohol.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SOCIAL SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2]
Debate resumed from 10 March, on motion by Mr Hunt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all too familiar with the measure that is now before the House, the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2]. The elements of this Bill first appeared in the omnibus Social Services Amendment Bill following the Budget and were rejected by this Parliament. They reappeared in the form of the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) which was likewise rejected by this Parliament. The same Bill appears before us this afternoon. It comes to us completely unchanged from the Bill rejected by this Parliament in November 1981 and its fate will be similar.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill's objectives are primarily to deny the single rate of unemployment benefit to spouses of trade unionists involved in strike action, to spouses of unemployed persons denied benefits under the work test, to the spouses of those allegedly voluntarily unemployed or dismissed for alleged misconduct. In addition, this denial is extended to the special benefits provision so that spouses of those who would have received special benefits, if they failed on any of these conditions, will also not get them.

As I have said, the Bill comes completely unchanged despite an intense parliamentary debate over nearly four months. Substantial criticisms were delivered against this Bill-not just from the Australian Labor Party but from Australian Democrats senators and independent Senator Harradine. Yet not one jot or tittle of the Bill has been altered to meet any of the reasoned criticisms that have been directed against it. Indeed, the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is virtually word for word the identical reiteration of the same tired old cliches used to justify this legislation twice already in this Parliament. I am pretty certain that on this occasion third time repetition will not be lucky. Basically this is anti-union legislation which seeks to use social security as a means of industrial discipline. The Minister has twice said, and his colleague elsewhere has also delivered exactly the same words:
We are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action as contrasted with other means open to employees in dispute with their employers to resolve these disputes.

Of course, the legislation is concerned with the merits of strike action. It is concerned simply with condemning strike action out of hand, with penalising the wives and children of those involved in strike action on the basis that all strike action is wrong and that the use of any weapon is justified against the families of those involved in the strike. There was never any suggestion in any of the speeches made from the Government benches that in the inevitable conflict between capital and labour, capital might occasionally be wrong. It is always assumed in all these cases that it is those workers involved in industrial action who are wrong and, therefore, these penalties have to be taken against their families. So let us have none of this thrice repeated nonsense that this Bill is not concerned with the merits of strike action. For the Government all such action seems to be, according to the justification of this Bill, always and everywhere unmerited. The Minister told us:
What we are concerned with is how the cost of strike action is to be borne.

He was saying what the Bill is really about is how the cost of strike action is to be borne. The Government's concern on this point has been shown to be basically unfounded because the numbers involved and the amounts are minimal. The justification for persisting with the legislation in this way does not rest on a very large financial basis. Of course, the Government does make much of the $450,000 which was paid to those 475 wives and children during the prolonged 12 weeks strike at the Utah coal mine in central Queensland. Yet the real question that needs to be asked about that strike is exactly the merits of that industrial action. Why was such a great multinational company, which made a $ 160m profit in the very year of that industial action, able to reveal nothing but unmitigated intransigence in solving its industrial relations problems? They are the sorts of questions that need to be asked in relation to this legislation .

The Government is wasting this enormous amount of parliamentary time on a measure which saves a minimal amount of money in its overall social security bill, not because it is concerned with how the cost of strike action is to be borne. That is not the reason for this measure; that is not the reason the debate has continued for four months it is not the reason that this Bill has been shunted back and forth between the House and Senate. The Government is not concerned with what the Minister ostensibly says it is concerned with. The Government is desperate in its concern with how votes are to be won. Union bashing seems a cheap and easy, if rather irresponsible, way of getting those votes.

Let us look at the legislation in detail. This Bill is the culmination of a prolonged attack on the social security rights of those involved in strikes. It is not the first of these actions. Throughout the history of this government it has been whittling away social security rights in relation to those involved in strikes. Enormous legislative resources have been expended on this relatively small group in the community. First of all, the Government denied the unemployment benefit to actual strikers. Secondly, the unemployment benefit was denied to those who belonged to the same union and who were stood down as a result of strike action by that union even though the strike may have occurred in another industry and, in some cases, even in another State. Thirdly, last year the Government reduced the benefit to the spouses of these people involved in industrial action from the married rate down to the single rate. This Bill attempts to go the whole way and remove the single rate unemployment benefit from the spouses of those involved in strike action.

Let us consider the situation which applies at the moment-that is, what this legislation aims finally to get rid of. First of all, the benefit which the Government aims to remove is the single rate benefit of $69.70 a week, plus $10 a week for each child. That is what the Government is striking at. It is not a family benefit because the spouses, usually the men, have already been dealt with. The Government is now primarily getting at the wives and children. The amount involved is the single rate benefit of $69.70 a week, plus $10 a week for each child. Moreover, no benefit is paid until seven days have passed after a person has registered for the unemployment benefit. So it will concern only those very few industrial actions which are prolonged for over a week. No benefit is paid at the moment unless the strike action extends over eight days. Of course, it is only paid then if the wife or the spouse has registered immediately. Moreover, usually no cheque is paid until two weeks after registration. So at best the strike needs to extend over more than seven days before any benefit at all is paid. In a strike lasting 10 days the spouse, if he or she had registered immediately, would get only three days' benefit.

Even this marginal pittance paid under these quite strict conditions, which already exclude the spouses of most of those involved in industrial action, will now be removed in order to punish the spouses of those few involved in prolonged industrial action. In those prolonged industrial actions-whatever the rights and wrongs of the case as judged objectively-the workers have usually made fairly tough decisions because such actions involve long term costs for them if the strike runs over the period with which we are concerned in this Bill. It is true that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), the so-called human face of liberalism, has said:

If a person is precluded from receiving unemployment benefit and special benefit, in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, his or her spouse may be eligible for special benefit at the single rate with additional benefit for children.

It is said that if this legislation does produce cases of extreme hardship these people may be eligible for special benefit. All of us are familiar with how the Department of Social Security applies the extreme hardship rules. As the Minister clearly pointed out, there have to be no other means of support-that is , resources such as savings have first to be whittled away, other resources have first to go before the extreme hardship principle can be applied. Basically what the Minister is saying-it is somewhat dressed up-is that if people are reduced to destitution then at least the Government will prevent them from starving. That is, after all their other resources have gone and they can no longer sustain themselves, at least the Government will prevent them from starving. Indeed, the Bill can be said to enshrine the latest of Liberal principles-family destitution as a system of industrial discipline.

The Australian Labor Party is totally opposed to the principle embodied in this Bill-that of using the social security system as a weapon in industrial relations, as a means of imposing industrial discipline. We object fundamentally to that use of the social security system. We have a second fundamental objection in principle to this measure. The whole of the Australian social security system is based on the principle of individual entitlement qualified by spouse income. We have a basic system which entitles every individual to the social security benefits for which he or she has a claim. This is qualified only by spouse income. Yet the changes embodied in this Bill sweep that basic notion away because the Bill says that in particular cases this individual entitlement will no longer exist. It seems to me that this is a fundamental attack on the basic notion of our social security system which is that individuals are entitled to benefits. It is true, as I have said, that that is qualified by spouse income considerations. But in this case, where the spouse-the wife, or in a few cases it may be the husband-has, for whatever reason, no income, he or she will not be entitled to any benefit. This continues the change of a fundamental principle on which our social security system has been based.

Given the effects of this legislation, which strike mostly at women, it is in a very real sense sexist legislation. Why should the wives and children lose unemployment benefit because of the actions of their husbands and fathers? It is a particular view of the society which seeks to impose this penalty on wives and children. Can members of the House imagine the outcry that we would have from the Government benches if the Polish Government cut the food vouchers to families of striking workers? The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) would no doubt come in to the House and make one of those rare statements which can not be debated. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) would no doubt protest outside the Polish Embassy and the back benchers would be wrapped in paroxysms of concern for the wives of Polish workers if such action were taken. Yet this basic principle is being applied here. We are saying that because of the actions of workers their wives and children shall be penalised.

One of the benefits of Ministers recycling their speeches ad infinitum is that their hypocrisies catch up with them. A fine example of this occurred this week. On Tuesday the Prime Minister, in his address on the state of the nation, said:
We seek an increasingly compassionate society.
The Minister for Transport who represents the Minister for Social Security in this House said on Wednesday:

The legislation, as it stands at the moment, permits a situation in which trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated-
I emphasise the phrase 'largely insulated'-
from the financial effect of their actions.

Let us look at this insulation which is boasted about by this Minister in a compassionate government. For a family with one child the insulation is $79.70 a week. That is, a family of three is insulated against the effects of this action by living on less than $80 a week. The poverty line for a family where the head is not working, is $128.90 a week. So such a family is well below the poverty line. The insulation the Minister talks about-'largely insulated from the financial effects of their actions'-is a weekly income $50 below the poverty line. Of course that does not take into consideration delays in payment and the fact that the benefit will not even be paid in the first week of the strike action. This so-called insulation seems to be a word used only by people who live in very affluent circumstances, and who have never in their lives experienced these kinds of costs. Only the affluent could describe a family of three having to live on $80 a week as largely insulated from the financial effects of their actions.

Again, let me stress the miniscule numbers involved in the whole operation which makes the Government's behaviour in anything but political terms very difficult to understand. A very small proportion of strikes in this country go beyond five days. In 1980 only 9.9 per cent of strikers were involved in strikes of five or more working days and only 4.8 per cent of strikers were involved in strikes of 10 or more days. Overall, the proposed changes to the Social Services Act, in relation to the spouses of strikers, appear likely to affect less than 2 per cent of all the workers involved in industrial action. I have had to make a judgment because we do not get a precise seven-day figure but about 60,000 workers would be involved in disputes which extend over seven days. Of these 60, 000 workers roughly one third are single people and roughly one third have working wives and, therefore would not be able to claim unemployment benefit anyway. So we finish up with about 20,000 workers, or 500 to 600 families involved in disputes lasting more than a week. As I said, these are cases involving prolonged strikes where there is a real sense of grievance on the worker's side. On the whole, workers in this country do not embark on strikes of the nature we are now talking about unless they feel that they have strong and distinct grievances.

This brings me to the point that the Government's legislation seems to ignore entirely the reality of industrial relations. It seems to assume that all strikes are unmerited. Basically, that is the justification for the legislation. Yet the causes of many of the disputes are directly attributable to management. An Australian Bureau of Statistics' survey in 1980 attributed the prime cause- not the only cause-of nearly 40 per cent of industrial disputes to managerial policies. In another 19.6 per cent of cases physical working conditions were the main cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many demarcations?

—I am sure that there are other causes as well. I agree with the Minister. All I am asking him to admit is that the assumption in this Bill that all strikes are unmerited is false. That is the basic assumption in this Bill. The wives of all strikers in any situation, no matter what the basis or cause of the strike, will be penalised by this Bill where the strike goes over a certain period. I wonder what sorts of sanctions might be thought of in relation to management. Of course, all the sanctions in this Bill are directed solely at one side of the struggle.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn briefly to the other section of the Bill because the Bill is not simply concerned with punishing the spouses of workers who are involved in industrial action; it also denies unemployment benefit to workers dismissed for misconduct. Again, the notion of misconduct in the work place is, as we all know , an extremely dubious one. At least it is debatable. I think fair-minded honourable members on the other side will say that in many cases there can be a great debate about the dismissal of a particular worker for misconduct. Secondly , spouses of those who are voluntarily unemployed will also be denied unemployment benefit or special benefit. We have had long debates, both in this House and outside it, on the notion of voluntary unemployment. Thirdly, the spouses of those who fail the work test will be denied unemployment benefit. First of all let me say that all these categories are extremely dubious. They are debatable. In 1980-81 50 per cent of all the appeals against the denial of unemployment benefit were upheld, that is, 50 per cent of social security denials of unemployment benefit, which in many cases related to the issues I have just mentioned, were upheld as incorrect. In many cases spouses will be punished in error as a result of this legislation. If the average remains we can say that in roughly half the cases penalties will be imposed on people who do not deserve them.

The penalties already are peculiarly harsh for workers who are dismissed for misconduct, who are voluntarily unemployed or who fail the work test. First of all, there is a mandatory denial of benefit for six weeks and it is up to the discretion of the Department to extend that period to 12 weeks. Therefore, if the full period of suspension-the 12-week period-is exercised against an individual that means a fine of $600 for a single person and at least $1,000 for a married person. Already quite extreme penalties are imposed on people. As I pointed out in an earlier debate, they are often higher than those penalties imposed on drunken or dangerous drivers. Now this measure seeks to punish the wives and children as well. The Government is not content with the already quite high penalties which are imposed on people who are dismissed for misconduct, who are voluntarily unemployed or who fail the work test. It is not content with the quite severe sanctions which are already exercised against them. These penalties will now be extended to the wives and families of these individuals. Again, the numbers are fairly miniscule; something like 300 to 400 families a week are involved.

For these reasons we have opposed this legislation in this House and we will continue to oppose it in another place. We are confident that we will be supported by independents and other parties on this issue. We also believe and are quite confident about facing the people on this issue. Once the Bill is examined in its reality and once we put aside the shroud of anti-union rhetoric which has been used to defend it and which no doubt again today will be used to defend it, I think it will be found that this is a splendid piece of legislation on which to judge this Government's pretended commitment to a compassionate and more humane society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always good to hear the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) since he has a capacity to dress up an argument with some deceptively attractive characteristics and at the same time to avoid the essential nature of what is before the House. I want to address my remarks to that part of the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 (No. 2) which deals with the payment of unemployment and special benefits to spouses of persons who are on strike. The question that that raises on the view put by this side of the House is: Who pays? The honourable member for Bonython called the legislation anti-union and sexist.
