The only thing he did not say was that there was some sort of conspiracy to intern the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get back to the central question, and that is: Who should pay? We know what the present system is; there is no dispute about that. It is worth while recording one or two of the occasions in recent times when there have been prolonged strikes. The honourable member at one and the same time points out that the consequences of this Bill are miniscule and says that it is a means of imposing industrial discipline. That is a very interesting way of putting an argument because the one view conflicts with the other.

Let us look at two or three examples of recent industrial action. I take what was said in the Senate by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on 25 November 1981. He referred to a series of strikes in the period 1980 to 1981, which gives and indication of the amount of money which can be involved. Let me pick up the examples he gave. Firstly, he referred to a strike from June to September 1980 at Blackwater in Queensland. The reason for the strike was a dispute about the subsidised housing. Some 4,500 people in that town were on strike, 411 wives were granted unemployment benefit at a cost of $30,800 a week and 112 wives were granted special benefit at a cost of $8,400 a week. The total cost was $431,475.

The next example is a strike which occurred from 19 January 1981 to 19 March 1981 in Gladstone, Queensland. Some 177 people were on strike and 47 wives were granted unemployment benefits at a cost of $4,000 a week. As I note that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) has entered the chamber, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Earlier this afternoon the Opposition attempted to move a motion in this House to the effect that a senior Minister of the Government has been responsible for preventing any action being proceeded with against Nugan Hand. This Government, in co-operation with the New South Wales Government, has been determined to establish whether Nugan Hand was involved in any criminal activities, particularly drug trafficking. A joint Federal-New South Wales police task force was set up in 1979 by the two governments following recommendations by Mr Justice Williams and Mr Justice Woodward to inquire into matters which had been raised before the royal commissions.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently Mr Justice Woodward, the New South Wales Royal Commissioner into Drug Trafficking, recommended in his second report that the evidence concerning Nugan Hand should be referred to appropriate law enforcement groups for further investigations. Thus, on 26 August 1980 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) took the initiative of proposing to the Premier of New South Wales that the terms of reference of the Commonwealth-New South Wales joint task force be extended to enable it to investigate breaches by Nugan Hand of Commonwealth laws as well as all State laws. The Premier agreed.

I table the Prime Minister's letter of 26 August 1980 and the Premier's response of 28 August 1980. As well, I table a subsequent letter of 9 September 1980 from the Acting Prime Minister to the Premier. It will be seen from these letters that as well as suggesting the terms of reference should be widened to include Nugan Hand, the Prime Minister also offered to provide any assistance to the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission in its investigation of Nugan Hand. The joint task force is investigating whether there was any criminal activity, particularly drug related, in or affecting Australia by any persons connected with Nugan Hand activities and, if so, I will seek to identify such persons so that appropriate action can be initiated. These investigations are being conducted irrespective of what organisations such persons may or may not have belonged to.

I am advised that the Nugan Hand liquidator has, with the assistance of the Commonwealth, approached American authorities for information. I am advised also that the joint task force has passed information through normal police channels to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for inquiries to the relevant American authorities including the Central Intelligence Agency. I emphasise that the police task force which is investigating Nugan Hand is a joint operation involving Federal and New South Wales police. It is managed by a committee chaired by the Premier's Department of New South Wales. There is close association including the exchange of information between the task force and the Corporate Affairs Commission of New South Wales.

Is the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) seriously suggesting that, given these circumstances, any Minister from this Government or the New South Wales Government could attempt to hinder, stop or delay this investigation without there being a public disclosure. It is clearly a silly and stupid proposition. A year ago to the day the Prime Minister, in this House, in response to questions by the Leader of the Opposition concerning Nugan Hand, invited the Leader of the Opposition to provide him with any information that he had that could help the joint task force.

As I understand it, the Leader of the Opposition did not and has not produced any information. I call on the Leader of the Opposition again today to provide, firstly, any information that he may have on any Minister who has been involved in preventing the Nugan Hand investigation either from this Government or the New South Wales Government; and, secondly, any information that he may have that the joint task force is not operating properly. For this purpose an assistant commissioner from the Australian Federal Police is available in my office now to take any information that the Leader of the Opposition may have. I extend also to all members of this House and the Press Gallery the same invitation. Indeed, any member of the public with relevant information on Nugan Hand should provide it to the police.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-First of all we should get the decks cleared and understand accurately what was moved in this House this afternoon. There was a rather inelegant effort by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) to redirect the whole thrust of what was raised in the House this afternoon. One understands why. It it worth the effort. If it succeeds it will mean that rather than the Government being required to explain itself on a number of scores, the Opposition-and in particular me-will be put on the defensive. As I said, I suppose it is worth the effort, but it is altogether too clumsy to succeed. The implication of what the Minister said in his opening paragraph is simply this: That I effectively had accused a senior Minister of the Government of being responsible for preventing any action being proceeded with against the Nugan Hand organisation. A little later he asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) seriously suggesting that given these circumstances, any Minister from this Government or the New South Wales Government could attempt to hinder, stop or delay this investigation without there being a public disclosure?

I moved something which is vastly different. There are two parts to it. I moved in the first part that this House views with the greatest alarm certain public allegations which are of quite an extraordinary and disturbing nature because they are so serious.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—The Minister does not dispute that. It is reasonable to view those allegations with alarm. They were transmitted on a responsible media outlet- Channel 9-this morning. The second thing that I proposed in the motion was that the House requires-because that is one of the parliamentary forms, but another way of saying it is to say seeks, requests or invites; as it effectively was an invitation-the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) forthwith to respond and to assure the House that there is nothing in these allegations. Now I will not go into the detail of the motion. It is on the record. Essentially the precis that I gave is an accurate reflection of what was moved. Therefore, it is a nonsense for the Minister suddenly to stand up in the House and to suggest that the Opposition is making allegations. It is not.
—You did.
—It is not.
—You named somebody.

—I will come to that in a tick, but there are a few things that need to be said. What I said was that very serious public allegations had been made. It is reasonable for the community to be disturbed about them. This afternoon the Minister agreed orally and should therefore clear the record up.
—I have.
—No, the Minister has not cleared it up. But let me go on. The Minister has come into the House with this statement and, in relation to the matters that I raised, has expressed his view. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clearly a silly and stupid proposition.

I congratulate him. It has taken him 10 hours to arrive at this conclusion, because the news was transmitted this morning at about 7.30. The Minister's office collected a transcript of the allegations which were made from the relevant television channel and made no attempt at any stage in the House to clarify what he confessed here this afternoon are extraordinarily serious and damaging allegations. That was 10 hours ago. It is now three and a half hours since the matter was raised in this House. The Minister could have stood up then . The Government could have spoken and said: 'This is clearly silly and stupid. It is an untenable proposition for the following reasons'. It could have convinced everyone, but no, no, there was no opportunity for any rational explanation. When I raised the motion this afternoon I sought to make it clear that we certainly did not endorse the allegations. How could we? We had no evidence of them. But we were disturbed. At that point six and a half solid hours had elapsed between when the allegations were made--

TALK.START.PARA: —Two hours. Stop telling lies.

—And when they went on to the news. I am going on the transcript. It states that the news went out between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. on telecast national news this morning. So it is six and a half hours. The Minister cannot even do simple arithmetic. No wonder the country is in a mess. He is a senior Minister. It is another three and a half hours after that before the delayed time fuse goes off-bang, and the Minister gets an inspiration and says that it is silly and it is stupid. Conceivably it is, but it is also very serious. If it is so obviously silly and so abundantly stupid why could not the Minister have made the patently obvious comment and say it right away? Why did the Government seek to gag debate? No wonder this country is in a mess. A bomb goes off today and the Minister will wake up to it tomorrow. I will tell the Minister the sorts of things which were said this morning on television; the sorts of things that rattle my composure and the composure of people who viewed that program. The gentleman interviewed said that he resigned because of interference. I shall not delay greatly on that as it is in the transcript. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Well so far as the investigation is concerned my information is that a Minister of the Crown, a Federal Minister of the Crown, directed that no action of any overt nature take place in respect of the Nugan and Hand organisation. He didn't have any responsibility in the Narcotics Bureau portfolio I hasten to add.
The next question was:
What was the thrust of the information relating to Nugan Hand?
The reply was:
It related to heroin deals. It related to the laundering of money.
Later on he said:
Well the directive was-the brief or the file was to be a holding brief. In other words it was to be a benign enquiry where information was gathered but nothing acted on.
A later question was:
Do you think, or could that lead you to a conclusion that it was set up for that purpose?
The answer was:
I think that, from all the information that's been gathered, that's what it was highly entirely for.
I am quoting exactly from the text. He continued:
For the laundering of money and for the marrying of the two organisations, the CIA and organised crime and various other people who wanted to launder their money. That's what it was all about.
The next question was:
How much do you know of a CIA connection with Nugan Hand?
The answer was:

Well this highly placed informant was within the Nugan and Hand organisation. The initial information was that one of the principals of Nugan and Hand was an ex-CIA operative, or current CIA operative connected with the CIA within the Nugan and Hand organisation.
He was asked:
Who was that?
The reply was:
I understand it was Michael Hand.
The person being interviewed went on:
It seems to the evidence that the intelligence organisations are raising funds to finance various covert operations through the assistance of organised crime.
I think those are sufficient extracts. I refer merely to the allegations which have been made. I ask to have the transcript incorporated in Hansard as the Minister appears to dispute it.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
March 10, 1982
The following is a transcript from National News Today. It is given to you on the understanding that credit be given to the programme National News Today and/ or Channel Nine.
Subject: Business correspondence, Patrick Lindsay interviews ex Australian Narcotics Bureau investigator, Mr Joe Volkman.
To be telecast National News Today, 7 a.m.-8 a.m. Thursday, March 11, 1982.
Embargo: Thursday, March 11th, 8.00 a.m.
Lindsay: Joe Volkman was an investigator with the Australian Narcotics Bureau, but he left the Force. We asked him why.

Volkman: I resigned because myself and three other colleagues were subjected to a form of victimisation, vilification. We believe it was because we were gathering information on the Nugan and Hand organisation and I got to a point where I could take no more and I resigned.
Lindsay: Who was responsible for this vilification?

Volkman: Well you can't single out any particular person. The problem was that various snippets of information were gathered from some very highly placed informants who had information on the Nugan and Hand organisation which was all channelled into the Narcotics Bureau as it was at the time and from there the information was delegated to a relatively junior officer who was in command of the file and it would seem that senior officers within the Narcotics Bureau in Sydney and in Canberra were responsible.
Lindsay: How high did it go?

Volkman: Well so far as the investigation is concerned my information is that a Minister of the Crown, a Federal Minister of the Crown, directed that no action of any overt nature take place in respect of the Nugan and Hand organisation.
He didn't have any responsibility in the Narcotics Bureau portfolio I hasten to add.
Lindsay: What was the thrust of the information relating to Nugan Hand?
Volkman: It related to heroin deals. It related to the laundering of money.
Lindsay: So the Narcotics Bureau's investigation had just been shelved.
Volkman: Well the directive was-the brief or the file was to be a holding brief . In other words it was to be a benign enquiry where information was gathered but nothing acted on.
Lindsay: When did the activities of the Nugan Hand bank first come to your attention?
Volkman: My recollection is it was late 1976 or early 1977 that the information started to flow.
Lindsay: But were they dealing before that?

Volkman: In the very early seventies, when Hand first arrived here and the Nugan Hand organisation was set up it seems that the information suggests that the deals started not long after it was set up.
Lindsay: Do you think, or could that lead you to a conclusion that it was set up for that purpose?

Volkman: I think that, from all the information that's been gathered, that's what it was highly entirely for. For the laundering of money and for the marrying of the two organisations, the CIA and organised crime and various other people who wanted to launder their money. That's what it was all about.
Lindsay: How much do you know of a CIA connection with Nugan Hand?

Volkman: Well this highly placed informant was within the Nugan and Hand organisation. The initial information was that one of the principals of Nugan and Hand was an ex-CIA operative, or current CIA operative, and there were other people connected with the CIA within the Nugan and Hand organisation.
Lindsay: Who was that?
Volkman: I understand it was Michael Hand.
Lindsay: You're convinced a conspiracy of silence existed which prevented a proper investigation of the Nugan Hand bank.

Volkman: Well there has to be some reason for why this has suffered the course of events that it has suffered. I would point out that I have information in respect of the Nugan and Hand organisation to the Federal Royal Commission into Drugs, the Williams Commission, in the middle of 1978 and I gave information about laundering of money, the export of cannabis and various comings and goings of the Nugan and Hand organisation.
Lindsay: This revelation that you're telling us about now throws a new light on Nugan's death because originally he was supposed to have killed himself because of financial difficulties.

Volkman: That's right. I think it's the only direct evidence we have of linking , if you like, between organised crime and intelligence organisations. It seems to the evidence that the intelligence organisations are raising funds to finance various covert operations through the assistance of organised crime. This suspicion was put up in respect of the Kennedy assassination in America. But here we have some direct evidence of this occurring. Here was the biggest thing in drug investigation this country had ever seen. I mean the only inference you can draw from the way it turned out is that it's Australia's watergate.

TALK.START.PARA: —These allegations have not only been made but also they are on a sworn affidavit.
—Not them.
—No, I am repeating them.
—You made them.
—The Minister agreed with me that they are serious.
—No, I did not.
—I could accept that you do not remember that you agreed, because it was three minutes ago.
—Repeat the allegations you made two hours ago.
—I will come to that in a minute. Do not worry.
—The Leader of the Opposition will direct his remarks through the Chair.

—These allegations are in a sworn affidavit which, I understand, Channel 9 has. I also understand that the affidavit will declare that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) is the Minister concerned. I know that another journalistic source, completely independent of Channel 9, also has that sort of information. Now I am not suggesting--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Deputy Prime Minister has already denied any association with this event. I do not believe that it is appropriate therefore for the charges to be repeated.
—With respect, I have been asked to repeat the allegations and I am quoting what I am told is on the affidavit.

—The Leader of the Opposition is not entitled to make any statements which impute ill motive on the part of any honourable member unless it be by a substantive motion. I know the way in which the honourable gentleman is putting it; that is, he is saying that it has been said, but the repetition of it it does carry an imputation and I ask the honourable gentleman not to misuse the Standing Orders.

—Mr Speaker, I obviously accept what you are saying, but let me underscore it in confirmation. The Deputy Prime Minister did stand up this afternoon and deny the allegations. I accept his denial. But the fact is that I was challenged by the Minister for Administrative Services to repeat the allegation that had been conveyed to me. They cannot have it both ways; demand I say it and then condemn me for saying it.
—You have accepted the denial. That is fine.
—If the Minister is prepared to stand up and deny it, it does not dispose of these allegations.
—But you accepted a denial. Do you accept it or not?
—What?
—His denial.

—Yes. I said that I accepted it. If the Minister stands up and denies it; I accept a denial from any honourable man, a member of this House, where an allegation has been made and evidence is not produced in support of it. I am saying that allegations have been made which are so serious that they alarm me and they alarm this rather dense Minister who agreed with me that it was reasonable to be concerned about them. Why did not the Government respond to this matter when it had the opportunity? Why did it take 10 hours for the Government to get three pages together to respond to it? I repeat, if the allegations which have been made, not by me but publicly, are clearly silly and stupid as a set of propositions, is there such a delayed time fuse on the intellectual mechanism of the Minister for Administrative Services that it takes 10 hours for a response to be made? I know his record in the war in Vietnam. My brother-in-law served with him. They sent him out on one occasion and he got lost. They had to send another troop out to get him back.
—Mr Speaker--
—The Minister will resume his seat. I call upon the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw the statement that he made.
—Which statement-that he got lost when he was lost in Vietnam?
—I ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw the statement in which he used words which the Minister apparently found personally offensive.
—That he got lost in Vietnam and they had to send a troop out to find him? I will withdraw it. I would be embarrassed--
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—Let us have the evidence for that too. You are becoming the biggest liar in this place.
—Don't you do a Bob Hawke on me or I'll walk out.
—You are a liar.
—The Minister will withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—The Leader of the Opposition is speaking by leave. I should remind him that he was given leave to make an explanation about a matter.
—No, leave to respond to the statement. That is what I sought and got.
—I ask him to comply with the forms of the House and remain relevant to that statement only.

—Yes, Mr Speaker, I accept that. I am not offended by the Minister's statement. He merely lost his way again-in parliament this time. I suggest the Minister should seek access to the affidavit which I understand has been sworn. I do not want to labour the matter but it has taken 10 hours for us to arrive at this point. No wonder, I repeat, that the country is in the fix it is in today. The Government has difficulty in responding to fairly obvious things that confront it. It is not the first time allegations of this sort of nature have been made. In the Canberra Times of 15 October 1980, in an article--
—I raise a point of order. What was printed in the Canberra Times cannot be relevant to the matter on which you, Mr Speaker, granted leave to the Leader of the Opposition to speak.
—There is no point of order.
—The article headed 'Investigation ''stopped by top Customs officer'' ' states:

SPEECH.PARA: An investigation into illegal dealings of the Nugan Hand Bank and other companies had been stopped by a high-ranking Customs officer in Canberra, a customs officers' union official said yesterday.
The gentleman referred to was Mr Spanswick. I do not know him. I have never come across him. The article reports him as saying:
'Members of my association had gathered enough evidence to conduct a full investigation of the Nugan Hand Bank when they were ordered to stop', he said.

'If these investigations had gone ahead we could have exposed these illegal dealings years ago. But now that they have come out this year, what do we have but a dead body, a collapsed bank, a missing principal and millions of dollars vanished'.
The article went on to state:
He had had discussions with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Garland, but had not reached any agreement.
'I was disgusted with his attitude as all he was trying to do was fob the whole issue off', he said.

People cannot be blamed for being disturbed when they see those sorts of reports , bluntly declared, publicly committed by these people. Let us look at Nugan Hand and the reason for concern. Bernard Morris Houghton, an intelligence operative of the United States, is a man who apparently has entry to and exit from this country without the necessity for a visa. He arrived in 1972 without a visa. What did he recommend so that he could get into the country? He recommended that the appropriate authorities at the port of entry contact the head of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. That was done. He was allowed in. Edmund Wilson was able to move in and out of this country in spite of being of quite unsavoury character. He is an intelligence operative of the worst type, in the worst areas of intelligence operations and reputedly tied up with the United States naval intelligence. He has been in and out of this country several times and he is an associate of Houghton, a man allegedly involved in quite questionable commercial transactions which could only undermine administrations in other countries.

What about the file on Nugan Hand which is held by the Federal Bureau of Investigation? That file, under the American Freedom of Information Act, is accessible but large areas of it are completely blocked out on the grounds of national intelligence requirements. I ask the Minister not to stand up and give a declaration but to give us some hard facts on this because I understand that the police task force was impeded by the Fraser Government in its frequent requests for support to obtain access to the intelligence portions of the FBI file. These are some of the facts that need to be tested. The Minister has said- -

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the statement. You are just making a fool of yourself.
—The Minister will cease interjecting.
—It does not take long to read the statement because it reflects the full intellectual output of the Minister for a late Thursday afternoon.
—The Leader of the Opposition--
—Well, stop him interjecting so foolishly.
—The Leader of the Opposition will disregard the interjection and continue with his statement.

—There is now no doubt that approaches have been made to the FBI because it had been intimated to the Government that if the task force was not assisted its report would make it clear that it was obstructed in that respect. Did Nugan Hand--
—False.
—You are telling lies again, Bill.
—Mr Speaker, do you want me to reply to interjections or are you going to stop them?
—Honourable members on my right will remain silent. I ask the Ministers to cease interjecting.

—Did Nugan Hand have any association with the Central Intelligence Agency? I had the opportunity of speaking with ASIO representatives. ASIO has shown some interest in this matter and of course I raised it with ASIO representatives. I have been assured that Nugan Hand did not have any association with the CIA. I said: 'How can you be sure they have not had any contact?' They said: 'Well, we asked them'. I said: 'That is scarcely evidence'. But they said: 'We asked them several times'. I said: 'How can you be convinced by just asking them?' They got very angry in the end, and they desisted. I am telling the House the facts. I am embarrassed somewhat by relating this but I am very unhappy that that is the level of intensive investigation in this matter. The Minister might be satisfied with the rather flimsy, rather threadbare bit of paper he has put before the House this afternoon, his rather thin efforts to try to turn the tables as it were and put me on the defensive, but the facts are that the allegations have been made publicly. They have been heard, I presume, by that portion of the New South Wales community that viewed the program I referred to and also by the rest of Australia if it was transmitted elsewhere. The Minister knew about it. The usual form in this House is to come in and make a personal explanation to clear the record on such a serious allegation, such a damaging allegation, but he did no such thing. It took six and a half hours before the matter was even raised in the Parliament and another two and a half hours or three and a half hours for him to think about it. It took 10 hours to get the Minister mobile. It takes an awful lot of cranking up to get his magneto sparking. I reject the whole flimsy approach of the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SERVICES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981 [No. 2]
Second Reading
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption to this debate I had given two examples of strikes during which social security payments had been made. Let me give a third example. In Broken Hill, from 18 February 1981 to 15 March 1981, 2,000 to 2,500 people were on strike and 1,167 wives claimed the unemployment benefit at a cost of $99,195 a week. Special benefit of $340 a week was also granted. This made a total cost of $369,274. In those three examples, we have a total sum of over $800,000. There is a very simple equation: Cause and effect. What takes place is that there is a strike, an application for social security benefit is made and the benefit is granted. We might remember that in those three examples we are talking about sections of the community which are certainly not the worst off.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that the proposed legislation is anti-unionist, that it is union bashing legislation. Let us spend one or two minutes examining the nature of a strike. We all know what it is but let us look at the decision to strike. Who makes it? The decision to strike is an act of free choice and is taken by a union or by union members to achieve one aim, and only one aim; that is, to advance what those engaged in the strike action judge to be their own interests. No other interests come into it. It is the ultimate industrial weapon and the weapon that has become all the more powerful as advancing technologies increase the power of the few over the many.

How is the strike weapon used? First of all, there is the classic method which is directed against an employer. That is obvious enough and it has been around for many years. Of course, sometimes the strike affects those who are not directly in the firing line but who happen to become involved. I refer to those people affected by the results of strikes because they find themselves, as sometimes happens on the waterfront, involved in events which do not concern them and over which they have no control. The second way in which the strike weapon is used is to bring social pressure to bear, and to bring it to bear in a way which is designed to try to induce a quick settlement. What is a classic example of that? A very striking example has been provided in New South Wales. It has been provided in the last 24 hours. Australian Associated Press reports that a 24-hour strike by 3,000 members of two associations has been so serious that the New South Wales Minister has alerted the Army that if the strike continues the Army could be needed. What has happened as a result of this strike ? Volunteers have had to go into hospitals to look after geriatric patients. There we have a weapon used which is known to affect directly and harshly people who are mentally ill or suffering from diseases of age.

The third way in which a strike can affect people, and affect people very broadly and generally, is by the sort of strike that is produced in the area of transport, the result of which is that men, women, small and large businessmen, who have nothing to do with or any reason to be involved in the strike, are directly and sometimes grievously affected by it. For those matters the Opposition professes no concern at all nor will it. It will pay some lip service to the consequences but it will say that there is an inalienable right to strike and to be funded when on strike. If we look at some of the examples of the widespread effects, we find them in transport strikes and in wharf strikes.

In this country, one of the problems that we face, and will continue to face, is the consequences of strikes that affect our overseas trade. Such strikes have given us a reputation as an unreliable supplier and will affect the long term trading reputation of this country. When that long term reputation is affected, the long term consequences for the country are grim unless we can recover the reputation that we would like to have. It is well known-it will be known to honourable members on the Opposition benches-that the Japanese view of the Australian industrial relations scene is such that Japan is seeking to diversify its reliance from Australia, from which it takes the majority of its raw material inputs for industry, to other countries. Why? It is because of the reputation we have earned, and, as the honourable member for Wills will know, we undoubtedly merit because of the actions which have taken place on the waterfront. We are a trading nation and, unless we trade and trade with Japan, the consequences will be felt by us all.

I have spent one or two minutes on the effects of strikes for the purpose of looking at this question: The need clearly to understand the costs of strikes. It is a cost which is ultimately borne by the entire community. Why should the community as a whole subsidise strikes? Effectively, that is what takes place if a payment goes to a family or to a spouse rather than to the person who is on strike. There is, in fact, no difference at all in effect. Why should the community as a whole provide economic support for those who strike, those who freely, deliberately and in pursuit of their self-interest, take industrial action against others and who frequently take such action regardless of any consequences to others, regardless on occasion of the cost to members of the community-indeed, it is sad to say, frequently regardless of that cost-and also regardless of the real suffering and hardship that strikes may inflict on others .

Does anybody in this House think that the strike that has taken place in the psychiatric hospitals in New South Wales is not a strike which inflicts severe hardship on others? If that strike were to go on for such a period as would allow the spouses of those on strike to be entitled to unemployment benefit under the Act, does anybody think that that would be a just result? Does anybody think that the kind of assistance that would be provided would be right, and that society should make that payment? I suspect that the answer that will be given at some stage in the evening will be to speak of hardship. Unquestionably, when people are on strike those involved suffer. Unquestionably, there are times when the members of the family of the person who is on strike will suffer.

There are three answers which need to be looked at. First of all, there is provision under the Act to provide payment in cases where there is real hardship . Secondly, whose decision is it to strike in the first place? It is the decision of the man, the woman or the union that goes out on strike. Thirdly, where does the balance of hardship lie? Does it lie with the community at large or does it lie with the individual who makes the decision or the union that makes the decision and does it in the interest of one thing and one thing only; that is, the pursuit of self-interest with no regard whatsoever for the consequences to the community?

Those who would oppose the legislation put forward would have to embrace this proposition: No matter what the consequences, no matter how arbitrary, capricious or bloody-minded and no matter what the cost, there is a group in this country that is entitled to special treatment and to a kind of support system against the consequences of its actions. Who else gets this sort of treatment in our society?

TALK.START.PARA: —Lawyers do not do too badly, and you are one.

—I might say that presidents of the Australian Council of Trade Unions do not do too badly either. The proposition will be rejected by the Australian Labor Party, and why? It will be rejected because that party is a party not of national interest but of sectional interest. Where there is a conflict between the national and the sectional interest, and where the conflict lies between the duties, the Labor Party owes to its owners and proprietors, to the interests that it supports, and the duties that it owes to the country--

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I had said that in the case of a conflict between sectional and perceived interests it would be a rare occasion indeed when the Opposition would depart from those interests which support it. I do not say that it does not happen but I most certainly say that it would be a rare occasion. What are we looking at here? It has been put by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) that this legislation is an exercise in family destitution-a most curious argument since, as I have pointed out, he went on to say that in any event the sums involved were only minimal. As I understood him, he said that every individual was entitled to go on strike. Nobody is disputing that, but we each of us have to accept the consequences of what we do.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue to which I have directed my remarks is as to whether the social security system should be available to persons to buttress them against the consequences of their own actions. The right to strike is an exercise in individual free will, for the advancement of a point of view that the individual or the union regards as being in that person's or in that union's self-interest- not for any social self-interest. The question then is whether in any way at all the exercising of that decision should be financed by recourse to the social security system. It is by recourse to that system that the three cases to which I have referred the House could be said to provide vivid examples of the way in which, shortly after strike action takes place, a large number of spouses apply for unemployment benefit. If these were genuine applications it would be one thing, but I doubt that anybody in this House would claim that they were genuinely made on behalf of people who were seeking work for the purpose of going on to full time employment. They were lodged simply for the purposes of providing more for the family income, therefore putting the family in a better position to ride through strikes.

Let us turn the coin around and take the case of a lock-out by a small family enterprise. It might say to its unionised staff: 'We are going to lock you out; you cannot come here to work. We will lock you out until you come to an agreement with us as to the terms and conditions under which you should be employed'. In those circumstances, would anybody in this House say that the owners of the business, or their spouses, would be entitled to seek unemployment benefit? Of course not; that would be arrant nonsense; it would be absurd. The reason is that that would be seeking from the taxpayer a subsidy against the consequences of their individual actions. Similarly, under this legislation we are concerned with the obverse side of the coin, the case in which unionists seek, through the medium of their spouses, to provide for themselves a financial buttress against the consequences of their own actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the most despicable pieces of legislation ever to come before this Parliament. My very informed friend, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) in an excellent speech on this occasion, as on an earlier occasion, has outlined the arguments which sustain that proposition. Essentially, what the legislation seeks is to use the wives and the children of workers who have chosen to exercise what is regarded as one of the characteristics of a free society-that is, the right to strike-as an instrument to try to prevent their exercising that right. The capacity for any honourable member to digest this despicable piece of legislation is not made easier by the defence which has just been advanced by the honourable member for North Sydney ( Mr Spender) being as he is, a member of one of the tightest, most highly organised, closed shop unions in the world. In other words, he is a Queen's Counsel, a member of a union which does not have to worry about going on strike to determine what its income shall be. It determines what that miserable income will be-some $1,000 a day or more-and also that no one shall have right of entry to membership except under certain conditions which it also determines. I will spend no more time than that on the remarks made by the honourable member for North Sydney. His hypocrisy condemns him out of his own mouth.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is labouring under the delusion that, with this piece of legislation, he is giving himself the second tool to go to the people on a double dissolution. I find it difficult at the best of times to follow the mind of the Prime Minister of this country, but in these circumstances I find it absolutely impossible. I understand that he thinks it good politics that his first tool shall be the fact that this Parliament has rejected his betrayal of a promise that he would not increase indirect taxation; that he proposes using as a tool the fact that his breaking of that promise has been frustrated by the Parliament. Apparently, he proposes to go to the people of Australia and say: 'Dear electors, I want you to return me because this awful Parliament, the combination of the Labor Party and the Democrats, will not allow me to impose additional indirect taxes on you'. That is a sign of his intelligence, but he now says that the second weapon in his armoury will be that he wants the people of Australia to say that they will endorse a proposal under which he will use the wives and the children of men and women who exercise their right to strike. He will say: 'I want to condemn them and want you to endorse me in that action'. All I can say on behalf of the Opposition is that we trust that the Prime Minister will summon up the courage, particularly after the defeats that he is about to suffer in the Lowe by-election and in the Victorian State election, to go to the people on a double dissolution with those two weapons in his armoury. We welcome it and challenge him to do it.

Let us look at the facts. The situation is that, of course, the right to strike has been brought into issue. As I have had cause to say previously, there is a marvellous difference between the perspective of the Prime Minister and this Government on this issue of the right to strike when they look at the situation in Poland, and their perspective when they look at the situation inside their own country. They have the clearest perspective, the clearest vision, that it is right that people in Poland should be able to organise freely in unions and, within such organisation, exercise the right to strike; that the Communist state should not be arrayed against them to prevent them from exercising that right. However, when it comes to the situation in this country the Government will use any piece of punitive legislation it can to try to deny or impede the exercising of that right.

In this Parliament recently I have had cause to refer to what must be a highly reputable source within conservative circles as to the fatuity of the recourse to such punitive legislation as this. I refer, of course, to a statement made in these precincts, at the Premiers Conference in August last year, by Sir Charles Court. It is appropriate, given the diabolical nature of this legislation, that we should recall the actual words used by Sir Charles Court in talking about resorting to punitive legislation to try to deal with an industrial relations situation. I repeat to the House the words used in these precincts last August by Sir Charles Court. At page 22 of the confidential transcript of the Premiers Conference he said:

After looking at the matter very closely, I am convinced that there is no set of rules which we can devise which will improve the situation if we cannot change the attitudes of people involved in the system. You can lay down the most diabolical rules, the most diabolical laws, and attempt to implement them; but if you do not have a spirit of co-operation in the matter nothing will work.
He returned to this point two pages later, when he said:
I come back to where I started: No system, no matter how clever the law or how diabolical it might be, will achieve a result if there is not goodwill on the part of everybody.

If there is an appropriate word to describe this legislation, it is the word ' diabolical'. Two grounds are proposed by the Government in purported justification of the legislation. There are the industrial relations grounds and of course there are the grounds that some people are ripping off the system. I will examine each of those two grounds. Honourable members opposite can bray as much as they like; they will not divert me. Let us look at the industrial relations ground. In respect of industrial relations I suggest that what I have quoted from Sir Charles Court makes the point that by passing diabolical laws we will not make people behave better. I preface anything else I have to say on this matter by repeating unequivocally to this House, in the context of this debate, what I have had cause to say before-that the trade unions of this country and individual members of individual trade unions make mistakes. They do at times make wrong decisions. they do at times undertake industrial action which I believe they should not undertake. But having said that, I repeat that we do not exhaust our intellectual responsibility in analysing these issues. We have to understand that in these issues fault simply does not lie on one side.

So it does not remain on the records here as merely the member for Wills making that assertion, I refer to the facts in respect of the analysis of fault situations. One example to which I can go immediately is in relation to the Loy Yang area, an area which has not been absent from the minds of the Prime Minister and this Government. I refer the House to what happened just last month in that area in regard to an industrial dispute. Over a period of some three years in the construction of what is known as the Big W station a set of safety procedures were worked out. They were arrived at in co-operation between the trade unions and the State Electricity Commission of Victoria. Those procedures in which the responsibility lay with the employer were then transferred into the building of the Loy Yang station.

On 12 February there was an accident in which a man fell a very considerable distance and injured himself very badly, suffering two broken vertebrae and broken arms. The safety hooter which was supposed to be sounded in these cicumstances was not working. No safety procedure was available and this man suffered untold agony for some time. The company was given seven days to bring the situation up to scratch. Within eight days another accident happened, on 20 February, when a man fell, breaking an arm and ribs. The hooter on this occasion was working but the loudspeaker was not. Those who wanted to rescue the man had no access to him. A crane had to be brought in and a box had to be built. In those circumstances the men refused to work for two days. They said that the employer had had three years; the responsibility had been put on the employer but the employer had not carried out that responsibility and the lives and limbs of workers were in danger.

In those circumstances the responsibility in this matter was crystal clear. It was not the fault of the worker and it was not the fault of the trade union; it was accepted to be the fault of the employer and in the event the employer paid all the wages of all those men who withdrew their labour for two days because there was a clear recognition that it was right, that the men and women involved in that situation should have withdrawn their labour. Whilst the responsibility was sheeted home where it should have been on that occasion, what would this Government have done in that situation had the strike gone on longer? It would have punished the wives and the children of those workers who properly had exercised their right to withdraw their labour when the employer had demonstrably been at fault.

That is a recent circumstance right in the heart of an area which this Government looks to. But do not let us rely simply on that. Let us look at what some academic writers dispassionately studying this area have had to say. I quote from an article by Clifford Donn, who was at the time a lecturer in economics at Macquarie University. In the Australian newspaper of 18 January 1977, on the question of the responsibility for strikes, he had this to say:

Some managers, politicians and journalists blame 'militant' unions for precipitating frequent strikes which are said to be damaging because they are unpredictable. In fact, strikes are often not nearly as difficult for managers to predict as is commonly believed. Many strikes are precipitated by unilateral management action which affects wages and working conditions. Often, workers and their representatives are not informed of such actions until the last minute. When unions are consulted it is usually after all the major decisions affecting the employees have already been taken. The management simply gives an order and expects it to be obeyed.

There is an asymmetry in the relationship between management and its employees: management can unilaterally make decisions affecting work conditions and insist that employees accept those decisions; employees can make no such unilateral changes. They can only resist the employer's decision by striking. For employers to pose in this situation, as they often do,-
And as their spokesmen do, I interpolate-
as the innocent victims of power-hungry militant unions is hypocritical nonsense .
I quote from the Australian of 2 December of the same year, 1977, under the heading 'Unionists not at fault in strikes, says consultant'. The article states :
At least 80 per cent of Australia's strikes and industrial unrest can be blamed directly on management and not unionists, a management consultant said this week .
Mr John Hood, who is in charge of the human resources department of PA Management Consultants Pty Ltd in Melbourne, said many strikes were caused by lack of communication.
Senior and middle management were not getting down to the shop floor. 'It's a ' 'them and us'' situation, and it's quite wrong', he said.

There are two totally independent analyses which confirm the point I have been making. Let us look at the statistics, the figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on industrial disputes in this country. For the last year for which an analysis of causes has been put forward, 1980, we find that 23 per cent of days lost are attributable to managerial policy and, in respect of the actual number of disputes, 39.7 per cent are attributed statistically to managerial policy. There we have it in the aggregate, there we have it in the theoretical analysis, and there, at Loy Yang, we have seen just in the last few weeks an illustration of what I have been talking about.

What do we find when we look at this first ground of industrial relations? We find that it is the greatest load of hypocritical nonsense for the Government to delude itself that it has properly analysed the situation simply by saying that when there is a strike it is the fault of the striker, because the evidence from the SEC in Victoria just a few weeks ago is that the men were entitled to go on strike because the management had seriously repudiated its responsibility for the industrial safety of the workers on the site. So much had it done that that it paid fully for the days lost by strike. There was a recognition of the fact that the workers were right. But what does this Government say in this situation ? It has introduced a piece of legislation which says in respect of a situation where the workers are justified: 'We, this compassionate Government, will make the wives and children of these people, who are justifiably withdrawing their labour, suffer'. Is there little reason that I say that this is one of the most despicable pieces of legislation to be brought into this chamber?

I now turn to the second ground advanced by the Government to support its legislation. It is that these people, the wives and the children of strikers, are engaged in a rip-off of the community. It is so convinced that these people are ripping off the community that it rushed in to pass this legislation. What a load of hypocrisy on the part of this Government! This Government has had since 18 December a report from a royal commissioner saying that the Income Tax Assessment Act should be amended so that the powers of the royal commission to pursue tax evaders in this community, assisted in their scheming by members of the profession followed by the honourable member for North Sydney, are increased . The royal commissioner needs this power to pursue not just people who are ripping off the community for a few hundred thousand dollars but people who are ripping off this community for billions of dollars. The Government has had that report since 18 December. Has it rushed off to frame legislation in terms of what the commissioner has asked? Of course it has not. Three months have now gone and the Government has refused to bring in the legislation for which the commissioner has asked.

Let us just look at what the royal commissioner has had to say about those people who are ripping off the community with the assistance of members of the legal profession. This is what the royal commissioner has to say about that. I will read again to the House what he had to say in paragraph 2.01 of his report. He said:

The Commission's investigations into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers' Union has led it, to the surprise of many, to the tax avoidance industry. This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years, at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. Unfortunately this industry carried with it a serious detriment to the interests of government and the Australian community. The detriment was two-fold: in the first place it diverted from the Treasury tax which would prima facie be payable on income of taxpayers; in the second place it diverted the tax payable by those engaged in that industry. The amounts involved are very large indeed, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars per year or more . . . It has introduced into the community a class of people, almost invariably the highest earners, who pay little or no tax and make no contribution in that way as citizens to their fair share of community costs.
He concluded:
In addition it has made more difficult for government the task of providing for the community as a whole a more equitable and reduced taxation burden.

In the few minutes that are left let me share with honourable members what the commissioner revealed in the transcript of the way in which members of the profession of the honourable member for North Sydney have aided and abetted these schemes which are costing the community billions of dollars. Let us see what they have done. I refer to page 5756 of the transcript of the royal commission on 3 December. This is what the commissioner said after it had been revealed that the lawyers and accountants sit down and arrange their scheme in a way in which within a matter of five minutes they do a deal which costs billions of dollars. They sit down and just swap money, steal from one company and give to another. They pass money on in a way that costs us billions of dollars. What did the commissioner say in respect of that? What did he say about the lawyers who facilitate this practice? This is what he had to say:

What would be the position if a man who was a very good driver was offered a job by two other men: his job was to drive those men, say, to the CBA at Blacktown in a car and his instructions were to sit outside the bank with the engine running while these two men-who coincidentally had masks on and guns in their hands, and he said, I do not want to know what you are doing in there and please do not tell me, and what is more I have taken senior counsel's advice that I am not to know what you are doing. Is he relieved of liability for being an accessory to that fact.

That is what we have. We have members of the legal profession and taxation profession in this country aiding and abetting these schemes. They are ripping off billions of dollars. We have a royal commissioner saying to this Government: 'Change the law so I can smash this industry'. There is no legislation for this purpose yet the Government will bring in legislation to attack the wives and children of people exercising their right in a democratic community. This is the height of hypocrisy. The Government will be judged accordingly by the community if it ever summons up the guts to go to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just seen a display by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) which was simply an act of grandstanding for the 10 supporters he has behind him. The fact is that the case to which he referred at Loy Yang-the case to which he has referred so often-is not even applicable to this piece of legislation. He told us that the workers were out for two days and the employers paid them for the lost wages. But the facts of life are that a week needs to pass before a person becomes even partly eligible for the provisions which exist under the legislation.
—Get your hand out of your pocket.

—The honourable member should just listen because he has a bit to learn too. As a result of 20 minutes of screaming and shouting by the honourable member for Wills every Australian turned down the volume of his radio . I can deliver my address at exactly the same volume. The previous speaker-I will not refer to him as I would like to-described this legislation as 'the most despicable piece of legislation to come before the Parliament'. He used the word 'diabolical' on many occasions. I want to remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker-and you probably do not need reminding-that in 1948, during the time of the Chifley Labor Government, a special sub-committee headed by Mr Chifley and including the late Dr Evatt and the then Minister for Social Security, Mr McKenna, advised, following consideration of this subject: 'that all unions represented at the conference in Sydney accepted the principle that the Commonwealth could not permit unemployment benefits to be used for financing strikes'. That was only 34 years ago! Tonight we have heard words such as 'diabolical' and 'the most despicable piece of legislation to ever come before the Parliament'. How honourable members opposite have changed! There is one thing that the Opposition is doing to Australia today that it did when it was in government between 1973 and 1975. It changed this legislation to enable a lot of these things to happen. Oh, the honourable member can sit there like a harpist. He has about as much sense as the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), sitting there playing an imaginary violin. What a clown! What an ungifted clown he is in this Parliament. As I was saying--
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw the personal reflection.

—I withdraw. For the sake of the debate I withdraw. I withdraw my comments and reflection on the honourable member as long as he leaves the violin alone. One of the problems with this country today is that there is always a group of people prepared to stand up and justify why something should continue to exist. Opposition speakers in this debate this afternoon, in a previous debate on this subject some weeks ago and in the other chamber have tried to portray this Government as proposing this legislation simply as an election gimmick on which to go to the people. I suggest to all members of the Parliament that if the case they are presenting here in support of the retention of this provision is as strong as they would like us and the Australian public to believe, there is no way in the world that they would carry on with the speeches to which we have been subjected from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wills talked emotionally about women and children. This is always a good tactic. We always get back to the women and children. The fact is that the decision whether or not to strike is made by the worker in the house. My background is not like that of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Speaker) who, because of his accomplished legal background, was denigrated by the honourable member for Wills. I was on the Australian waterfront as an industrial officer in the 1960s. I know what strikes are like. I know how some people are hurt when the decision is made to go out. I know that there are always a number of people who are dragged out against their will. I understand that completely and utterly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are contradicting what he said.

—The honourable member should go back to his seat, be quiet and have a shave. When a decision is made collectively to go on strike the people who make the deliberate decision to stop work and to stand up on a matter of principle cannot expect the taxpayers to dip into their pockets and say: 'We will help you to stand on your principles'. Provisions already exist in this legislation which enable the Government, through the Department of Social Security, to assist those people who are suffering extreme hardship.
—We will give you half the parity wage.

—What the honourable member for Bonython, an academic without any realism in his body from head to toe, is saying is that if a unionist who has $25,000 in the bank takes a decision to go out on strike his wife has an unfettered and automatic right to go along to the department of Social Security, knock on the door, and say: 'I want a cheque because my husband has stopped work '. That is all the honourable member has done in this debate. He has oversimplified the matter. He tried to talk simply about women and children. He has dismissed the fact that provisions exist and provisions will be maintained under special benefits to look after those people who are unfairly and unduly hurt and who are put into a position of suffering as a result of this legislation. Listening to the honourable member for Wills, one would think that the only people who ever suffer setbacks as a result of strikes are those who make the decision to go on strike. Many a business that has provided employment-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition can laugh. The honourable member for Wills does not understand. That is why he will never be the Prime Minister of this country. Strikes can absolutely cripple small business and they can smash big business. What is more-this is what he does not seem to understand- when an industry goes out on strike it can have effects so far down the line that people whom we do not even think of, who are unseen and unheard, can also suffer. People employed in other businesses which are completely unrelated to the cause which is being pursued also can be destroyed and crippled. That is something which the honourable member does not understand. He has lived in the trades hall for so long that he has not been able to see behind the brick walls. It is about time that he came to understand basic economics.
—Your ticker will go on strike.

—The honourable member for Wills is patting his heart as if he could not care less. It is about time the Government of Australia stood up and pursued what is right. For too long now we have been prepared to go along with namby-pamby machines and simply say: 'We might hurt somebody and we cannot take it back'. As I have said, a unionist who has $25,000 in his bank account is able now, by the existing legislation, to dip into the taxpayer's pocket. I repeat that for the family which has nothing, provisions exist in this legislation to continue assistance so that that family is not reduced to the state that the honourable member for Wills tried to portray.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney referred before the suspension of the sitting for dinner to the actual costs involved. Compared with a national budget of $40 billion and social security costs of $11 billion perhaps about $2m in not much money. But it is the principle involved which matters. I do not know how members of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine can stand up, shake their heads and say: 'You cannot take this back from the people'. I will go into a little more history for the benefit of honourable members opposite. It was only the changes to legislation made by the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) in 1973 which brought this current situation upon us now. He was the man who in 1973 lacked the foresight to see what his alterations to legislation would cause. Now he is trying to offer himself as the alternative Prime Minister of this country.

Before beginning my speech I was asked to speak for only 10 minutes in order to allow other speakers to speak, as the debate on this legislation is to finish at 9 o'clock to allow other legislation to come on. I sum up my remarks on this Bill by saying that we are debating a proposition whereby the Government is stating to the people of Australia that, if somebody is suffering dire consequences as a result of industrial action, provisions exist to support them and assist them through that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by 'dire'?

—There is no doubt that such consequences exist. But what we are saying is that no longer can we tolerate a situation whereby, when people take the decision to go out on strike, the Australian taxpayers are going to rush in and make a contribution to their pockets to assist them to continue their strike and to continue to allow them to maintain nest eggs that they may have built up in the past. That is what it is all about. If Labor speakers believe, to use words of the honourable member for Wills, that this is the most despicable and diabolical piece of legislation ever to come before the Parliament, it is time they went back into the history a little and noted the attitude of Chifley and Evatt and people such as that towards legislation of this kind. All the Opposition is doing is trying to grandstand, politic and rip at the hearts of people. There is nothing to what the Opposition is saying. It is trying to rip at people's hearts in emotional argument without foundation. The sooner this legislation gets through this chamber and into the Senate, and is passed, the better it will be for a country that is being slowly consumed and destroyed by the attitudes of Opposition members which prevail here tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech given by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) is indicative of the type of paranoia which exists in the Government ranks about strikes. The Government has an unreasoned approach to industrial relations. The type of outburst which we have just heard is one of the reasons that 40.2 per cent of strikes in 1981 were caused by managerial irresponsibility. When one looks at the honourable member for Fadden, who would claim to be a spokesman for the employer class, there can be no doubt that the figure was 40.2 per cent. In fact, it makes one wonder why 90.2 per cent of strikes were not caused by the inflammatory attitude of people such as the honourable member for Fadden. As I have said, Government members are obsessed with strikes and strikers. They have lost their reason and their ability to deal with industrial relations. They have reached the stage where they can no longer cope and are willing to bring legislation into this Parliament which will strike out at women and children. That is the depth to which they have sunk in their attempts to handle the industrial relations system in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: On 18 November 1981 I was very proud to join in the debate on the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) when it first came before this Parliament. Unfortunately that legislation was passed by this House but it was successfully defeated in the Senate. I have no doubt that after the Government passes this legislation on to the Senate again this evening this Bill will be struck out once again. The Government will show its loss of reason by attempting to have an early election on whether one can beat women and children over the head because the husband or the breadwinner in the family might be in a position where he cannot work. As evidenced in the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) and the explanatory notes he has issued with this Bill, the Government has taken a dishonest and a disgraceful approach to this matter. In both the second reading speech and the explanatory notes the Minister referred to the application of this renewed industrial action. In fact, the Minister and the Government know that to be blatantly not true. This legislation will militate against those people involved in lockouts and those people who, for no reason of their own, are involved in industrial action.

A number of examples have been brought forward by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). The most specific example which comes to mind is a circumstance in the car industry-an industry which is spread right throughout Australia-in which because of a decision taken by workers in one plant workers in another plant may be stood down. For example, when the workers at the Broadmeadows plant of the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd went on strike, workers in New South Wales were stood down. They had no vote in whether the Broadmeadows workers went on strike; they had no chance to change the attitude of the workers at Broadmeadows. Nevertheless, they were stood down and under this legislation their wives and children would have been deprived of any sustenance. The Minister for Transport in his second reading speech said that strikers make the decision to strike against the rest of the community. I think I have pointed out quite clearly that the people employed by Ford in New South Wales had absolutely no chance at all of affecting the strike that occurred at Broadmeadows.

The Government has perverted the definition of the word 'strike'. In this legislation-this is made clear in the Minister's speech, in the speech of the honourable member for Fadden and in the speech of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender)-the Government has attempted to whip up an emotional climate of hostility towards people who are engaged in industrial action and more particularly against their families. It is important to note the situation in Australia in regard to strikes. According to figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the first six months in 1981, which are the latest figures issued on industrial disputes in Australia, 64.7 per cent of disputes lasted two days or less. Only 7.5 per cent of disputes lasted more than 10 days. To me those figures do not indicate a country which is wracked by massive industrial unrest. In fact, Australia seems to have a fairly reasonable industrial record. In those six months only 10 per cent were involved in any industrial action that lasted 10 days or more.

It is more informative to look at the reasons given for a number of strikes. As I said earlier, 40.2 per cent of strikes were caused by what the ABS classified as managerial problems and 19.2 per cent were caused by what the ABS classified as working conditions, the majority of which were safety conditions and things such as that. Only 24.9 per cent of the strikes in that period were caused by wage disputation. Less than a quarter of the strikes were over wage disputation. Nearly half the strikes were caused by managerial incompetence. That suggests to me that rather than the Government bringing in legislation against women and children it should be bringing some proper industrial legislation into this country which will attempt to educate management in circumstances that will allow it to be less inflammatory than some Government members have been in this debate this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would give in all the time.

—We hear the voice from the bush. The honourable member would not know what industrial relations was unless it involved going to some local government conference in Perth where he was surcharged by his own council. He is a man with a great record of negotiation! I think the most important thing that we have to look at in considering this legislation is how much it will save the Government. The Minister has not said at any time that this legislation will save millions, tens of millions or hundreds of millions of dollars. I put it to the Parliament tonight that this legislation would save only thousands of dollars. The best example that the Minister could come up with in his second reading speech was one isolated instance where $40,000 was involved. Honourable members can bet their lives that if there were any other intances the Minister would give us a whole schedule of how many millions of dollars this legislation would save. Quite frankly, it will save the Government peanuts. It is a method of beating trade unionists over the head and making an attack upon them and their children. It is typical of the type of action of this Government. It is all too keen to attack those who are least able to defend themselves; it is all too keen to attack the disadvantaged in this country. The Government's attacks on child care, pensioners and migrants have been outlined quite frequently in this Parliament in the last few weeks. This legislation is just another attack on women and children, the most disadvantaged group of people in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The people that I am most concerned will be affected by this legislation are the many migrants who live in my electorate. They are people who have recently come to Australia and are in the most fragile economic circumstances of any people in the country. They are trying to make a new living in Australia and are battling to find work and some way to exist. Sometimes they get involved in industrial disputes in the rather large manufacturing industries in my electorate, but they have no control over them because they started interstate and the employers have closed the plant down. Migrants do not understand why they cannot get some relief from the Government; they do not understand why this Government is trying to attack them in their attempts to make new lives for themselves in Australia.

I think it is very important to look at this Government's stand as compared with that of governments in the rest of the world. I think it is quite fair and proper to contrast the actions of this Government with the approach of the communist Government in Poland. It is absolutely no different in its approach to trade unionists and their families. The approach of this Government in the repression of workers and workers' rights parallels very much what the military regime in Poland started to do in the last 12 months. Perhaps that is one of the reasons why this Government has absolutely no intention of debating in this Parliament the situation in Poland. On one hand the Government bleats. The present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) and his colleagues in the National Country Party are the ones who say every day how the trade unionists are trying to bring the country down. They say: 'We have to do something about them. We must have penal clauses in legislation to gaol them. We must have clauses in legislation to drive their wives and children into poverty'. They say that what the trade unionists are doing is terrible. But on the other hand the same spokesmen for the Government say: 'Isn't it terrific that the workers in Poland are going to bring the Government down?' It makes one realise that the split personality of the honourable member for Fadden is very much indicative of the double standard the the Government has in regard to most issues. I am quite happy, as are other members of the Opposition, to stand here tonight and support the wives and children of trade unionists and attempt to get them a fair go from this Government. We are more than happy to fight any election that the Government may try to win on this Bill. I have no doubt that when the Australian people are asked about their attitude to this Government and its attacks on the disadvantaged, women, children and pensioners, they will resoundly adopt the position of the Opposition. If the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wants to use this Bill as grounds for a double dissolution we will most heartily welcome the chance to ask the Australian people their views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been heartily disappointed by the contributions that have been made to this debate by members of the Opposition. What the Opposition has not told us is that the legislation that presently exists is unique in the world. No other country in the world where people, of their own free will, decide to go on strike pays benefits to their families from the social welfare budget. That provision is unique to this country; it does not exist anywhere else in the world. That measure was brought in by a previous Labor Government, headed by Mr Whitlam. No doubt it was brought in to pacify the supporters of the Australian Labor Party in the union movement. In no way can it be justified as a measure that should be supported by the Australian people. The ALP is asking the Australian taxpayer to pay for those people who by their own determination want to go on strike. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), in his contribution to this debate, tried to tell us that his measure was designed to prevent strikes. It has nothing whatever to do with preventing strikes. Anybody in this country who wants to withdraw his labour has a perfectly legitimate right to do so. The real question is: Who pays? The Opposition wants the Australian taxpayer to pay the costs of those people who, of their own free will, want to go on strike. If they want to go on strike, that is their decision, and it is their constitutional right to do so. But if they do they must also expect to accept the obligations that go along with that decision and not to have them picked up by the taxpayer.
—What if the strike is justified-Loy Yang?

—I welcome the interjection by the honourable member for Wills. In his contribution to the debate he referred to the situation at Loy Yang. He tried to have the Australian people believe that all strikes were about safety conditions . He did not make one mention of people who strike for more money. Honourable members opposite have to accept the balanced situation; they have to accept both sides of the equation. Some people go on strike in order to get more money and then want the taxpayer to support them while they are on strike.
