If people go on strike and indulge in industrial action in order to help their own financial situations they cannot expect other workers who continue in their occupations and who pay their taxes legitimately to support them while they are on strike. That is a totally unfair and unreasonable expectation. That is the way in which Australian people will see the situation, and rightly so.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I make in the brief time available to me is that we must remember at all times that the money that is paid in benefits to the wives of striking workers is paid out of the social welfare budget. That reduces the amount of money that is available to those people who genuinely need help through the social welfare system.

The Opposition would have us take away money from these people who genuinely need to be supported by social welfare. Opposition members cannot have it both ways. They will say that they will pay out of the social welfare budget people who go on strike to try to get more money for themselves and to have more money in the bank and to be better off. At the same time the Opposition will say to the elderly and disabled people in this country that it cannot give them all the support they need because it has to pay union members who are on strike. I do not believe that the Australian people will wear that. I am surprised that a party which claims to be genuinely concerned about the disadvantaged people in our society supports such a measure. I challenge members of the Opposition, if they share that genuine concern for the disabled and needy in our society, not to support the point of view they have proposed and in fact to vote with the Government on this measure.

I am also surprised at the protestations that have been made by the Australian Democrats in another place. They too try to wear their hearts on their sleeves and claim to be concerned about the needy people in our society. They, too, are adopting exactly the same stance as the members of the Opposition in this place. It is my view that if the Australian Democrats in another place want to carry the burden of their own decisions they will have to think very carefully about how they will vote when this legislation reaches the other chamber. If they decide that they will not vote with the Government on this legislation they must carry the odium and responsibility for that decision. They cannot have it both ways. What the Democrats are doing is taking money away from the genuine needy and giving it to the greedy. That is what it boils down to, and that is what members of the Opposition in this place are all about.

I am disappointed that I do not have more time to speak tonight. I would have liked to make some other points but in order to give other members an opportunity to speak I will conclude my remarks. With the points I have tried to make very briefly I hope I have urged all members in this House to support the Government on this legislation. I urge members of the Opposition to show their concern for the needy and the genuine taxpayers and also to support the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us tonight should be seen very clearly for what it is: It is a blatant and clumsy attempt by the Government to bludgeon unionists into submission by causing as much personal hardship as possible. Why is this legislation coming forward? It is coming forward simply because the Government thinks it can win votes by bashing unionists and their families. The Government hopes, by this tactic, to take away the attention of the electorate from the real problems of this community. The effect that seven years of Fraser Government has had on the Australian family can be seen in terms of interest rates, taxation policies, inflation, health insurance policy and the declining value of the pension. That is the real effect that the Fraser Government has had on Australia. The Government is attempting to disguise that effect by bashing unionists.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation not only attempts to misuse the Social Services Act but also represents a fundamental abuse of the rights of a significant group of Australian citizens. The provisions of this Bill refuse payment of unemployment benefit to the spouses of those who fail the work test or those on strike even though the spouses in their own right qualify for that benefit: Even though the spouses qualify in their own right the benefit will not be paid to them. That is what this legislation is all about. Clearly, the legislation is totally insupportable. The Government cannot unilaterally deprive one section of the community of its rights in this way and expect to maintain the respect of the Australian community. The Australian community cannot and will not support this piece of legislation which attempts to achieve an industrial relations advantage by hurting the innocent parties affected by dispute through no fault of their own. Newspaper editorials support this view. I will quote from some of them. The Age comments:
Unemployment benefits should be regarded as a right for people jobless through no fault of their own. They are not a privilege and they most certainly are not a plaything for politicians.

We have seen tonight members of the Government using this issue as a plaything for themselves to try to divert attention from the real issues in this community . the Canberra Times reports the proposals in these terms:
. . . a threat to the right of freedom of opinion, a denial of justice to taxpayers, and a perversion of the conventional definition of what constitutes unemployment.

So much for the reception these proposals will receive in society at large. The hypocrisy of the Government in this matter is all too clear. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in introducing this legislation made no mention of the effect it would have on the children or the spouses of striking unionists.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your school children? The teachers don't think about the kids.

—A Government member has referred to a very important issue which I think highlights what this Government is all about. On the one hand, it brings in legislation which attacks children but, on the other hand, this morning in this Parliament the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) said that to protect the interests of children he had to implement the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act in the Australian Capital Territory. That is having an incredibly divisive effect on this community, and it shows the hypocritical attitude of this Government. We see this in its handling of industrial relations issues. Its one policy is to attack unionists; this legislation attacks the children and the wives of unionists. What the Government does is deliberately provocative and contributes nothing towards stable industrial relations in this country. That is what members of the Opposition are aiming for and what the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) was talking about when he spoke in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have constructive views; this Government does not. The situation in the Capital Territory today demonstrated this. I will prove that to the House tonight. The Australian Capital Territory has had rolling strikes by members of the Australian Teachers Federation, which action did not have universal support amongst its members; I acknowledge that. It did not have the total support of the Australian Capital Territory Council of Parents and Citizens Associations. What happened after 300 teachers were stood down under the CE(EP) legislation? There is now a unanimous support from the teachers. That action has brought them together and made them more determined. Half an hour ago I received a telex from the Australian Capital Territory Council of Parents and Citizens Associations. It reads:

The ACT Council of Parents and Citizens Associations deplores the application of the CEEP Act in the present industrial dispute involving ACT teachers in government schools and calls for the immediate rescinding of the directive to the Chief Education Officer to stand down teachers.
I ask Government members to listen to this:

This highly controversial and divisive legislation is inappropriate to a local school system where children are inevitably the victims of actions by any parties to aggravate or prolong industrial tension. Applying the CEEP Act will have damaging effects on the ACT schools system long after the present dispute has been settled.

But this is the action of this Government. That is what it wants; to provoke industrial reaction. It wants to destroy the whole industrial foundation of this country. It has no plan; it is purely provocative. This legislation before us tonight is a part of that attempt to provoke unionists. The Social Services Amendment Bill should be seen for what it is; a political ploy to try to beef up the Government's tarnished image in the community and to draw attention away from its disastrous mismanagement of the economy. My Labor colleagues on this side of the House and I hope that in the future the Government will concentrate on the development of effective social policies which provide maximum assistance to the most needy in our society and effective industrial relations policies which promote constructive and equitable means for the settlement of disputes, not the sort of legislation we have before us tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesitated to enter into this debate because it is obvious that the Government has no business of any substance before the House and we are merely accommodating the Government at this point. But in case it should be thought that the Opposition ran away from this debate I take up the cudgels and point out that many of the speakers on this side of the House spoke previously when this proposition came before us. To date the Government has in no way given any justification for its proposition. Some of the speeches made tonight by honourable members on the Government side were quite deplorable. Clearly the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) has shown his lack of concern for the women and children of workers. His attitude, in seeking to take away assistance for supporting mothers, is well recorded and well established. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), with his constant interjections, is well known by this side of the House as being clearly on record as saying that he does not support the right to strike. I hope that he challenges me on that, but he had better check his Hansard before he does.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate really should come down to a level where there can be reason on the merits of the issue. I refer to a report of some substance that was brought down by the South Australian Liberal Government. This report was written by Mr Frank Cawthorne, who was appointed by the Tonkin Government in November 1980 to review independently the South Australian Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Mr Cawthorne was President of the Industrial Relations Society of South Australia from 1978 to 1980 and wrote a special handbook for industrial advocates. Clearly it is not one that the honourable member for Fadden has read. Mr Cawthorne was previously the industrial research officer for the Public Service Board and industrial advocate for the South Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the Metal Industries Association of South Australia. I suggest that the gentleman has credentials that cannot be disputed.

In that lengthy report dealing with industrial relations Mr Cawthorne rejected some of the major industrial reforms proposed by the Liberal Party in South Australia and the policy on which the Tonkin Government was elected in 1979. The proposals he rejected included compulsory pre-strike secret ballots, cooling off periods and the use of sanctions generally in industrial disputes. I suggest that this attempt by the Government is just one of those things; a sanction against the trade union movement. The Cawthorne report rejects other sanctions proposed by the Liberal Party, including legislative codes of conduct, a requirement for unions to pay a monetary bond as a precondition to the granting of additional wages or benefits and heavy fines for unionists who strike during the life of their award. They were all rejected by Mr Cawthorne. Several other recommendations by Mr Cawthorne would reverse the thrust of both State and Federal government industrial policies in some areas. He said:
. . . there is no need for an industrial ombudsman to protect individuals' rights.

He recommended that an existing limitation on the Industrial Commission's power to award full preference to unionists be removed from the Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the tribunal be permitted to grant preference at the point of engagement and on termination of employment. That is in a report by someone appointed by a Liberal Government in South Australia and goes to the heart of some of the sanctimonious Bills that this Government tries to bring in to try further to subject the trade union movement. But the Government in another place has said that it is not concerned with the merits of strike action; it is concerned with the costs of strike action. Let us take that question of costs and see how dinkum this Government is on costs to the economy and to the Australian taxpayer.

This Government has been in power for too long. Its record in industrial relations is shocking but its record in industrial health and safety is abominable. More than 1,000 Australian workers are killed in the workshop every year. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) finds that humorous. I will repeat it . More than 1,000 Australian workers are killed at work every year. More than 300,000 Australian workers are injured at work each year. In 1979 the total cost of industrial accidents was estimated to be nearly $4 billion. The Government has said that it is concerned about costs and about the economy. What has it done about health and safety in the workshops?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—Nothing. Who could ever feel that this Government was genuine? It uses the industrial field as it treated the social welfare field when it kicked around the pensioners, when the pensioners became a political football. Now it is the workers in this country, both in the cities and in the rural areas, who suffer and who are used as political footballs by this Government. If we want to talk about this issue rationally I suggest that the Government should put forth people who have worked in the industrial field, the front men, those who have been up front dealing with industrial disputes and who know what they are about. I would have respect for Government members with those credentials. But if they do not know what they are talking about I suggest they shut up. In particular I suggest that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) should shut up when it comes to industrial relations matters. He said: 'No one denies the workers' right to strike'. I suggest that is nothing but a pious platitude. Could it be that that same honourable member is speaking for his legal fraternity, the industrial mercenaries, the vultures of industrial relations, the only people who make a cop out of industrial disputes? Employers lose, workers lose; the only people who make anything are the industrial mercenaries, the lawyers. Their organisation would be the greatest closed shop in Australia, as is well known, and the doctors would be runners up.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer again to the article on the Cawthorne report and mention a couple of points that he made about industrial mercenaries. The article states:
'There is no legal magic wand whereby industrial troubles can be whisked away', he said.

'A significant step in industrial relations will be taken once it is generally accepted that given the nature of our society some conflict is inevitable, that there are no simple legislative or other answers to industrial conflict, that not all conflict is going to be resolved without resort to industrial action ( and indeed that not all industrial action is necessarily a bad thing), and that good industrial relations cannot be achieved through confrontation backed by the law.
That is, the industrial mercenaries.

In my previous position I dealt for 12 years with industrial officers who were the front men in industrial disputes. I respected them because they were trying to achieve what most union officials were likewise trying to achieve but not at the sacrifice of their responsibilities to their members. Kinds of disputes need to be mentioned. Firstly, there needs to be a recognition that trade unions are a proper and legitimate part of the industrial scene in Australia. They are not renegades. They are not something that has been imported from Moscow. They are very much a part of the industrial scene, very much a part of the Australian scene. They are associations registered under the Acts of the parliaments of Australia. They have a role to fulfil in the industrial scene, a role that is recognised by fair-minded people of Australia. The traditions of the trade union movement within Australia are respected by honest Australians.

The function of a union is to assist workers in maintaining and improving the standards of their working lives. Because of the very nature of the role and function of trade unions they are in an adversary position with the employer. This Government seeks to destroy the effectiveness of the trade union movement in its legitimate role to maintain and improve living standards. This attack, on the wives and children in most cases of workers, is aimed at destroying the workers' legitimate and legally recognised association of trade unions. I do not think that the Australian people will fall for this humbug that this Government is putting up. I am sure that the Australian people believe in trade unions, believe they are part of Australia and believe they need to be protected against the kind of vultures that we see in the industrial field, in the legal system and on the Government benches.
