TALK.START.PARA: —May I have the indulgence of the House to raise a point of procedure on this matter. Before debate is resumed on this Order of the Day, I would like to suggest that it may suit the convenience of the House to have a general debate covering this motion, the motion to take note of the Ministerial Statement on defence, Government decisions and the motion to take note of the Memorandum of Arrangements for the Tactical Fighter Aircraft. I suggest, therefore, Mr Deputy Speaker that you permit the subject matter of the three Orders of the Day to be discussed in this debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering the three matters?
—I raise a point of order. The Opposition will be seeking to move a motion in relation to one of the reports. I take it that this procedure will not inhibit that taking place?
—The honourable member for Corio may be assured that that opportunity will remain at the disposal of the House.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Following on the comments made by the Minister, I find it extraordinary but characteristic that the Government is trying to stifle debate on defence issues. What is really being proposed here is that three major statements by the Minister for Defence be telescoped into one debate.
—Order! There is no point of order. The House being in accord with the proposal, I will allow that course to be followed. The question is: ' That the House take note of the paper'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was mentioning, in this debate the Government is telescoping three major statements by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) into one shortened debate. What we are talking about here is a massive expenditure by the Government on defence. We are not arguing about the expenditure on defence but we are talking about something of the order of $3,000 worth of equipment and this House is not having an adequate opportunity to discuss this expenditure by the Government. The Government has a very poor record, as all members of this House will recognise, in informing the House of its thinking behind its defence expenditures. The Parliament, and particularly the committees of the Parliament, have had great difficulty in trying to get the necessary information on the very significant issue of defence on which to base an intelligent debate in this House. That is as it may be. It has been characteristic of the Government for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw to the attention of the House a comment that I made some years ago, in fact in October 1976 just prior to the release of the Government's White Paper on defence. At that time I pointed out:

There are already signs that the future defence debate in Australia may degenerate into a political auction over equipment. Just as rhetoric does not constitute a defence policy, neither does a shopping basket full of assorted military goodies. The purchases must be related to total defence requirements and not to individual services' isolated bids.

I went on in that article, which was published in the Pacific Defence Reporter, to point out that announcements of equipment decisions should explain their rationale. I was very interested to note that the British Government, in its recent White Paper on defence, which foreshadowed the disposition of HMS Invincible, stated:

We have done this in terms of real defence output-the roles our forces undertake and how they should in future be carried out-and not in terms of organisation. It is increasingly essential that we tackle the business of defence this way and manage it in terms of total capability rather than service shares.

That kind of approach is foreign to this Government, which continues to approve single Service bids in the vain hope that they will add up to a defence policy. It is for this reason that I, on behalf of the Opposition, move the following amendment:
Delete all words after 'That' and substitute in their place-
this House requests that as a matter of urgency the joint parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence consider and report on-
(a) the relevance of an aircraft carrier to Australia's current and perceived strategic environment;
(b) the role of an aircraft carrier in the defence force structure of Australia ;
(c) the effects of the purchase of an aircraft carrier on the future defence procurement program;
and that the Committee be requested to report to this Parliament on this matter not later than 1 September 1982, unless an extension of this date is approved by the House.
That amendment will be seconded by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) who will speak to the motion next.

I have pointed out already that the Minister's statements on both the FA18 and the acquisition of the aircraft carrier are singularly deficient in providing a rationale for the purchase. No attempt was made to consider other options in performing the ascribed anti-submarine warfare role of the carrier. First, one should ask: Do we need a seaborne air platform for this task at all? One of the purposes of the FA18, as described by the Minister, is long range maritime interdiction. The P3Cs-that is, the Orion aircraft-are being equipped with Harpoon missiles. We still have the F111s for reconnaissance and they can be fitted for anti-shipping and anti-submarine warfare. These are the kinds of considerations that are not discussed either in the statement by the Minister on the FA18 or in that by the Minister on the acquisition of the Invincible. We can look at the whole question in a new light. Let me make one point: Australia itself is an aircraft carrier. It ranges the two oceans of our immediate concern -the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. Where is there in any of the Government 's statements a consideration of the option of using land-based aircraft as distinct from a handful of helicopters on a seaborne platform which has, on all expert advice, very limited capacity? It is outside the realms of reality for any navy, let alone the Royal Australian Navy, to patrol effectively Australia's long sea lines of communication which cross the Indian and Pacific Oceans. No navy in the world, not even the United States Navy, would be capable of undertaking that responsibility. But there are focal points where hostile submarines are likely to operate and these can be protected because they are close to our shores. For that reason the use of land-based aircraft is an option that should be considered but it has not been taken up by the Minister or by the Government in either the debates in this House or the statements that have been made.

Apart from the consideration of role and performance there is in the Minister's statement no attempt to relate the purchase to Australia's current or perceived strategic environment. That is precisely why we have placed such a term of reference in the amendment which we propose. Not only is there no statement relating to Australia's current or perceived strategic environment; the Minister also absolves the purchase from any rationale at all. He stated:
There is no single scenario or contingency for which this ship is being acquired.

That is a curious statement and a damning indictment of the manner in which the Government approaches defence. The Government is attached to a replacement syndrome-that is, replacing one item of equipment with a similar item. As the Minister no doubt would readily admit, that does not require much intellectual effort but it does detract from our total defence effort. The purchase of the aircraft carrier is a splendid example of this Government's penchant for fighting the last war. We all know and agree that the ship is cheap; but are we- I ask this question very seriously-to behave like a tourist in Hong Kong who goes broke trying to save money? The Minister, evidently to his own satisfaction , dismisses in a few lines the very real crticisms that have been raised by members of the Government-certainly in the Senate-of the vulnerability of carriers in modern warfare conditions. We know that no decision has yet been made as to whether the ship will retain the Sea Dart air defence missile system. Even with the Sea Dart there are grave doubts that the Invincible is capable of defending herself against missiles, submarines, aircraft and other surface craft . We know also that the ship will not have any vertical short take-off and landing aircraft of the Harrier type. The Minister has already indicated that. With the United States version of the Sea Harrier, the AV8B, which is currently valued at something in the order of $20m each, there is a reasonable doubt that we will ever see such an aircraft aboard the Invincible. A carrier that is so defenceless will require a large escort of destroyers, frigates and land-based aircraft cover. This type of deployment will distort not only our naval force structure but also at the same time our total defence structure. It makes a nonsense of the whole Government justification of the purchase. I have been invited to talk about justification. I will quote what the vendor of the Invincible had to say about the product that he was selling. We have been talking about the vulnerability of the Invincible. On 23 February 1982 in the House of Commons, the Secretary of State for Defence, Mr Nott, had this to say:
We cannot afford to deploy the air defence and anti-submarine escorts that would be necessary to protect the carrier . . .

If the mother of navies, the British Navy, is in a position to say that, what would a much smaller navy such as Australia's be in a position to do? Mr Nott went on to say-it should be underlined in Hansard:
I don't believe any Government would order a carrier today.

This statement was made by the person who was selling the carrier. The Australian Government has accepted the carrier at a cheap price, but nothing is cheap when the whole concept will distort not only the naval force structure of Australia but also its whole defence structure. It is for these reasons that we propose that the matter go to the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, the Defence Sub-committee of which is currently undertaking a review of the Australian Defence Force structure. It is a very appropriate group of members of the Australian Parliament to consider a matter that has been dealt with by this Government very lightly.

I want in the time available to me to take up a point that follows from a question that I put on notice to the Minister for Defence some four months ago and to which I have just received a reply. It is in relation to the United States production of the FA18 aircraft. There are very real doubts about not only the production volume of the FA18s but also their production rate. The Minister indicated in his statement on the FA18s that he realised there was a risk. He said:
The chief risk appears to be the possibility of reduction in the production rate in the early years of the program, thus increasing production cost.

Not only is there a very real doubt about the production rate but also there is a very real doubt about the production volume. The Minister, in his reply to my question, said that the target for the United States Navy was some 1,366 aircraft. The fact is that the total already has been reduced by 300 because the United States Marine Corps has purchased the Sea Harrier version of the AV8B aircraft. The Pentagon deducted those aircraft from the bid by the United States Navy for its 1,366 aircraft. So, it is already 300 down in terms of volume. When we come to the question of the production rate, the last figure I can find is that the United States Navy will take only 534 aircraft in the fiscal years 1983 to 1987. That figure is 233 fewer aircraft than were planned in 1980 for the same period. So not only is the production volume down but also the production rate is down. This means only one thing-that the unit cost to the Australian Government will increase. I would very much appreciate having the Minister's response to these comments. I think that the end result will be a significant increase in the presently estimated price of $21.5m for each aircraft. I predict that before delivery the cost will rise to at least $25m in 1981 prices, which is the basis for the pricing of $21.5m. We are going to be caught because already there has been a reduction in the volume and there will be further reductions in the rate of production. This will bring about a heavy increase in the unit cost of the FA18.

I again ask the House to support the amendment because this Parliament needs the facts, the information on which it can make a decision particularly about the Invincible. It is one of the more curious decisions that have been made by this Government. I think that on both sides of the House there has been a lot of concern about the purchase. The only way to clear this up is to have a full investigation by the appropriate committee of this Parliament, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. None of us can vouch for the accuracy of the report which appeared in the Weekend Australian which purported to be a summary of a paper on the Defence Department's latest strategic guidelines on policy and equipment. According to the report there is no relationship between the Department's contemporary strategic thinking and the most recent of the Government's purchases, the Invincible. As I have said, I cannot vouch for the report as I am not privy to the documents. I can say that every point outlined conforms to every bit of public official evidence I have heard and read as a member of the Defence Sub-committee of this Parliament's Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, it establishes five priorities as the considerations which should govern our strategic doctrine, force structure and procurement. They are: Firstly, intelligence collection and surveillance of areas of approach to our southern regions; secondly, a strike capacity as a deterring influence and for strategic operations; thirdly, a capacity to combat air and sea borne operations against widely dispersed targets in northern Australia; fourthly, air defence of Australian forces, facilities, population and industrial centres particularly in the north; and, fifthly, the need for highly mobile ground forces to defend a wide range of geographically dispersed civil and military facilities.

Throughout the report it is alleged that our defence officials identify the north as our primary area of strategic concern and stress the need for competent air defence. Nowhere is there featured a requirement for an additional anti- submarine warfare capability, yet this was the justification of both the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) for the purchase of the aircraft carrier. In other words, what will be the focal point of our Navy, in large measure the determinant of the nature and priority of future naval equipment purchases, is unrelated to any strategic objective that the Government's advisers see as essential. It is unrelated to any likely threat that they can foresee to the security of this country and is worthless in the areas that they define as of most importance in planning the defence of this nation. I do not believe governments need to agree with their advisers. There are some positions adopted by the Department both in evidence to the Committee and in this leaked set of documents with which I do not agree. For example, I do not agree with the proposition that we should focus our planning exclusively or substantially on the most immediate level of threat, which is essentially one of low level harassment and limited lodgment. I believe effective deterrence is to determine the maximum level of threat that Australia would be capable of deterring from within its own resources and to structure our defence base accordingly. On the way to achieving this objective we will pick up a capability to deter lesser levels of threat.

I think there are dangers in the current approach of the Department. They are these: Firstly, in circumstances where limited resources are available concentration on the most immediate threat might well produce imbalances in our Defence Force which will be difficult to remedy in a crisis of greater magnitude than anticipated. For example, with a correct emphasis on our maritime strike capability, we might nevertheless neglect the importance to our deterrent capacity of a sufficiently mobile and capable ground force. Such a force would increase substantially the forces necessary for a successful invasion of this country. Such a force would increase substantially the forces necessary for a successful invasion of this country. Secondly, such a concentration again might well cause us to neglect important aspects of our defence infrastructure; for example, aids to communications such as appropriately located roads and railways , dispersed facilities for military operations and self-sufficiency in productive capabilities. The closure of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is a betrayal of those obligations. Similar considerations ought to apply to Williamstown.

Thirdly, concentration on immediate low level threats gives too much latitude for state of the art purchases with the risk that important capabilities which quantity at the expense of some quality might provide. In regard to the purchase of the FA18s such attitudes may well have caused us to rule out too early the desirability of a mix of aircraft, such as some FA18s and some others cheaper but able to be purchased in larger numbers. The purchase of such highly expensive items might also set back the purchase of AWAC aircraft and other aids to the effective air defence of this country. It does not matter much if we consider the risks to be low but there is a problem if our calculation is wrong.

These leaks are indicative of a deep disturbance in the Defence Department. They signal a fear that the Government has made a decision which will have consequences that are highly damaging to our defence capability. The article that appeared in the Weekend Australian is not the only indication of a degree of concern within the Defence Department. I draw the attention of honourable members to an article which appeared in the Pacific Defence Reporter of August 1981 which, according to the editor, was from two officers senior in the Service . It presents an excellent argument against the purchase of the aircraft carrier . I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did indicate to my honourable friend that leave would be granted. I said I would do so in charity. I do hope that the House returns to the discipline adopted by Speaker Cameron a quarter of a century ago that argument should not be included in Hansard. I resist the temptation to take small points in this House but I do not particularly admire the anonymity of the authors. I would appreciate it if the honourable gentleman would identify them.
-Is leave granted?
—I grant leave but I will attend to the document when I reply.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: The document read as follows-
THE CASE AGAINST THE CARRIER

The article on 'The new carrier and the TFF' in the June issue of PDR was read with much interest. One of our staff officers has drafted a reply to Mr Grazebrook. We hope that it will promote some discussion on the subject.

This was the opening sentence in a letter written by two highly responsible officers in two of the Services to PDR. To protect the writers, and the author of the paper, we have refrained from publishing their names.-Editor

With decisions on both the TTF and carrier still not finalised, the article by A. W. Grazebrook in the June PDR was most timely. Unfortunately the article contained a disappointing combination of fact, half truth, unsubstaniated assumption and innuendo which robbed it of the impact its timing should have assured. The random scatter of this unfortunate mix has produced an article that demands comment but almost defies step-by-step analysis.

Our current maritime force structure contains, or will soon contain, three assets with a stand-off capability to sink ships at sea. These assets are: those naval escorts to be Harpoon-fitted, the Oberon submarine and the Harpoon-fitted P3 Orions. Each of these assets has capabilities that suit it to particular situations about which the following generalisations can be made.

Conventional submarines lack mobility and must be in the right place at the right time. However, when in the right place, submarines have the unmatched combination of highly-sensitive passive sensors, covertness of manoeuvre, and high capability weapons that enable them to consistently attack ships from outside the range of ship's sensors. This proven capability gives them the ability to sink specific units whether a group, or a number of units either grouped or singularly. Dollar for dollar, a submarine in the right place is the most efficient asset available for sinking ships (or submarines) at sea.

The P3 Orion has outstanding mobility that gives it the ability to carry out a single-handed surveillance and attack mission throughout a large area. Weapons load is limited but a number of aircraft in co-ordinated operation overcome this limitation. Its chief disadvantage is the inability to always distinguish specific targets among medium and high densities of shipping when forced to operate outside the range of modern surface-to-air missiles.

Surface ships need assistance in over-the-horizon targetting and reconnaissance and are themselves vulnerable to cruise missile attack. They can, however, carry a large number of missiles and maintain a continuous presence for protracted periods (provided they are part of a properly structured force).

Overall our existing maritime strike assets are all capable of various degrees of autonomous operation, are complementary, and when fully optimised, possessed of a considerable maritime strike capability.
Except in the simplest of scenarios, aircraft such as the F-18 or F-111s are not capable of autonomous maritime strike operations.

The often protracted nature of pre-strike reconnaissance and the extra problems then presented by strike direction suggest that the involvement of existing assets would necessarily be at such a level that these assets could mount a sizeable attack by carrying and firing their own weapons. In short, except in the simplest circumstances, such aircraft are weapons carriage and delivery platforms only and as such could probably only usefully contribute when all the other assets, necessarily in the area, had fired their not inconsiderable number of weapons. The usefulness of such capability obviously depends on individual threat scenarious, but the substantial potential of existing assets suggests that this area is well covered, and that supporters of the TFF as a maritime strike asset seem to have jumped on the Harpoon wagon and tailored their threat to meet their potential assets.

In modern warfare the cruise missile and the submarine launched torpedo both represent a serious threat to naval surface units. Indeed when such a threat appears, albeit from a single submarine or cruise missile platform, naval surface units seldom even transit except as a group. Twenty-five years ago ships were judged by their individual capability against a submarine: 15 years ago the judgment was based on performance as one of a pair; now they sail in groups and aim to detect submarines in time to avoid them.

Today, ships seldom hunt submarines. Kill capability as a design aim is a thing of the past: today's criterion is survivability when one of a group, surrounded by other ships and supported by helicopters, fixed-wing aircraft and (sometimes) friendly submarines. Submarines killed by the group are killed in self defence: even groups of ships don't go out hunting submarines.

When the 500-knot skimmer cruise missile is added to the submarine threat we have today's multi-threat environment. Ship's anti-aircraft missile systems are generally regarded as most effective against all types of manned aircraft and preparation for an ''iron bombs'' attack on a modern force would sensibly include some white scarfs for the briefings.

This is not so for cruise missiles which fly very low, have a very small radar cross-section, can be launched in salvos and home actively. To counter this threat Close In Weapons Systems (CIWS) such as Phalanx have been developed, and while trials prove that such systems can reduce the effect of cruise missiles they add to the already vast and complex array of defensive system ships have been forced to fit to achieve a reasonable survivability quotient.

As a result of the ascendency of the submarine and the cruise missile over the naval surface ship, much naval surface posture has become defensive, with avoidance of conflict and survivability foremost in the criteria of design philosophy and tactics. To wrest the initiative and maintain the naval surface units status as the ultimate across-water power projection tool, those powers with the assets, such as the USN, have attack Carrier Battle Groups (CVBG). These battle groups are based on a huge carrier with AEW and fighter assets to counter the air launched cruise missile or bomber threat and a full spectrum of ASW assets to counter the cruise missile and attack submarines. Every avenue in the multi-threat situation is covered and in the majority of cases a battle group can look after itself and still have significant capability to project power. Like the gorilla whose master replied ''wherever he likes'', to the question ''where does the pet gorilla sleep?'' the battle group is a very powerful force that can go just about where it likes. Nevertheless, to project power as they do, such groups must devote vast resources to survivability, with 24-hours a day AEW, ASW and CAP air effort and similar efforts by surface units.

Only with a force as big as a CVBG can part of the effort be directed away from survivability to capability. The self-defence air effort, for instance, must be maintained 24-hours a day and show a surplus before air assets can be used in power projection. Survivability, when it involves the destruction of the enemy, is of course also capability. However, the point here is that to just break even against the combined submarine and cruise missile threat posed by only a relatively few submarines and missile delivery platforms requires something approaching a CVBG, and to convert survivability into offensive capability can take full CVBG performance.

There is a limit to how far a battle group can be scaled down and retain these qualities. Anything less than 24-hours a day from the self-defence air effort will leave the group vulnerable. A group denied these air assets when either threat is present fights without the assets that keep the enemy at arms length and must grapple with an enemy that is vastly superior in the clinches. Australia cannot afford a full scale battle group or even a scaled down one. Operation of the type of carrier group we can afford against a determined enemy equipped with modern conventional submarines and a cruise missile capability would most probably mean very heavy losses for us. Land-based air assets could reduce these losses but our present force structure and geography restrict severely the potential of help from this source. Rather than the gorilla that sleeps where he likes, our surface naval forces could, in such circumstances, be better likened to the small monkey on a chain who sleeps when and where he is put. In today's multi-threat environment, with carriers, it's very much a matter of get big or get out.

Two operation considerations that add to the vulnerability of naval surface vessels are fuel and refits. Destroyers and frigates have a relatively short- range and need tankers or port refuelling for protracted or long-range operation . Guaranteeing fuel is normally only a logistics operation during peacetime, but in war the availability of tankers and port facilities within Australia's huge area of interest may be a critical factor.

Even more important than the refuelling problem is the need for refit. The long hours ships spend at sea means that lengthy overhauls (refits) are unavoidable. This is not a problem when numbers are such that capability is maintained by a planned refit program. However, with small numbers the need for refit obviously reduces the force capability. A single unit provides the extreme example: it is either available or it is not. In general terms, with three ships planners can expect two to be fully operational some of the time and one all of the time.

In the case of all surface naval units operated in small numbers to have one ship fully operational at all times needs two ships, as one is almost permanently in refit or work-up. This fact is often overlooked when cost- effectiveness comparisons between various defence assets are made. A squadron of P3 Orion aircraft and an FFG 7 are about the same price but the squadron is capable of continuous operation for years and the ship isn't. Continuous operation requires two ships, not one.
Perhaps the ultimate in vulnerability is a single unit, the only one we have, in dock for refit when its capability is needed at sea.

Current submarines and cruise missiles find surface ships, even well equipped naval vessels, very vulnerable. Only CVBGs can produce the combined abilities to adopt a capability posture rather than the more usual survivability posture lesser groups must assume. Battle groups cannot be scaled down past a certain point (in general terms this point is when their self-defence air assets cannot operate 24-hours-a-day) and carrier operations is one area where you get big or you get out.

Adding to this battle vulnerability are the need for guaranteed fuel for ships planning remote or protracted operations and the fact that refit and work-up periods are so time demanding that two ships are needed to guarantee one ship at sea at all times.

So it is that with carriers that what we need is big ones, not little ones, and two, not one. As the little one we are planning to buy will cost, with aircraft, at least $A1,000m, and big ones, fully equipped, cost tens-of-billions we obviously cannot afford a viable weapons system of this type.

But $A1,000m would buy a third squadron of P3Cs and a squadron of submarines. The P3Cs could provide the necessary fixed-wing ASW air assets for naval ships operating in Australian and adjacent waters and would contribute to the area ASW efforts. The extra submarines would increase the size of our submarine force enough so that their relative immobility would be reduced in importance by their greater numbers and the submarine force could then provide both anti-shipping and a very effective area ASW capability.

These P3 and submarine assets, properly used, would significantly reduce the capability of an enemy to operate either surface ships or submarines within Australian waters and waters adjacent to Australia and would consequently contribute to the safety of all shipping in many areas.

Additionally, these assets represent the spreading of capital outlay over many relatively cheap individual units rather than on a single expensive unit. When the survivability quotient is also considered, this produces a force capable of graceful degradation during protracted operations over a wide area, not the vulnerable 'all eggs in one basket' asset with a capability to work in only one area at a time, some of the time, represented by the carrier.

While this force structure would provide a more efficient and durable counter to both the submarine and the cruise missile, it would not obviate the need for the maximum possible self-defence for all naval surface vessels and some means of countering the shadowing aircraft and the subsequent cruise missile. An Air Early Warning Capability (AEW) combined with a long-range air defence missile ( the range of which would ideally exceed that of the cruise missile) would obviously be a worthwhile combination in this area and even in a relatively rudimentary form should represent a considerable threat to a shadowing patrol aircraft. Without constant AEW, VSTOL fighter type aircraft in the number possible on a small carrier represent almost no threat to a shadowing aircraft, consequently the use of AEW aircraft (even though land base) and missiles would be a substantial increase in capability over the small carrier with VSTOL fighters option. This AEW capability would be additional, not alternative, and would require funds not now planned. But something must be done.
To buy more surface vessels but not increase the survivability of existing units would be folly.

Overall, the relativities of maritime warfare assets have been presented as generally understood today. The P3Cs and submarines are the best ASW and maritime strike assets we have and it seems logical that we should be optimising our known strengths and avoiding our weaknesses. Our force must be able to take damage and continue to fight, perhaps in a number of areas at once and for protracted periods. One 'eggs in one basket' carrier will not do this for us: more P3s and submarines will, at the very least, place us well along the road to achieving that capability. We can't afford a gorilla but we don't want a monkey on a chain instead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House, and the Minister. The Government is well aware of this division and I think it has been panicked into this decision by two assessments which really are an insult to it. The first is an assessment by the advocates of the aircraft carrier that they are losing the internal debate and that they must act now if they are to benefit from the inertia of the oft alleged replacement syndrome which afflicts governments and the Department. The syndrome is the last planning cliche in the mind set of those responsible for decisions that can legitimise the purchase. Even though the Invincible was ruled out earlier by the advocates of an aircraft carrier as a suitable replacement for the Melbourne, it has been dragged in as the only thing kicking around that can be bought at short notice. The second assessment-and I think this is a really quite critical assessment-is that the Government is responding to carrier advocates who see it as being on a downward electoral slide. They know that the ALP will not support a carrier purchase.

SPEECH.PARA: Why does the Government respond in the way in which it does to our defence problems? It appears to have no defence doctrine. It hopes for an ignorant electorate that will permit it to go on announcing purchases of equipment that either are not going to be purchased for years, though the implication is that they will arrive tomorrow, or are unrelated to any clear purpose. It likewise announces intentions to proceed with capital facilities then chops them back at the slightest hint of budgetary problems. It does all this because deep down it does not believe in the direction of all clear headed defence thinking in this country. It does not believe in a defence doctrine based on the defence of Australia. It says it does but the fact is that when it comes to dotting the i's and crossing the t's of defence policy, when it comes to detailed planning it cannot sustain the relentless intellectual effort necessary to achieve the objective. It wants to move away from the doctrine of defence self reliance to one based on forward defence. We do not call it forward defence; we call it co- operation with allies in strategic concern, a contribution to regional defence. There is no other explanation for the purchase of this carrier and for many of the other Government defence decisions.

The carrier has value if added to an American carrier battle group. It has value if we want to intimidate Fiji, New Zealand, New Caledonia or whatever. It has absolutely no value to the defence of Australia. I really believe that this purchase of the carrier is an indication of a quite substantial shift in the orientation of Government defence doctrine which has yet to be explained to this House.

The cost to Australia is that very real threats to our security will not be dealt with, that our defence force structure will be distorted and that important equipment purchases will be delayed or dropped. The Navy will suffer from this as much as the other two services. My State and the northern and western reaches of this country, which on all defence analysis, along with the Northern Territory and the North of Queensland, ought to be the focus of defence planning at the moment, will suffer most of all. Where is the patrol boat base in the north-west of Western Australia that keeps being promised but which the Government managed to slide out of in the last Budget? When will HMAS Stirling be properly utilised by the Royal Australian Navy rather than being left purely as a visiting spot for allied visitors on rest and recreation visits? When will work on the upgrading of our northern air bases be completed and will they ever have proper air defence systems? I would also like to know whether the development of those airbases was included in any of the cut-backs or delays that were announced a couple of weeks earlier. Will the Government ever give serious consideration to the defence infrastructure of that area to ensure that road, rail and air connections do permit a rapid transfer of ground forces to the area?

It is time that serious consideration is given to the relocation of the Orions from Salisbury in South Australia to Pearce or Learmonth. The initial capital costs would be considerable but so would be the long term savings. It is time too that the potential of Cockburn Sound and Fremantle as an Australian submarine base was properly realised. None of this will be possible under this Government because it has no real convictions about the need for the defence of Australia. It will dream up a threat for electoral purposes while knowing the threat is remote and then plan our forces in a way that tacitly acknowledges the remoteness of that threat. It is I believe a deeply intellectually lazy Government when it comes to the question of defence. I believe that its decisions are now regarded by many people within the Minister's department as too costly to be pursued in terms of the security of the country. I think that the amendment that we have moved is an absolutely vital amendment at this stage. I want to talk about some other matters but I have decided to conclude at this point as I see that my colleague the Chairman of the Sub-Committee on Defence has entered the chamber. I would like to give him some time to put his views before the proceedings conclude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dealing with the Government's decision to purchase the Invincible and the FA18 as our new tactical fighter I would like to refer to the manner in which the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) and his advisers, both uniformed and civilian, conducted this most demanding and complex operation. Their attention over what was finally a period of years in relation to the FA18 aircraft and many, many months in the case of the Invincible was impeccable. Consider the momentous factors involved. First, consider the expenditure, as the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) mentioned, of possibly $3 billion-and maybe it will go beyond that. Secondly, consider the daunting consideration that these fighter aircraft and the replacement aircraft carrier have to take us into the next century. We should also consider the all worrying inhibition of deciding whether these major contributions to our air defence and maritime defence were merited when balanced against our general defence requirements. Finally, we should consider the most important factor of Australian industry participation. Would this purchase stimulate activity which would lead to the employment of many Australians and give industry a much needed boost? Well, in the case of the FA18 it very clearly will. I am sure that in the case of the Invincible, industry participation will undoubtedly go beyond what was indicated by the Minister when he addressed the House in relation to the purchase.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite remarkable that when the Minister for Defence announced the decision of the Government to purchase the FA18 there was no significant objection from any section of the community. In fact the reaction to this momentous decision was quite remarkable when contrasted with the decision to purchase the F111 aircraft. We know the regrettable agonising that went on and on in relation to that decision by the Australian Government. I think the reason for this reaction is that it had become very clear to the Australian public that very deep and significant consideration had been given to the decision finally to purchase this aircraft. The same applies to the purchase of the Invincible. I must confess that, probably through ignorance and not really understanding in the first place the scenario in which the Invincible would have to fit, I was somewhat hesitant about coming to a decision as to whether or not this was a suitable purchase. I had to depend on the views of people who I believe know very much more about these things than I.

I had to fit the purchase into the scenario of the briefings I received when I visited Washington and, more particularly, Hawaii. Those briefings provided a background for the role into which this superb aircraft carrier must fit. The picture, as presented to me by Admiral Long and his advisers, is that prowling around the Indian Ocean-we talk a lot about the Indian Ocean without giving much consideration to the Pacific Ocean-are probably 30 to 40 Soviet nuclear submarines. If they are not nuclear submarines at least they are highly armed. But we do not consider that there is probably an equal number of Soviet submarines in the Pacific area. There is a sophisticated base of operations in the northern Pacific which I am told by people at this level is as equally developed and capable as the base that is provided for the Warsaw Pact nations. Therefore it became quite obvious that we had to have a weapon that could deal with submarines. I would agree with the honourable member for St George that we would like to have it both ways; we would like to have an aircraft carrier with a great strike capability that would go beyond submarines.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Curfew at Sydney Airport-Small Business: Import Quotas-International Disarmament -Death of Dr Clyde Fenton-Kim Dae Jung-Bruce Highway

PROCTEXT.PARA: Curfew at Sydney Airport-Small Business: Import Quotas-International Disarmament -Death of Dr Clyde Fenton-Kim Dae Jung-Bruce Highway

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I asked the Minister for Transport ( Mr Hunt) a question concerning the current consideration of an application to allow passenger jets to land at Sydney during curfew hours. The Minister, in his reply, was very careful to deal only with an application from Trans Australia Airlines for an all-hours operation of the Airbus. I agree. I think all honourable members on this side of the House would understand that the Government is unlikely to favour TAA's application until Ansett Airlines of Australia is in a position to compete on an equal footing. Later this year Ansett will bring into operation its Boeing 767s. I am reliably informed that a deal has already been done and that an agreement for both aircraft to operate during curfew hours will be forthcoming. The justification will be that the domestic airlines are in grave financial difficulties and that night operations will assist them financially. It will be claimed also that the aircraft-that is, the Airbus and the Boeing 767s-have lower noise levels than other passenger aircraft and would meet noise abatement criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: The spectre of night operations will become a reality before Christmas. The one -quarter of a million residents of Sydney who are already directly and adversely affected by aircraft noise will be subjected to regular flights throughout the night. There is no such thing as a quiet aircraft at 3 o'clock in the morning. We would have no objection to 24-hour operations by airlines at a second Sydney airport which was well removed from residential areas. But the Fraser Government has failed to face up to its responsibilities. It continues to dither and delay on constructing a second airport. The only way that Ansett, TAA and the international airlines can operate financially and effectively is to have an airport which is available 24 hours a day. We have made that point time and again. That second airport is a vital necessity for the financial well-being of the airlines. The Opposition has opposed and will continue to oppose putting another nail in the coffin of the curfew at Sydney Airport. If the airlines want -as they do-24-hour operations, it is for them to put pressure on the Federal Government to ensure that a second airport is built for Sydney. I represent the people of St George who are directly and adversely affected even now by the operations of aircraft but who would be more so affected by aircraft operating curfew hours, particularly passenger aircraft. Any suggestion, recommendation or decision by this Government that the aircraft will operate through curfew hours will receive our opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are far too many cases where small businesses are threatened, not by the operations of the market or by bad luck, but by the indecisive and bungling intervention of government. Nowhere does this appear more the case than where tariff quota policies are concerned. I believe the House should be aware of the damage that is being done to Australian small businesses by inconsistent and arbitrary government controls which take the form of granting or withholding import quotas or the quixotic variation of import controls against the interests of both small businesses and consumers. Officialdom has in fact dealt in tariffs and in percentages of tariffs and has sold the right to import more to the highest bidder with the result that an entire trade appears to have grown up in the purveying of official licences to import.

SPEECH.PARA: This situation has been glaringly evident in regard to the importation of footwear. The House might think that the local shoemaking industry has been more than adequately protected as a result of a sudden decision by the Whitlam Government to restrict imports, a decision imposed on the industry in September 1974, and which disrupted many transactions which had been entered into in good faith by Australian importers. However, since 1974 importers of footwear have been subjected to a bizarre numerology invoked in an effort to reconcile the conflicting claims of importers and the protected local manufacturers. To carry out this design, a bewildering procession of combinations and permutations, all to be enforced by weird calculations, has been foisted upon importers. Let me put before the House the weird mathematics which have been conjured up to impose the latest vagaries of policy on importers of footwear.

The base performance of importers has been measured. This has been declared to be their imports for the period 1 July 1978 to 1 July 1980. As a strange sequel to this, an interim quota was worked out to set the number of imports to be allowed each importer at a basic tariff for the period 1 September 1980 to 31 December 1981. In each case this was to be, for these 16 months, 16/12ths-that is the fraction-of the base performance figure; that is, the total import of shoes between 1 July 1978 and 1 July 1980. This number, and only this number, of shoes could be brought in by each importer. The level of trade in fact was to be frozen at the level of the base period, irrespective of any new circumstances and any changes in the state of the market.

The same petrification of the trade is to continue for the next seven years, for during this period each importer will be allowed to bring in each year 42.85 per cent of its base period import performance at a 40 per cent duty. Each year the right to import 7.15 per cent of the base period amount will be auctioned off by companies bidding by tender. Finally, if a company at present wishes to import more pairs of shoes, either because it has not matched the winning tenderer's bid, or because it is simply seeking to stay in business, it can continue to import more shoes at a penalty rate of $15 per pair of shoes on top of the basic tariff of 40 per cent of the shoes' value.

As an actual example of the kind of official harassment this system means in practice, I wish to put before the House the experience of one Australian firm, Philip Graves Pty Ltd. Mr Graves is a constituent of mine. This firm has been in existence for over four years as an importer of high quality shoes. The shoes it deals in cost at factory level in Europe $45 to $55 per pair, and it is hard to see how they can outsell Australian products in Australia. Yet Philip Graves Pty Ltd has been placed, with the most detrimental results, in the vortex of this officially imposed confusion and has suffered adverslely in the wheeling and dealing that has resulted. To put it precisely, the company was allowed to import during 1981 some 2,000 pairs of shoes at a tariff of 34 per cent. However , from January 1982 it is allowed to import only 811 pairs a year at a tariff of 40 per cent. To import more the company must tender for a further increase in its own quota. However, it has not been able to match the winning tenderer's bid of an increase of the basic tariff to 71 per cent, which would mean the shoes retailing in Australia at $185 per pair as opposed to $155 per pair under the basic 40 per cent tariff. The only alternative is to import more pairs at the penalty rate which, as a result of normal market operations, means that the price per pair of shoes is raised to almost $188. So overall the company is now in a situation where it can bring in each year only 42.85 per cent of its 1978 to 1980 imports without penalty. Its business is to be shackled, for the next seven years at least, to the performance of those two years irrespective of the state of the market and its present or future opportunities.

What is the purpose of all this? The shoes imported by the company cannot outsell the local product. Also over-protected under this scheme are the large firms which juggle quotas, wheelers and dealers in quotas, and of course the bureaucrats who decide such unaccountable arithmetic. How is the fight against inflation served by this esoteric numerology? I call the House's attention to this matter. Why, in a free enterprise economy, should such firms face ruin because of arbitrary official arithmetic? It is time that the whole process was subjected to closer scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I attended an international conference on disarmament and detente held in Vienna. I wish to repeat some of the remarks which I made in my opening address to the conference because I believe that the whole question of the pursuit of peace is of concern to this House and to the nation. Indeed, the frightening pace at which the world is moving towards nuclear war has become an issue of great concern to many Australians, as will be demonstrated in the rallies for peace to be held throughout Australia in April. The decade of the 1970s was designated by the United Nations as the decade of disarmament and yet it witnessed the greatest increase in production and trade in arms since the end of World War II. During this period total world expenditure on defence and armaments amounted to four trillion dollars-an amount of money so astronomical as to be virtually incomprehensible to the average person.

SPEECH.PARA: Thus we find that the conservative Reagan Administration in the United States of America has increased defence expenditure substantially and plans even more increases. On projected figures, the United States defence expenditure in 1985 will reach a level almost equal to the $US300 billion-estimated in 1982 dollars- spent at the end of World War II and will surpass the real value of United States defence expenditure in either the Korean or Vietnamese conflicts. At the same time, if these trends continue, expenditure on defence by the Soviet Union is also expected to rise sharply. Thus there is a real danger of a nuclear holocaust engulfing the world. The confrontation in Europe between the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces and Warsaw Pact forces has escalated to extremely dangerous proportions. This confrontation will be heightened further by the proposed deployment of 464 cruise missiles and 108 Pershing II missiles by NATO countries, under United States control, by 1983. The United States Administration justifies this by talk of a threat posed by the SS20 tactical nuclear missiles of the Soviet Union and its allies.

In this climate of suspicion, insecurity and fear every nation and every people are inexorably involved because there is no such thing as a limited nuclear war. No nation can hope to escape from the horrors of such a holocaust which threatens to wipe out civilisation. It is our view that both of the super-powers must bear responsibility for the escalation of the arms race and the current increase in world tensions. We recognise that the primary responsibility for this increased tension lies with the current ultra-conservative government of the United States. President Reagan is, in our view, the mouthpiece of the military industrial complex in whose interests it is to increase as much as possible the production of weapons systems. His Government has shown very little interest in questions of disarmament, notwithstanding its rhetoric about peace. President Reagan went as far as to propose the abolition of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Whilst, due to pressure, he has not done so he has placed in control of that agency Eugene Rostow, a man who has publicly said that he is dubious of the Strategic Arms Limitations Talks and other existing arms control agreements.

To escalate further the situation the United States Administration has revived and strengthened the doctrine of linkage by which it seeks to make progress in disarmament talks dependent on what it terms 'the Soviet Union's willingness to cease intervention in the internal affairs of other nations'. These claims are hyprocritical in the extreme. The United States Government has a woeful record of gross interference in the affairs of other nations, such as Vietnam and Chile . It is presently engaged in attempts to destabilise the Nicaraguan Government and it is behind the repression in El Salvador.

The Australian Labor Party has publicly condemned the United States Government on these matters. We have called for an end to United States intervention in Latin America. We have called on the United States to ratify the SALT II Treaty and to begin immediate talks on arms and reductions as envisaged in SALT III. Nevertheless, we as democratic socialists also believe that the Soviet Union must bear responsibility for the current arms race. The official Soviet position is that it does not want military superiority but wants to maintain parity with Western powers. However, it appears to us that the doctine of parity must also be subjected to critical scrutiny. When one has enough missiles to destroy the world 50 times over, is it really necessary to increase these so that one has the capacity to destroy the world 70 or 100 times over simply for the sake of parity? We do not believe so. This is not to say that we advocate wholesale unilateral disarmament on the part of the Soviet Union. However, we believe that , particularly at this critical time in world history, an action by the Soviet Union to reduce some of its arms deployment would be an enormous boost to the peace process and would be applauded by peace loving peoples throughout the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to pay tribute to Dr Clyde Fenton, a truly great Australian, in fact a national hero, who recently died in Melbourne aged 80. Dr Fenton's name may be unfamiliar to honourable members but I am sure that his work, which has become a legend, will be well known, especially to those who are familiar with outback Australia. It was Clyde Fenton who originally started the Northern Territory aerial medical service in 1934. In fact from 1934 until the outbreak of World War II, based in Katherine, Clyde Fenton was the entire aerial medical service. He was its pilot, mechanic and doctor. Most of his activities were confined to the northern half of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: To give honourable members an idea of the enormous challenge he faced I point out that in the course of those six years he covered a quarter of a million miles and flew over 3,000 hours. The important thing about Clyde Fenton's approach was that he saw the potential of air travel for health care in remote areas. He did not see the aeroplane merely as a flying ambulance or as a taxi to get doctors to their patients. Rather he envisaged an integrated form of health care for patients in remote areas. He first arrived in Darwin in 1928 by ship on his way back to Melbourne. For five months he stayed and helped Dr Cecil Cook, who at that time was performing two functions-handling administration of health and quarantine and being chief protector of Aboriginals.

In 1928 he approached the Reverend John Flynn of the Australian Inland Mission about a job as doctor-pilot. However, Flynn was adamant that the two jobs were incompatible and maintained his stance of one man one job. Fenton then left the Territory. In March 1934 he was appointed medical officer at Katherine. He returned to the Territory with a de Havilland Gipsy Moth which he had bought for 500 pounds. He later crashed this aircraft at Victoria Downs station on a trip to the Ord River. His aircraft was eventually replaced by what I suppose would be called one of the first aircraft loan guarantees ever undertaken by the Commonwealth Government. At the time the only aircraft available in the Northern Territory was a Gipsy Moth, belonging to Qantas, which Fenton was urging the Government to obtain for him. Qantas refused to part with the aircraft until the Government either paid for it or guaranteed a loan. Fenton went to the Northern Territory Administrator who sent a telegram to Canberra arranging a loan guarantee within an hour. The new aircraft was registered VH-UOI but for the rest of its life was nicknamed 'IOU' because of its debt.

Most of the stories relating to Clyde Fenton's exploits in the air tell of his dare-devil attitude to flying, his cavalier disregard for regulations and his continual disputes with civil aviation authorities. My mother recalls personally some of his adventurous pranks in Darwin such as the occasion when people were sitting in the gallery of an open-air theatre and Fenton flew his plane between the screen and those watching the movie. On another occasion when he was offended by not having been invited to a garden party at Government House he flew over the function and dropped flour bombs in brown paper bags on the guests . One of his friends said: 'Dangerous as he is in the air, I'm still prepared to fly with him; but drive, never again!'.

Nonetheless it has been said that Clyde Fenton often risked his life to get medical help to those in need. He flew over treacherous country, often at night, with no navigation aids, no radio for communication and often not knowing where he was. He became lost more than once and certainly had more than his fair share of crashes. Fifty years later we in the Northern Territory are still benefiting from Dr Fenton's vision. The Aerial Medical Service is an important part of health care services in the Northern Territory. It is relied on by many people in outlying areas where medical practitioners are few and far between. For his services he was made a member of the Order of the British Empire. At the end of his book Flying Doctor Clyde Fenton quoted two lines of poetry which sum up his achievement. He said:
One crowded hour of glorious life is worth an age without a name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that I have to speak tonight on a matter of grave urgency in an attempt to save the life of a man who is being subjected to brutal treatment in a South Korean prison. I am referring to Kim Dae Jung, the former leader of the Opposition in the South Korean Government, who is at present undergoing a life sentence for conducting what would be construed in Australia as legal activities. It is ironic that I should have to make this appeal to save the life of a great democrat in a house which only recently welcomed a parliamentary delegation from the South Korean Government. I hope that in honour of their visit the South Korean parliamentarians will take note of a request from this chamber that their Government show clemency to Kim Dae Jung. I, and other members in this House, are not alone in our protests at the treatment of Kim Dae Jung. Many parliamentarians and people who represent governments all over the world have called for his release.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest information that I have is that Kim Dae Jung is critically ill and is suffering from serious ailments in a cell which is bitterly cold and confines him in cramped conditions. It is clear that his gaolers are attempting to so weaken him that he will eventually die. He is reported as saying that he has little sleep because he is suffering heart breaking pain. The South Korean Government must know that during the trial no witness or evidence was produced by the prosecution except alleged confessions made by the accused. This made the court proceedings a mockery of real justice.

Mr Kim's only crime was that he had been associated with a left wing movement; but he denied that he had taken part in any riots and pointed out that he was a practising catholic. Mr Kim admitted that he had attended political meetings, made speeches and distributed some political funds to supporters in preparation for his election campaign. In fact, Kim Dae Jung did nothing more radical than many other honourable members on this side of the House and probably on the other side of the chamber also. Even his original arrest was illegal in that he was kidnapped from Tokyo despite strong protests from the Japanese authorities.

The South Korean Government should realise that the Kim Dae Jung problem is not just a matter of the fate of a South Korean democratic figure but a matter directly concerning the democratisation of the South Korean society and the peaceful reunification of the whole country. I call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) to join me in appealing to the South Korean Government to allow Kim Dae Jung to return to his family and, if he so desires, to a life of peace in Japan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity in the adjournment debate tonight to speak of a tour that the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) recently made of the Bruce Highway, which is that part of the national highway between Rockhampton and Townsville. The tour was undertaken at the invitation of Senator Collard from Rockhampton, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean) and me. The invitation had been outstanding for some time. Four weeks ago the Minister, in the company of Mr Hinze, the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, travelled the road in a convoy. I think it was probably the best experience that the Ministers could have had in that they were able to feel the conditions of the road and to see where the funds expended on our roads and national highways go. More importantly, they were able to find out what that stretch of highway is like. I think I am quoting fairly correctly the Minister for Transport when I say that he commented that it was probably the worst section of Commonwealth highway that he had ever experienced. I agree with him.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the trip we hope that some assistance will be undertaken and that additional funds will be provided by the Federal Government to enable the road to be put into a better condition. The national highway system is peculiarly the responsibility of the Federal Government. I understand that the submission to be made to the Government will be a joint one and that Queensland will take the unique step of agreeing to fund a portion of the national highway. Many problems are associated with the highway, particularly that section of it to which I have referred. I will speak later about road safety.

One of the problems is that a section of the road is of gravel construction. No bitumen has ever been laid on it, but that position will be rectified shortly. Many bridges go under water in flood times, thereby stopping traffic at both ends of the section of road involved. Narrow one lane bridges have been in use of the last 30 or 40 years. The pavement is over 20 years old, and pavement life in normally only 15 years. All in all, the Minister acknowledges that this is a bad road. Whilst it is not typical of all national highways in Queensland there is a lesson to be learnt from it.

Road deaths must be associated with road conditions. Whilst the handing over of the Queensland system to the Commonwealth in 1974 left a lot to be desired, I think we have to recognise the fact that there will never be sufficient funds in Australia to make sure that roads are brought up to the standard of those of America. I believe that road deaths are matters of concern for every person who drives on the road. They must look to the safety not only of themselves but also of others. The three great causes of accidents and death have been determined as drinking, speeding and impatience. A combination of these three factors leads to the tremendous road death toll.

I turn to the American experience in relation to speeding. American roads and main highways are certainly in a much better condition than ours. The Carter Administration reduced the speed limit from 100 kilometres an hour to 80 kilometres an hour. In the 12 months immediately following that move there was a reduction in deaths from road accidents of, I understand, some 40 per cent. There was a reduction by some 50 per cent in the number of accidents that affected the health of people. Fuel consumption dropped by 25 per cent. A special highway patrol makes sure that people drive at 80 kilometres an hour. People become accustomed to driving at that speed and as a result reap the benefits of fewer deaths and accidents and lower fuel consumption.

I have maintained that the proper speed for a driver should be the combination of these factors: The driver's ability-this should be the subject of very severe tests by the police-the nature of the car that is being driven, the climatic conditions and the road surface. After this combination of conditions is taken into account it is up to the individual driver to suggest the speed at which he or she can drive. I maintain that, because of the condition of the Bruce Highway and the roads in Queensland and the rest of Australia, that speed is less than 100 kilometres an hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few more remarks about the problem of peace in Europe. Let me say something about the immediate problems. Everyone is aware of the escalation process there. Talks are taking place in Geneva to see whether some reversal of that process can be achieved. I am not optimistic that these talks, as presently structured, will succeed. The reason is that the United States Administration and the Soviet Union have positions which are very far from each other. President Reagan has put forward the so- called zero option whereby the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers will scrap their proposal for introducing the Pershing and cruise missiles by 1983 in return for the Soviets removing all SS20 missiles aimed at Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Soviets perceive this offer as one sided and unfair, and we understand that point of view. However, it should be pointed out that the very fact that an offer has been made and that talks are taking place in the current tense atmosphere are testament to the success of the peace movement in Europe. The continued protests of the people of Western Europe have forced the Reagan Administration at least to make an offer and to talk. This is an optimistic note in a gloomy situation. Because of the unsatisfactory nature of the United States proposal from the Soviet point of view, President Brezhnev has made a counter offer in which he proposes the so-called zero option. This has two points. The first is that if NATO scraps its plans to deploy the Pershing and cruise missiles the Soviet Union will automatically reduce a considerable number of the SS20s. Secondly, if NATO reduces some of its existing nuclear weapons the Soviet Union will reduce its SS20s by an equivalent number.

Whilst there is merit in the Soviet proposal, it is widely perceived in the West as not going far enough and not being sufficiently balanced. This is the perception not simply of conservative governments; it is also the perception of the social democratic governments of France and West Germany. However, unlike conservatives in the West, we democratic socialists perceive merit in the Soviet proposals and see them as providing the basis of negotiation. However, more importantly, we believe that a compromise between the United States and Soviet positions is possible and can be achieved. In this regard social democratics and democratic socialist governments throughout the world are working towards bringing together the Soviet Union and the United States in an attempt to achieve such a compromise and to begin a real process of reduction of nuclear armaments in Europe and throughout the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 10.30 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government still intend to sell migrant centres to private enterprise.

(2) If so, what arrangements will be made in relation to staff presently working at these centres, and in particular (a) will the private company taking over the centres give an undertaking to employ existing staff (b) will accumulated sick leave be portable (c) will any guarantee of permanent employment be given to these staff and (d) when will the takeover occur.

(3) Are the provision of services such as welfare, housing, youth leader, nursing sister and child care proposed to be transferred to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; if so, can he say whether all staff working in these services will be transferred to that Department.
(4) If staff are not transferred, what will be the situation.
(5) In view of the uncertainty surrounding the future of staff at migrant centres, will he undertake to resolve these matters as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Action is currently being taken to transfer the management of the accommodation and catering functions of Commonwealth Government migrant centres to the private sector.

(2) It is the Government's expectation that staff associated with these functions will be made offers of employment by the new operator. Attempts will be made to come to an arrangement whereby the staff will be able to retain their accrued sick leave benefits upon transfer. The extent to which these objectives can be achieved will be subject to negotiations with the successful tenderer. Steps are being taken to resolve these matters as quickly as possible. However, in view of the complex nature of the contractual arrangements to apply, it is likely to be some months before the transfer of the migrant centre functions will be effected.

(3) and (4) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has reviewed the non-catering and non-accommodation services provided by Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd in migrant centres. The Report of that Review is being examined by relevant authorities. That Review proposes that the non-catering and non-accommodation functions should continue although the organisational location of some of those functions is a factor still under consideration. Until that matter and associated aspects are resolved it will not be possible to say whether CACS staff presently working in particular functions will be transferred to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(5) See answer to (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What criteria does his Department use to determine a de facto relationship.

(2) What are the figures for (a) investigations into determining a de facto relationship, (b) investigations concluding in (i) the affirmative, (ii) the negative in each of the last 3 years, and (c) de facto relationships existing at present in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In deciding whether a couple are living in a de facto relationship the department of Social Security takes into account all facets of the relationship and is guided by decisions reached by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

This requires consideration of the inter-relationship of the parties and any children in the household; whether that relationship contains any of the characteristics of a relationship of a family unit; the way in which the parties present their relationship to the outside world and the financial arrangements between the parties.
Within this broad concept the following basic matters are considered to be relevant in examining whether a couple should be treated as if they were married :
whether the couple share accommodation;
the duration and stability of the relationship;
whether the couple provide financial support for each other;
the nature and extent of mutual interdependence and support;
whether there are children of the relationship or children of either party living as part of a family unit;
whether there is, and if so in what form, any public or private acknowledgement of the relationship; and
whether there is a sexual relationship between the couple.
These criteria are by no means exhaustive; each case is determined on its individual merits and in an individual case there may be other factors which have relevance.
(2) The information is not available.
